Tool specialties: RenderWare, RenderWare Studio, 3DS Max, Maya, Softimage XSI, Lightwave, Photoshop, SI, SG, VDRender farm & Mocap studio.  Client list: Electronic Arts, Midway, Microsoft, Activision, SEGA, DICE, Interactive Vision, LucasArts, Monte Cristo Games, SpaceLab, Nadeo, WildTangent. The company once owned the development studio Kenjitsu, but sold it eventually.

TransGaming Technologies was a Canadian company established in 2001 by Gavriel State. It specialized in developing software to port games to other platforms such Linux, Macintosh, Xbox, PlayStation 2, and PSP. The headquarters were located in Toronto, with offices in Ottawa and Atlanta. TransGaming was especially known for its Cider portability engine that allows PC games to be enabled on Apple's Intel Macs without redevelopment from the ground-up. The engine acts as a wrapper around the PC game dynamically translating PC API calls to the Mac OS X. The company was also involved with multiplatform deployment of interactive entertainment and the distribution of games for Smart TV set-top boxes. On 11th June 2015 NVIDIA Corporation announced the acquisition of TransGaming’s proprietary cross-platform portability technology for $3.75 million, as an enrichment for its GameWorks real-time graphics and simulation for games. NVIDIA also announced to open a new office in Toronto, Canada. The company was officially closed on 12th June 2015. Founder Gavriel State became Senior Director, Simulation and AI at NVIDIA. The interactive and TV entertainment division was moved to the UK company TransGaming Interactive Ltd. established on 9th June 2016 and since 1st September 2017 known as PlayWorks Digital Ltd.

Avalanche Studios was founded by Christofer Sundberg, Linus Blomberg and Viktor Blomberg in 2003. The studio is located in Stockholm, Sweden and currently employs 90 people. It is the trading name of the company Fatalist Development AB. Avalanche Studios is a privately held development company for independent games. It focuses on original IP or selected high-profile licenses and innovative games technology. In September 2006 the company released its first game, Just Cause. The sequel, Just Cause 2 was released March 2010. In March 2010, Avalanche Studios announced that they formed a new development studio called Expansive Worlds which will be the casual and online games division with a strong focus on community-driven subscription-based titles. Expansive Worlds develops and publishes theHunter, which was acquired in February 2010 from Emote Games Ltd. The Avalanche Engine (current version 2.0) is the studios' proprietary engine. The engine is focused on large landscapes with varied climates zones. The engine also features advanced weather effects and day-to-night cycles. The engine is used in Just Cause, Just Cause 2 and theHunter. The company also has subsidiaries in New York and Malmö. Until 30 September 2025, they also had a studio in Liverpool. It is not to be confused with WB Games | Avalanche.
Gearbox Publishing is the publishing arm of Gearbox Software.
Milkstone Studios is a small independent game company based in the north of Spain. It was founded by Alejandro González and Miguel Herrero around 2009. Their target platform is Xbox LIVE Indie Games.

Sonnori (손노리) was a South Korean company that was established in 1994 as a development team of Softry, and later of Phantagram. The company became independent in February 1998. Sonnori is best known for their work on the Astonishia Story games.
Spike Chunsoft, Inc. is the North-American subsidiary of Spike Chunsoft Co., Ltd., established in 2017, for localization and publishing of its own games on the US market.

Tin Man Games is an independent game development studio based in Melbourne, Australia, founded by Neil Rennison and Matt Lacey. Specializing in digital gamebooks – interactive fiction/RPG style games where you control the story – Tin Man has worked many different games. Notables include Tin Man’s own Gamebook Adventures series, 2000 AD’s Judge Dredd, and the popular Fighting Fantasy series by Ian Livingstone and Steve Jackson.
bitComposer Games GmbH, founded in March 2009, is an independent publishing company with headquarters in Frankfurt/Main Eschborn in Germany.

D Wonderland was founded in 1982 in Tokyo by two brothers, Toshirō and Eiji Yokoyama as T&E Soft. They are best known for their Hydlide series, as well as various golf games. In 2002 T&E was renamed D Wonderland. In 2003 Toshirō Yokoyama founded Digital Golf, which continued publishing games under T&E brand. As a result, D Wonderland is often named "Old T&E", while Digital Golf is referred to as "New T&E". T&E software was dissolved in 2019. D4 Enterprise obtained the software copyrights of T&E.

Fireshine Games is a publisher for indie games, founded as Sold Out Sales and Marketing Limited in late 2013 after spinning out from the Mastertronic Group. It is led by Garry Williams and James Cato. While it initially used the same name as Sold Out Sales & Marketing Ltd. (1994-2017), a budget release publisher bought by Mastertronic in 2005, Fireshine did not re-enter the budget release market and instead focused on digital and occasionally physical distribution and publishing of independent games.

Gearbox Software LLC is based in Plano, Texas (USA) and was founded in January 1999 by a group of experienced 3d game artists, designers and engineers: Randy Pitchford, Brian Martel, Stephen Bahl, Landon Montgomery and Rob Heironimus. They formerly worked together at Rebel Boat Rocker, Inc. until the studio went out of business. Pitchford and Martel previously worked together at 3D Realms, and Montgomery used to work at Bethesda Softworks. The company initially worked closely together with Valve on titles in the Half-Life franchise. They ported the game to the PlayStation 2 and were responsible for the three expansions: Opposing Force (1999), Blue Shift (2001) and Decay (2001 - only released as a part of the Half-Life PS2 version). A Dreamcast version they had in development was eventually cancelled. The team was also involved with Counter-Strike and Condition Zero. Around 2002, they started forming relationships with other publishers, which led to the PC versions of 007: Nightfire (2002), Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3 (2002) and most notably the Windows version of Halo: Combat Evolved (2003). The studio's first game based on in-house IP was the first-person warfare shooter Brothers in Arms: Road to Hill 30 (2005), it marked the first game in a short-lived series that branched out to a wide range of platforms. As a departure from their FPS history, Gearbox Software created the Wii version of Samba de Amigo in 2008. In the 2010s, Gearbox Software released the Borderlands series, Duke Nukem Forever and Aliens: Colonial Marines. Since 2013, they have owned the Homeworld IP, licensing development out to Blackbird Interactive. In December 2015, the main company was joined by a secondary studio Gearbox Studio Québec. Since 2016, Gearbox Software has run the Gearbox Publishing label, joined in 2022 by the San Francisco branch purchased from Perfect World.  On 2 February 2021, Gearbox Software became part of the Embracer Group as its own operational unit. On 22 November 2022, Eidos Shanghai was transferred from the CDE Entertainment operating group to Gearbox and renamed Gearbox Studio Shanghai. On 28 March 2024, Embracer Group sold Gearbox Software to Take-Two Interactive for US$ 460 million. This sale included Gearbox Montréal and Quebec studios, as well as most of the company's intellectual properties. Gearbox Publishing San Francisco and its belonging subsidiaries and properties would remain with Embracer, and was renamed to Arc Games shortly afterwards as it no longer had any rights to the Gearbox name.

Just Trains is the specialist railway label of Just Flight, operating in the UK but also offering worldwide download versions. The divisions is specialized in publishing realistic train simulators, both full games and expansions.

New World Computing, Inc. was a North American video game developer and publisher based in Agoura Hills, California. It was founded in 1984 by Jon Van Caneghem, his wife Michaela, and Mark Caldwell. They are best known for their Might and Magic series. On July 10, 1996, the New World Computing was purchased by 3DO Company. A large portion of its staff was laid off in April 2002. The following year 3DO filed for bankruptcy, putting an end to New World Computing's existence as well. The rights for the Might and Magic franchise were sold to Ubisoft.

Northwest Synergistic Software was a US game development and publishing company founded in 1978 in Seattle as Synergistic Software by Robert C. Clardy and Ann Dickens Clardy. In the IBM PC DOS era the company became known for its porting work. Synergistic was acquired by Sierra in 1996 and continued as an independent group in the company until it was shut down on 22nd February 1999. Previously, Robert and Ann had started the company Eclectic Games in 1998 but no games were ever developed as there was insufficient funding. No longer part of Sierra, a number of the staff returned to the name Northwest Synergistic Software and the company left the entertainment market in 2000 to focus on custom fit apparel pattern-drafting software as My Pattern Designer, LLC.

Prime Matter is a premium gaming label of Plaion. After its reveal in June 2021, some games and franchises from its sister label Deep Silver were transferred to Prime Matter. In May 2023, an internal presentation at Plaion announced an upcoming discontinuation of all Plaion publishing labels, including Prime Matter, and the shift to using only the main Plaion company name instead, but it was a process that could gradually take up a year's time.

Rovio is a European mobile and wireless game developer. It was founded in 2003 and it is headquartered in Helsinki (Finland) and also has development studios in Sweden, Denmark, Canada, and Turkey. In April 2023, Sega announced it was set to buy Rovio Entertainment in a deal worth €706 million ($776 million).

The company was founded as LithTech, Inc. in February 2000 as a subsidiary of Monolith Productions, Inc. to handle the development and sales of the LithTech 3d engine that was first introduced in the 1998 game Shogo: Mobile Armor Division. The engine technology was developed in close cooperation with Microsoft. Starting with the 1.0 version, the company went on to create different commercial versions of the engine which could be licensed. In March 2003 it was announced the company name would be changed to Touchdown Entertainment, Inc. as the studio announced to expand its development to console engines with a new 3d engine called Copperhead. Previously, their Jupiter engine was already ported to the Xbox platform as well. The company is presumed to have been merged back into Monolith after the 2004 acquisition by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment Inc.. The different versions of the game engine are:  3D Engine: Lithtech 1.0 (as LithTech, Inc.) 3D Engine: Lithtech Talon (as LithTech, Inc.) 3D Engine: Lithtech Jupiter (as LithTech, Inc.) 3D Engine: Lithtech Jupiter EX (as Touchdown Entertainment, Inc.)

Kairosoft Co.,Ltd is a company that has been producing games since 1996 and exclusively makes simulation games. Almost all of these games were for Japanese personal computers and phones, but they did port one of their games to Western smart-phones called Game Dev Story.
On 2nd November 2015 the company announced Activision Blizzard, Inc. acquired all outstanding shares of King for a total equity value of $5.9 billion, acquiring the company.

Lemon Sky is a CGI art and animation studio based in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia that provides art outsourcing for animation and video game titles. The studio has contributed game art for major titles. Notable animation series' that the studio has been involved with include Nickelodeon's Santiago of the Seas and Middle School Moguls. Lemon Sky is also the creator of the original web animation series: AstroLoLogy.  As of writing, Lemon Sky's production team is made up of over 350 artists and production staff. The studio's headquarters is located in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, with an additional branch located in the city of Penang. The studio's founders, Cheng-Fei Wong and Ken Foong, currently act as the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Creative Officer of the studio respectively.

My.Games is a publishing company uniting the games of My.com B.V. and Mail.Ru LLC. It was launched on 30 May 2019. In October 2022, it was acquired by Leta Capital, and detached entirely from Mail.Ru and the Russian market as a whole. In June 2024, the company launched the Knights Peak label.

Super Rare Games is a video game publisher and distributor based in London, England. The company releases a new rare print physical game for the Nintendo Switch roughly every 3 weeks, available exclusively on their website. This technically makes them the biggest European Switch publisher in terms of number of titles. Super Rare Games titles generally have a small print run of between 3,000 - 6,000 units. The company was founded on February 20th, 2018 by George Perkins, the Head of Doing Stuff. As of 2020 the company is led by Stuart Townsend (Head of Colours), Verity Murphy (Head of Numbers), Lindsey Reed (Head of Customer Happiness), and Ryan Brown (Head of Saying Stuff).

Visceral Games was a development studio of Electronic Arts and operated as part of its EA Games label, focused on mature games. The studio had different offices over the world carrying the Visceral Games name, but the original, main studio was located in Redwood Shores, California (USA). It was in the same location as the EA corporate headquarters. The Visceral Games brand was established on 4 May 2009 in the reformed studio Electronic Arts Redwood Shores Studio, which was already active since 1998. The other Visceral Games studios were located in Los Angeles (USA), Montreal (Canada), Melbourne (Australia) and Shanghai (China). Visceral often provided support to projects with developers from different Visceral branches. In that case, the main Visceral Games (Redwood Shores) company is credited. The studio's closure was announced by Electronic Arts on 17 October 2017, while the studio was working on a Star Wars-licensed game.
A gaming company front for a single developer named Benjamin Kistler.

Founded in 1995, Her Interactive began its life as "Games For Her", a division of American Laser Games located in Albuquerque, New Mexico. As part of American Laser, their primary function was the development of "live-action" software specifically for girls. Their first title, McKenzie & Co., was released that same year followed in 1996 by The Vampire Diaries. In 1997, the Her Interactive division secured the much-sought-after rights to produce games starring Nancy Drew, the famous teenage detective, from copyright owner Simon & Schuster. It is with this license that the company became most famous. In an unprecedented move, Her Interactive bought out American Laser in 1999. The following year, Her Interactive sold American Laser to Digital Leisure Inc. As quoted from the Her Interactive website:  "Her Interactive creates intelligent interactive entertainment for girls of all ages. The company designs, develops and markets award-winning interactive CD-ROM games that offer role-playing mysteries and adventures that girls and adventurous sleuths find both challenging and fun. Her Interactive's Nancy Drew series offers exciting adventure game play without violence or gender stereotypes. With years of experience developing games for girls the company will continue to identify opportunities for interactive products for girls.  Our corporate mission is to lead the industry toward a new standard of intelligent interactive entertainment for girls. By providing role-playing experiences through computer games and online media, Her Interactive's goal is to open the doors of technology to girls by making computers more appealing."   Most of Her Interactive's games have been initially released for Windows, with some ported to other platforms later. The company's first game for the Macintosh was McKenzie & Co. released in 1995. The company re-entered the Macintosh gaming market with Win/Mac hybrid release of Nancy Drew: Trail of the Twister in June 2010.
Imagineering Inc. appears to be an internal development studio of Absolute Entertainment, Inc.

Best known for racing games, Magnetic Fields was founded as Mr. Chip Software in 1982. Later the company employed her most famous developers, Shaun Southern and Andrew Morris, initially working on the Commodore 64. The company became Magnetic Fields in 1988, and created the seminal Lotus and Super Cars lineages for Gremlin. Their last release was  Mobil 1 Rally Championship in 1999. Several developers ended up at Team 3 Games established in 2005.

column1: Sony Interactive Entertainment México S. de R.L. de C.V.

column2: Throwback Entertainment is a publisher of interactive entertainment, founded in 2004. It became known as a company by acquiring most of the assets of the bankrupt Acclaim Entertainment, Inc., in 2006. The library includes 158 different titles and many franchises. In 2019, the company restarted the Mirrorsoft Games label.
Winter Wolves Studio produces sports simulation and RPGs. The company is owned by Celso Riva.

Interactive Magic was founded in 1994 by MicroProse co-founder "Wild" Bill Stealey. The company was taken public in 1998, and had its name changed to iEntertainment Network in 1999. It is based in Cary, a suburb of Raleigh, North Carolina. The company focused on Military Simulations initially and then bought two Internet companies, MPG Net (casual online games) and in 1997 Interactive Creations Inc. (known for WarBirds, an online WW2 combat flight game). Other games in their portfolio include war games such as North vs. South and their The Great Battles series. In February 2000, iEntertainment created iWireless Games, a subsidiary to focus on the emerging wireless games industry. On 7 April 2003, it was announced that iEntertainment Network's corporate status had been changed to 'privately held' to add more value for their stockholders. In November 2006, iEntertainment released the retail game Flyboys Squadron, a World War I combat flight simulator based upon the MGM movie Flyboys. The company continues to develop and release additional games in their Total Simulations Series. This brand includes simulators for aircraft, tanks and other vehicles from World War I through the end of World War II for the PC and Macintosh platforms. On 13 January 2010, the company acquired Thriller New Media, Inc.. In the 2010s, the company continued to release games in the WarBirds series, M4 Tank Brigade, Outdoors Unlimited and BowHunter Games. In the past, the company also had distribution offices in the United Kingdom and Germany.

Atomhawk Design Ltd. is a creative visualisation and digital art production company based in the Gateshead, Newcastle (England), specialized in digital art and design in 2D, 3D and video media, across all interactive industries including film, games and online. Following the demise of Midway, it was founded in 2009 by four former Midway Newcastle employees: Cumron Ashtiani (who also leads the company), Pete Thompson, Corlen Kruger and Steven Pick. On 21 August 2017, the Atomhawk Canada division was opened.
Russian developer and publisher of computer games and mobile services.

Keywords Studios Katowice is a division of Keywords Studios and it based in Katowice, Poland. It was established no earlier than 2019. The division is involved with Functionality QA, Localization QA and Player Support.

column1: Keywords Studios México, S. de R.L. de C.V.

column2: Nexon Corporation was established in 1994 in South Korea. The company develops online games and MMORPGs. The company has divisions in Europe, USA, Japan and Korea, and it acquired Wizet as a subsidiary, known for the popular MapleStory franchise.

Production I.G was founded on 15th December 1987 as I.G Tatsunoko by production manager Mitsuhisa Ishikawa and character designer Takayuki Goto. It was renamed Production I.G, Inc. in 1993. The company has produced a number of acclaimed feature films, OVA (original video animation), TV shows, and videogames. Known productions include Ghost in the Shell (1995), Jin-Roh: The Wolf Brigade (1999), Blood: The Last Vampire (2000) and Ghost in the Shell 2: Innocence (2004). In 2005 they released the TV series IGPX. They have been working on games since 1994, on the screenplay, design, production, animation and visual effects.

Riverhill Soft was founded in 1982 in Fukuoka, Japan. The company produced games in various genres for different platforms, initially focusing on detective adventures such as J.B. Harold and Tōdō Ryūnosuke series.

Ubisoft Kyiv (formerly Ubisoft Kiev) is a development division of Ubisoft Entertainment SA, located in Kyiv, Ukraine and Ubisoft's third studio in Eastern Europe. The formation of the studio was announced on the 29th April 2008. The studio works on different projects along with colleagues in Ubisoft studios worldwide. In March 2018, it was joined by Ubisoft Odesa which are often commonly referred to as Ubisoft Ukraine.
The Montpellier Studios created the Rayman and Tonic Trouble franchise, as well as Beyond Good & Evil.

Headquartered in London, England, ZeniMax Europe Ltd is a wholly owned subsidiary of ZeniMax Media Inc. The company publishes the games by Bethesda Softworks LLC throughout UK/EMEA territories. The establishment was announced in February 2008.

Absolute Quality, Inc. has been a leading outsource company in the area of multimedia software testing and technical support since its founding in 1996 by Stephen Muirhead, former President of MicroProse Software Inc. In addition to Muirhead, the AQ original team consisted of previous employees of MicroProse's Quality Assurance Department and was headquartered in the same city in Maryland (USA), Hunt Valley. AQ quickly became the preferred outsource solution of major developers and publishers including Hasbro Interactive, Virgin Interactive, and Broderbund and offer testing and technical support to clients all under the one roof. By 2004, the company reported having over 300 employees worldwide providing software testing, localization and technical support solutions to companies around the world in ten languages. In 2004, Absolute Quality's divisions and locations were: * Hunt Valley, Maryland USA (main headquarters) * Alameda, California USA (west coast division) * Absolute Quality (Europe) Ltd., Glasgow, Scotland - European headquarters & testing division (opened in 1999) * Munich, Germany - European localization and voice-over division (opened May 2004) On June 22, 2004, AQ was acquired by e4e, Inc. and merged with its Vinciti Networks subsidiaries. The Absolute Quality name was still used publicly, while official name was changed to Vinciti AQ Inc. This added two more locations: Phoenix, Arizona (USA) and Bangalore, India. Original founder Stephen Muirhead became President of Vinciti AQ. As of December 7, 2009, the Absolute Quality name was totally phased out. The new name is e4e Interactive Entertainment Services. Bhaskar Menon is e4e’s CEO & President, based in e4e’s Headquarters in Santa Clara, California. On 22nd August 2012 the Interactive Entertainment division was acquired by Pole To Win Co., Ltd.

CyberConnect 2 Co., Ltd is a Japanese video game developer. The company was founded in 1996 in Fukuoka. A studio in Tokyo was subsequently opened in 2010, followed by a Canadian subsidiary in 2016. The studio is known for the .hack RPG series. They were also involved in the Final Fantasy VII Remake project until 2017 when they left the project

The company was founded in Germany in 2001 as Triggerlab GmbH. Previously, the management team had already been involved with games since 1997 at Artex Software, developing games for the Acorn RiscPC platform such as Exodus: The Colonisation of Space. The company's first release was Stealth Combat (2002), a tactical shooter. In April 2002 the company changed its name to Deck13 Interactive GmbH and started focusing entirely on point-and-click adventure games. They continued the Ankh franchise, established in 1998 with the release of Ankh: The Tales of Mystery on Acorn RiscPC by the Artex Software team. After the release of the Ankh, the 2005 sequel, two more stand-alone episodes were developed: Ankh: Heart of Osiris (2006) and Ankh: Battle of the Gods (2007). In between they also released an entirely different adventure: Jack Keane (2007). The company still uses the name Artex Software as a brand for a line of budget publishing.

Five-BN was founded in 2002 by Evgeny Sokolov, a graduate of Dneprodzerzhinsk State Technical University. The company's first game was a simulator called Billard which was published by Maus Software. In the autumn of 2008, Five-BN became Alawar Five-BN, an internal studio of Alawar Entertainment.

Grey Alien Games is, primarily, a one-man operation run by Jake Birkett. He is helped by his wife, Helen Carmichael and his sons Callum and Conan Birkett. He primarily creates games for Windows, Macintosh and mobile (iOS and Android).

Formed from the roots of Logotron, the London-based Millennium were best known for the James Pond series, but released a range of games, particularly for Amiga and ST systems. Their titles were generally distributed by U.S. Gold. In 1997 the company was bought by Sony and became SCE Studio Cambridge. In 2009 it is part of the SCE Worldwide Studios group and is named simply Cambridge Studio. In 2012 the studios became part of Guerrilla B.V. and its name was changed to Guerrilla Cambridge. On January 12, 2017, Sony Interactive Entertainment closed Guerrilla Cambridge.

Home Entertainment Suppliers is an Australian company that distributes computer games and gaming equipment. Founded by Sebastian Giompaolo in 1984, the HES offices are based in Punchbowl, Sydney. The company started by distributing games for the Commodore 64, but peripherals as well, such as generic auto fire controllers, Game Boy power adapters, Master System converters for the Mega Drive and adapters for NES games such as the HES Unidaptor and HES Unidaptor MKII. They were also known for distributing unlicensed NES games at budget prices, on EPROMs. Nowadays, the company still distributes peripherals and games in Australia for modern consoles, by publishers ZOO Digital Publishing, Tru Blu Entertainment and Phantagram. Source: official homepage and Wikipedia.

Incredible Technologies is a US studio founded in July 1985 by Elaine Hodgson and Richard Ditton who previously worked at Action Graphics, Inc., a studio spun off from Bally Midway Manufacturing Co., Inc.. It was initially started out as Free Radical Software, Inc., developing Championship Wrestling for Epyx and responsible for the Atari ST and Amiga conversions of Winter Games. The company initially specialized in designing and manufacturing commercial/arcade entertainment development and they are best known for the Golden Tee Golf arcade series. Incredible Technologies developed Grave Yardage for Activision. in 1989. The staff's biographies in that game's manual show the range of design and development IT has done: arcade game design and Bally/Midway and Capcom; development of original games and/or conversion for Cinemaware, Epyx, Mindscape; pinball machine development for Data East; system design for Brunswick's BowlerVision system. While still creating games, the company also started releasing casino games and machines in 2008.
Massive Black Inc. is a company based in San Francisco that provides illustrations, concept art, 3D assets and animation for game projects.

Starting out as a spin-off from Universal Co., Ltd., Aruze is now a major player in the Japanese leisure machine business, specialising in pachislot machines. Part of the Aruze sphere are also companies such as SETA (including its contents division Ikusabune), Nautilus and CyberFront.

Founded in 1983, and headed by Tetsuo Akiyama, Visco Corporation (株式会社ビスコ) was involved in the planning, development and sale of games for both consoles and the arcade. After the release of 2001's Vasara 2, the company would leave the video game market to focus on the development of prize and slot machines.

Arc Games is a game publishing company founded in 2008 in Redwood Shores, California. It was originally called Perfect World Entertainment and was a subsidiary of Perfect World Beijing. During Perfect World's ownership, the company mainly focused on publishing English-language international versions of the Asian online free-to-play games developed by Perfect World Beijing, but also distributed a few other games for other developers electronically as well as in retail packaging. In 2022, the company was acquired by Gearbox Software and renamed to Gearbox Publishing San Francisco. Under Gearbox, it was the second office under the Gearbox Publishing label. When Gearbox Software was sold to Take-Two Interactive on 28 March 2024, the San Francisco publishing company, with its belonging IPs and subsidiaries, remained with Embracer Group. It was renamed to Arc Games Inc. on 8 March 2024, after their existing Arc brand used for their game launcher.

Centauri Production is a Czech (located in Prague area) software house which focuses mainly on computer games (most prominently on adventures, although they also have action games) but has also some experience with iOS (Father Frost, 2011). The company is also active in the production of multimedia applications and presentations, the software for film and animation studios, and of web pages and interfaces. Centauri Production is a member of IDEA Games. September 30, 2010 Centauri Production was acquired by fellow IDEA Games member Bohemia Interactive. Officially established in 2000, the team had already been working together between 1994 and 1999, created games in their spare time such as Hot Summer 2, Dung-beetles and The Knights of the Grail. Later, almost the entire graphics department of Bohemia Interactive Studio joined the company after completing Fairy Tale About Father Frost. The next years, the studio worked on various titles such as Domestic Violence (2003), various titles featuring Ferdy the Ant, 4 Leaf Clovers (2001) and The Fifth Disciple (2002 - assisting Napoleon Games). Later came games like Gooka: The Mystery of Janatris, released in June 2004, Evil Days of Luckless John (2006), Memento Mori (2008), Pat & Mat (2010), Alternativa (2010) and Pound of Ground (2010). Last released game is adventure Memento Mori 2, which came out in Germany in June 2012. English version's status is unknown, as game's publisher dtp Entertainment has financial difficulties.
GIANTS Software is a game development studio founded in 2004 and based in Zurich, Switzerland. The company is known for its Farming Simulator series.

Humble Games is a publishing label of Humble Bundle, Inc. It was launched on 14th May 2020. Previously Humble already published some titles under its Humble Bundle name, so it seems largely a rebranding to separate Humble Bundle from Humble Games.

Kasedo Games (official pronounciation: Kass-ee-doh) is a publishing label of Kalypso Media founded in 2014, and is attached to indie games published by the company. It was originally operated from the Bracknell office, but was later (by 2018) moved to the Leicester office (which would share the name with the label as of 3 December 2019).

Nicalis is a game development/publishing company founded in late 2007 by Tyrone Rodriguez, a former editor for IGN and a former publicist for Nintendo. The company is responsible for the WiiWare ports of the indie games La•Mulana (in development) and Cave Story. In January 2011 an entirely new game was released by Nicalis: NightSky (Windows), designed by Nicklas Nygren.

Backbone Charlottetown Ltd. was founded as one of the three development studios of Backbone Entertainment in March 2006. When co-founder Andrew Ayre left Foundation 9 Entertainment on 25th May 2007, he spun off the studio Backbone Charlottetown Ltd. into the independent company Other Ocean Group Inc. It is a Canadian-owned and controlled company, based in California. The development studio of the group is called Other Ocean Interactive Ltd.. A second studio, based in St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador, was announced on 9th September 2008. On 13th December 2007 the company had also opened the QA testing facility Sculpin QA. Both are based in Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island. In July 2008 the establishment of P.E.I. studio was announced, a specialized Apple iPhone development division. Other Ocean team's first released title (still as Backbone Charlottetown) was the Xbox 360 XBLA adaptation Castlevania: Symphony of the Night (2007). It earned the studio two of 10 Xbox LIVE Awards from Microsoft at the 2008 Game Developers Conference in San Francisco; Best Classic Game, and Highest Rated Game. The studio's second achievement was the release of Ultimate Mortal Kombat (2007) on the Nintendo DS. Soon to follow were the releases of two well-known games from the classic franchises, Tron (2008) and Discs of Tron (2008), both for the Xbox 360 XBLA service. After the establishment of an iPhone development division Super Monkey Ball (2008), their first title for the platform, was released. It sold 300,000 copies in the first twenty days after the release. The team's next release was the Windows hidden object game Enchanted Fairy Friends: Secret of the Fairy Queen (August 2008) for ValuSoft, Inc. In September 2008 two more games were released; their first Wii title Ten Pin Alley 2 and their second iPhone game Diner Dash. Upcoming titles are Story Hour: Adventures and Story Hour: Fairy Tales, both for the Wii, an Atlantic Canadian-inspired game Puffins: Island Adventure (DS) and several other games that have not yet been announced.
PM Studios, Inc. is a game publisher established in 2008.

Player Research is a games user research partner. They enable gamedev to gain meaningful insight from real players across the world. Founded in 2012, they have contributed to games of all genres, platforms, and audiences, leveraging their expertise in player experience and research methodology toward the development of truly successful games. Player Research conduct usability testing and other insight-generating research during the pre-production, production and post-launch stages of game development.

Chinese branch of Nintendo, founded in 2002, iQue has distributed Nintendo 64 (as iQue Player) and Nintendo Game Boy Advance (as iQue GBA), Nintendo DS (as iQue DS), Nintendo DSi (as iQue DSi) and Nintendo 3DS XL (as iQue 3DS XL) to Mainland China, the company also localized (and still doing today) Nintendo games to Simplified Chinese and Traditional Chinese. (Though some of Traditional Chinese games were localized by Nintendo Hong Kong branch) Since 2013, the company became a wholly-owned subsidiary of Nintendo.

3D Brigade was an art and asset outsourcing studio. It provided developers with concept art, 3D models and cinematics (including motion capturing). It was established in 2002 in Budapest, Hungary as 3D Brigade Hungary Inc. The company relocated to Dublin, Ireland and was incorporated on 9th May 2016 as 3D Brigade Arthouse Ltd. The company closed its doors on 10th June 2020.

GarageGames is a unique Internet publishing label for independent games and gamemakers. We are a band of professional gamemakers committed to publishing truly original and exciting titles on our own terms. We want to give any and all gamemakers the opportunity to publish their games, find their audiences - and perhaps make their fortunes. Garage Games self proclaimed mission is, "To provide independent developers with tools, knowledge, co-conspirators - whatever YOU need - to make great games."
Green Man Gaming Publishing is the publishing label of Green Man Gaming Limited.

TamTam Co., Ltd. (株式会社タムタム) was a game development studio based in Shinjuku, Tokyo, Japan. The company was established in June 1991 by programmer Atsushi Kanao, who had previously worked at Elf, FairyTale, and Enix. The company entered bankruptcy proceedings in November 2017.

Terminal Reality, Inc. was a development and production company based in Texas (USA), founded in October 1994 by Mark Randel and Brett Combs. Randel previously worked at The Bruce Artwick Organization Ltd. on Flight Simulator games. Combs was formerly the general manager of Mallard Software. The company went out of business in 11 December 2013.

Ubisoft Reflections Ltd. (formerly known as Reflections Interactive) is a game development studio based in Newcastle, UK. It was founded in 1984 by Martin Edmondson. The company's first released game was Ravenskull (1986). Among their best-known game series are Shadow of the Beast, Destruction Derby, and Driver.  In 1998, the company was acquired by GT Interactive. On 13 July 2006, the studio was acquired by Ubisoft.

1st Playable Productions, LLC is an independent game development studio located in Troy, New York, and founded by CEO Tobi Saulnier. The company's main focus is on handheld games for kids. Their goal is "to make games that build, not exploit, the entertainment brands that they represent." The company is a licensed developer for Nintendo Game Boy Advance, Nintendo DS, Microsoft Xbox, as well as other embedded game platforms.

Ascaron was a computer game company headquartered in Gütersloh, Germany. The company was founded in 1991 under the name Ascon by Holger Flöttmann and developed entertainment software for the German market for 18 years, with games franchises like Patrician, Port Royale, Anstoss (On the Ball) and Sacred. Later it also became known for its publishing and distribution activities. In August 2001, the company went into administration for the first time. However, the reestablishment of the company keeping all IPRs and brands made it possible for Ascaron to continue its operative business and to survive.  In July 2002, Ascaron expanded by opening a wholly-owned subsidiary, Studio II Software in the University City, Aachen (Germany) and in September 2002, the first international office, Ascaron Entertainment (UK) Ltd. with its main office in Birmingham, was founded. After many years of continuity the company got into financial difficulties once more. According to a spokesman of Ascaron this was due to immense costs and extended time for the development of Sacred 2: Fallen Angel. On 14 April 2009, Ascaron Entertainment went into administration again. This time, the company did not recover and negotiations began with "several well-known interested parties" to discuss a positive takeover.  In June 2009, Kalypso Media acquired the majority of licenses and assets of company when the firm entered insolvency. Among the intellectual properties acquired were Port Royale, Darkstar One, Anstoss (On the Ball) and Patrician. However, certain titles distributed online by Strategy First since 2008 would remain with the latter. On 18 June 2009, it was announced that fifteen former employees of Ascaron would be part of Kalypso's newly acquired studio Gaming Minds Studios. The Sacred intellectual property would be fully acquired by its European publisher, Koch Media, following the release of the last ASCARON-branded title, Sacred 2: Ice & Blood in August 2009.

Revo Solutions (also known as Revo Studios) is a Romanian company which began in 2005 as a Quality Assurance testing company. The company's game development team was created in 2008 and five games for the iPhone were finished the first year.
Blind Squirrel Games is a game development studio based in Costa Mesa, California (USA). It was established in 2010 and is led by CEO Brad Hendricks.

Climax Studios Ltd. is the last remaining development studio of the Climax Group, based in Portsmouth, United Kingdom. The current name was introduced around 2009-2010. Before that, the division was known as Climax Action, a virtual re-branding of the Climax London, Climax Solent and Climax Handheld Games divisions, all under a single name to make it less confusing for publishers. All the locations and people remained the same and it is led by President Simon Gardner, based at the Portsmouth Climax Solent location. By February 2008, it became the sole development division of the group. As Climax Action, the studio made the Nintendo DS game Nicktoons Unite! in 2006. As Climax Studios the team was responsible for Silent Hill: Shattered Memories (2009), Overlord: Dark Legend (2009), Overlord Minions (2009), Rocket Knight (2010) and Gormiti: The Lords of Nature! (2010).  In 2011, the studio released the PlayStation Move game Eyepet & Friends. In 2012, the team released the XBLA game Bloodforge and Smart As, a PS Vita braintraining game under the banner of Sony (XDEV Studio Europe). On 22 April 2021, the company was acquired by Keywords Studios for £43 million. By 2024, the company had studios in 4 locations: Portsmouth, London, Edinburgh and Liverpool.

Coatsink is a game development studio established in December 2009 by Tom Beardsmore and Paul Crabb, and is headquartered in Sunderland, UK. On 5 October 2020, Thunderful Group AB announced the acquisition of the studio.

Eko Software SARL (also known as Eko System) is a French company that was founded in 1999 as an internal development studio of Cryo. One of the co-founders is Jérôme Durand. The studio's first title was Gift released in 2000. After Cryo's demise in 2002, the studio went on by itself. The company creates games, proprietary technologies and tools for the Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo DS and Wii consoles, as well as for the Sony PSP, PlayStation 2 and PlayStation 3.

La Marque Rose SARL was a French studio involved with voice recording. Following the acquisition by Keywords Studios on 4th August 2017 it was merged into Keywords Studios France SAS on 4th October 2018.

Magic Pockets is a development studio based in Paris, France. The team is comprised of people who have been developing on Nintendo handheld systems since 1994, beginning with the Game Boy Advance and, more recently, the Nintendo DS system. The company also developed and markets its own Magic Pockets DS Engine. Magic Pockets' mother company was PAM Development. Sometime in early 2005 or 2006 PAM Development was acquired by Take-Two Interactive and with it went Magic Pockets, which was a Take 2 subsidiary from July 2005 until January of 2007. The company has since broken away from Take-Two and is an independent studio.
Marvel Characters, Inc. is a subsidiary of Marvel Entertainment, LLC. It seems to hold the general non-movie rights to all Marvel Characters.
Matrix Software (社マトリックス) was established in July 1994 by former Climax and  Telenet Japan members.

Nintendo EPD (Nintendo Entertainment Planning & Development) is an internal development division of Nintendo. It was created in September 2015 when Nintendo EAD and Nintendo SPD were merged as part of a corporate restructuring.
Established in 1995 under the name Racdym, Racjin Co., Ltd. is based in Osaka, Japan. The company changed its corporate moniker from Racdym to the more Japanese-pronunciation-friendly Racjin in 2000.

Raven Software is a computer game developer based in Madison, Wisconsin. The company was founded in 1990 by brothers Brian and Steve Raffel, and initially had a staff of five people. Their first game was Black Crypt (1992). Later, they shifted their focus from first-person RPGs to first-person shooters, a genre in which they created their best-known works such as Heretic and Hexen, Soldier of Fortune and other series, primarily in engines made by id Software or their derivatives.  In 1997, Raven Software made an exclusive publishing deal with Activision and was eventually acquired by that company.  During the time they shared a published with id Software in Activision, the two companies would closely collaborate, and Raven would even lead the development of Quake 4 and Wolfenstein (2009) instead of id Software. Additionally, Raven Software would develop several games making use of Activision's Marvel license in the mid-to-late-2000s. After id Software was acquired by ZeniMax Media in 2009, Raven Software would no longer use id Tech engines. Their last standalone title was Singularity from 2010, which used Unreal Engine 3. After this, Raven Software would assist in development and support of the Call of Duty franchise, starting with Call of Duty: Black Ops in 2011.

Vancouver, Canada-based Relic Entertainment develops electronic entertainment. It was founded in May 1997 by Alex Garden, Luke Moloney, Erin Daly, Aaron Kambeitz, Rob Cunningham, Gary Shaw, and Shane Alfreds. Operations began in a modest 1600 sq. foot office upstairs from a popular nightclub. In April of 1998, Relic made the move to its new 12,000 sq. foot world class facility in Vancouver's historic Yaletown district. The studio’s first title was the space strategy game Homeworld (1999). Publisher Sierra Entertainment continued the franchise in 2000 with Homeworld: Cataclysm, but by a different development studio. Their next title Impossible Creatures arrived four years later in 2003, a real-time strategy game for Microsoft Game Studios where the units were animals that could have their genes modified to inherit different traits. It was received fairly well, but received less attention than their first title. Shortly after, a sequel to Homeworld was released as Homeworld 2, also in 2003. Reviews were generally positive, but it made less of an impact than the first game. In April 2004 the studio was acquired by the publishing house THQ for close to $10 million in an all-cash transaction. The acquisition was completed in May. Later that year, the studio released the fantasy strategy title Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War based on the tabletop Warhammer 40,000 universe. Over the years, the studio released multiple expansions: Winter Assault (2005), Dark Crusade (2006) and Soulstorm (2008). The last expansion was done by Iron Lore Entertainment, but received post-release support from Relic due to Iron Lore's closure weeks before it shipped. Previously only creating games for computers, the studio’s first and only console title was The Outfit (2006), a shooter set during World War II that was received fairly well, but less than their other titles. Much more successful was the launch of the Company of Heroes franchise, started with Company of Heroes in 2006 and followed up with the Opposing Fronts and Company of Heroes: Tales of Valor expansions in 2007 and 2009 respectively. Again set during World War II, they featured squad-based strategy gameplay. There were also rumours that Relic was looking to reacquire the Homeworld franchise from publisher Vivendi to create a third game in their sci-fi series. Through the discovery of a document at the trademark office, THQ eventually confirmed that Relic owned the trademark once again, making it possible to create a new title for THQ. However, the IP was eventually bought by Gearbox Software in 2013 and the next game in the Homeworld series, Deserts of Kharak was developed by Blackbird Interactive. In February 2009, the Dawn of War sequel Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II was released. In September 2011, they would ship the third-person shooter Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine. Following the closure of parent company THQ in January 2013, the studio was sold to SEGA. As part of the acquisition, SEGA also brought their IPs Company of Heroes and Dawn of War from THQ. Soon afterwards, Company of Heroes 2 was released. After the unsuccessful Dawn of War III, Relic Entertainment was contracted by Microsoft Studios to develop Age of Empires IV and contribute to the codebases of the earlier Age of Empires titles' Definitive Editions. The former was released in October 2021. In their returning title to the SEGA-owned part of their portfolio, Relic Entertainment announced Company of Heroes 3 in July 2021, with a short open pre-alpha playtest session soon after announcement. The full version of the game was released in February 2023. On 28 March 2024, the company became independent from SEGA. Between February and June 2025, Relic's titles published under SEGA would become self-published and would no longer use SEGA's community forum system. On 4 September 2025, the company revealed the Relic Labs label, meant for games that have smaller teams and shorter development cycles, starting with Earth vs Mars.

This Telenet Japan subsidiary was founded in 1987, and initially headed by Masahiro Akishino. It went independent for 2 years, then got folded back in. It is known for its work with Japanese PCs, the Sega Mega Drive (Genesis), and the Super Famicom (SNES). They developed Zan, Arcus, and Hiōden games. In 1993, it was restructured, as part of a Telenet Japan initiative to reduce costs. Some staff resisted the change, including Wolf Team head, Masahiro Akishino, producer  Masaaki Uno  (went to  Camelot Software), Sega Genesis programmers  Toshio Toyota  and  Yukihiko Tani  (aka bugtaro) (both co-founded Gau Entertainment ). Wolf Team producer Joe Asanuma took the helm at this time. Due to the poor sales of their games, they needed to seek an outside financier to publish and market their next game, based on the novel Tale Phantasia, written by Yoshiharu Gotanda. After seeing bids from some companies, such as Enix and Namco, they signed on with the agreement made by Namco. Namco made many marketing changes to the game, which struck a protest from Yoshiharu Gotanda, and Masaki Norimoto. Many people on the team supported them, and these protests saw Joe Asanuma get ousted for his lack of ability to solve these protests, so they brought in Eiji Kikuchi  to direct the game. This brought up the idea for the protesters to start up their own company. After Tales of Phantasia was released, most of the development staff left Wolf Team. Most of this development staff went to participate in the founding of Tri-Ace. Only Motoi Sakuraba, Shinji Tamura and Eiji Kikuchi remained with Wolf Team after this breakup. Wolf Team kept developing the Tales games for Namco, and did some sports games on the side for Telenet Japan. In 2003, the remains of Wolf Team were dissolved, and the remaining staff were transferred into a new subsidiary known as Namco Tales Studio, and develops the series for its financier and publisher, Namco.

Created in 2003, Artefacts Studio has done subcontracting work on titles such as Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Double Agent, Dark Messiah of Might & Magic and Test Drive Unlimited. As an outsourcing subcontractor Artefacts Studio also worked on Rayman Raving Rabbids for Ubisoft. On September 2006, Artefacts Studio became an official Nintendo DS developer.

Creatures, Inc. is a subsidiary of Nintendo founded on November 8th, 1995 by Tsunekazu Ishihara as a successor to Shigesato Itoi's company Ape. The company focuses on developing Pokémon games. It is the producer of the Pokémon card game, and owns one-third of the copyright over the franchise (together with Nintendo and Game Freak).

Denda is an independent publisher of games and software located in the Netherlands. The company was established in the late 1990s (either Nov. 1996 or 1998) by Jacques Neuvel who, in 2009, still retains ownership and manages the company. The company name was Denda Multimedia BV from 1998 until 2003 and then was changed to Denda Publishers B.V. sometime between 2003 and 2006.  The company publishes and distributes its localized products to the Benelux market in retail package form as well as casual games by electronic download. In 2009 Denda reported having more than 50 casual games available for download from the company's website.

Double Fine Productions was founded in July 2000, in an old clog shop in San Francisco, California, USA. The founder, Tim Schafer, created for his previous company (LucasArts) such games as Grim Fandango, Full Throttle, and (half of) Day of the Tentacle. He started Double Fine with a large part of the Grim Fandango team, as well as new hires.  After releasing their first game Psychonauts in 2005, they moved into different offices. The studio would, like its founding developers, be best known for adventure games. In 2014, they launched the Double Fine Presents label for publishing projects by external indie developers. On 9 June 2019, the company was acquired by Microsoft and placed in its Xbox Game Studios label. The Double Fine Presents label would be wound down by mid-2020.

Kogado (工画堂) is a Japanese company based in Tokyo. It was founded in 1916 and specialized in design and printing. The company went into public trading in August 1960. Kogado has been developing video games since 1982. They are mostly known for their strategy games, such as the Schwarzschild series, as well as visual novels. Their games publishing label used to be KGD Software Products / Kogado Software Products.

M.C. Lothorien Ltd was founded in 1982. Commonly known as Lothorien, they were a developer and publisher of videogames based in the United Kingdom. Their head office was in Stockport, Cheshire. Lothlorien made games for several 8-bit platforms including the ZX Spectrum, Dragon 32 and BBC Micro. In their early years they were known for making wargames. The company was founded by Mike Cohen and Roger Lees who had both created games in that genre as a hobby and sold them privately. Cohen was the Managing Director and Lees was in charge of marketing. The company was joined in 1983 by Geoff Street who was their Technical Director. Street had previously been a programmer working for a bank. At first their games were only available by mail order but they later were sold in stores. Later games included arcade action titles and adventures.

Founded in 1982, earlier than most other videogame start-ups of that time, Rabbit started as an offshoot of Cream Computers, a shop in Harrow (North London) that specialised in business micros. One of the employees wrote software and they decided to sell some games by mail. The games had very basic packaging: cream coloured paper with a rabbit stamped on it and hand-written details. Along with the buzz of the Vic-20 release, the company became quickly known for their Vic-20 and Commodore 64 games. The company hired a tele-sales team and made sure their games were available from different major computer outlets; a risk at the time. They started producing games for the Spectrum at the end of 1983 and soon had the titles Escape MCP, Race Fun, Phantasia, The Birds, Frogger, Lancer Lords, Murder, Pakacuda, Paratroopers, Potty Painter, Centropods and Quackers. In 1984, the company moved to Wealdstone and they no longer had in-house programmers. Producer/Director Terry Grant thought up the ideas and then contracted programmers. In that year, they released the Spectrum game Death Star. Because software producers had difficulty maintaining stocks for chain stores, Terry Grant and Heather Lamont founded Copy-Soft to offer a full scale service to all software houses, including inlay design and printing, right through to bulk copying and delivery. By 1985 Virgin Games acquired the Rabbit Software name and used it as a publishing label to sell mid-priced titles on a range of machines, including the Spectrum. The first game released on this new label was The Great Fire of London.

2K Valencia, originally known as Elite3D and the trading name Platygobian, S.L, was founded in 2004 in Valencia, Spain by José Luis Queral Herrero and Oscar Ferrero Lopez. They met in 2000 while working in London and in 2004 they built up Elite3D. Since then, they had been helping various studios. Among their collaborations are Electronic Arts, Crytek, Cloud Imperium and Milestone. On 9 November 2021, they were acquired by 2K Games and placed as the second studio under the 31st Union umbrella.

Altagram is an independent video game localization, voice-over and QA group based in Berlin, Seoul and Montreal. They have localized over 5,000 games, from casual indie games to major AAA titles, in over 50 languages. When it is not clear which specific studio worked on a project, this umbrella company entry is used.

Bohemia Interactive is an independent game development studio that focuses on developing state of the art computer entertainment software and the research of advanced real time 3D graphics, artificial intelligence and physical simulation technologies for real-time interactive environments.  In 2001, Bohemia Interactive finished the development of Operation Flashpoint. The debut game of Bohemia Interactive, published by Codemasters, immediately became the No. 1 selling game in the United Kingdom, Germany, France, Australia, Czech Republic and other countries. The development team continued to support the game with regularly released upgrades and patches over the internet and prepared a special US version of the game. It launched in September 2001 and it also became one of the best selling games in the US. Operation Flashpoint has won many accolades including Game of The Year and Best Action Game. Over 1.2 million copies of Operation Flashpoint have been sold since its release. In December 2001, Bohemia Interactive opened a studio in Australia and started the development of special military training simulation program VBS1 in cooperation with U.S. based Coalescent Technologies. VBS1 is already being used as a training tool by the U. S. Marine Corps. and various other military organizations are looking into possible implementation of VBS1 into their training programs. Bohemia Interactive's research and development team has more than 25 experienced game developers. It’s based in Prague, Czech Republic with development studios in the Czech Republic as well as Australia. Bohemia Interactive Studio has won Best PC Game Developer of the year 2001 award at London’s exhibit ECTS and Rookie Studio of the Year award at GDC 2002. On 28th March 2014 the acquisition of the Slovakian development studio Cauldron Ltd. was announced. It was renamed Bohemia Interactive Slovakia.

CCP Games, a privately held company, concentrates on MMOGs. CCP creates, develops, publishes and distributes its games. The company is headquartered in Reykjavík, Iceland. In November 2006, the company merged with White Wolf Games, known for various tabletop RPG franchises. Both companies continue under their respective names, but the wholly-owned subsidiary White Wolf is now headed by CCP CEO Hilmar Petursson. White Wolf now created physical products for CCP's MMOG EVE Online, such as strategy guides, enhanced collectable card games, role-playing systems, and novels. In October 2007 the company expanded its operations with the establishment of CCP North America, a North American headquarters located in in Stone Mountain, GA.

Founded in 2009 by Lee Hutchinson and Matt Shepcar, Double Eleven is a games developer and publisher based in Middlesbrough in the North East of England.  As of 2022 they have 300 employees and their main body of work consists of porting, adapting and expanding existing games or franchises.

Eidos Montréal was originally a development studio of Eidos Interactive. It was formed in Canada in February 2007. In addition to development, the studio also performed Quality Assurance testing for all of the Eidos' divisions worldwide. The first title developed at the studio was Deus Ex: Human Revolution, which was released in August 2011. Since then, the studio has developed games primarily in the Deus Ex, Thief, and Tomb Raider franchises. On 2 May 2022, Embracer Group AB entered into an agreement to acquire the studio along with Crystal Dynamics and Square Enix Montréal from Square Enix. The acquisition was completed on 22 August 2022. From then on, the three studios form Embracer's 12th operative group under the leadership of Phil Rogers and his management teams. The operative group is interchangeably referred to as "Crystal Dynamics/Eidos Montréal" and "CDE Entertainment", while select games would have Eidos Montréal as the assigned publisher on digital stores in January 2023. With the move of its sister studio Eidos Shanghai to the Gearbox operating group within Embracer and the silent closure of Eidos Sherbrooke in January 2023, Eidos Montréal is the final remaining company bearing the Eidos name as of 2023.

Gamelion Inc. is a company founded in Finland in 2002 by Anton Gauffin and they develop and port games for mobile and handheld devices, and consoles. It has two development studios in Poland. The first one is located in Szczecin and the second one, in Bydgoszcz, was established in 2007. In February 2009 the company employed around 100 employees. In August 2007 the company announced a merger with BLStream. The deal was finalized in June 2008. Gamelion is now part of BLStream but retained its brand name. It is also still led by founder Gauffin.

Illusion Software was founded in Yokohama, Japan. The company specializes in developing adult  hentai video games. Unlike other hentai games, many of the games developed by Illusion Software feature 3D models (instead of pre-rendered images), 3D animations, and precise customization and interaction possibilities.
One of the leading Russian developers and content aggregators of games for mobile phones.

ExeQuo was founded in September 1998. Thanks to the confidence and loyalty of its clients, ExeQuo's business has grown over 25% a year to establish the company as a respected partner in video game localization. ExeQuo maintains an extensive network of established partners in Germany, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Netherlands, Scandinavia and is currently building a team in Japan. Thanks to such synergy, ExeQuo delivers quality products, on time and in more than 10 languages. ExeQuo's short and medium term objectives are:  to build on its successful collaboration with numerous game editors, and confirm its leadership in multi-lingual video game localization; to develop its audio and video design activities among its current and future clients so as to build a reputation as a valuable partner in their game promotion strategy; to penetrate the Japanese market and reinforce the company's European structure.  [Source: www.exequo.com]
LuckyDolphin Lda. (d/b/a Locsmiths) is a Portuguese company specialising in English-to-Portuguese localizations for video games.

Mindscape B.V. is a Dutch publishing company, originally a publishing and distribution arm of Mindscape SA (covering Benelux and Scandinavian markets). After the liquidation of its parent company in August 2011, Mindscape B.V. took over the operations of the brand.

Psyonix, Inc. is an expert Unreal Engine development team located in southern California. The company moved across the country from its original location in Raleigh, North Carolina, to San Diego, California, in December 2009. Over the past 10 years, Psyonix has contributed to more than a dozen Unreal Engine based games including later installments of the Unreal Tournament series, Gears of War, and its own independently developed title, Supersonic Acrobatic Rocket-Powered Battle-Cars. Psyonix has built its success on applying Unreal technology to games on all platforms. Their arguably most successful game, Rocket League, was released in 2015 and gathered a large e-sports following. On 1 May 2019, the company announced to have been acquired by Epic Games, Inc., with the closure of the acquisition expected in late May or early June of that year.

Sproing Interactive Media GmbH was a PC and console games development company based in Vienna, Austria. It was founded in 2001 by Harald Riegler and Gerhard Seiler. Sproing developed games for platforms such as PS2, PSX, Xbox, GameCube, Nintendo DS, GBA, PC, handheld and web. Their services included:  Game development for all major platforms (contracted or original) Game porting (PC to Console or vice versa) Audio Services for the gaming industry (soundtracks, sound Design) Advertising games (web or CD-ROM based) Gambling and ITV applications  The company filed for insolvency in 2016 and closed down in 2017. In 2018 several former employees founded Purple Lamp Game Development GmbH and acquired the rights for the Sproing brand and certain games previously made by them.

BlueSky Software or BlueSky Software Corporation was an American software company situated in California formed in 1988 and had a successful run for 12 years before closing down in March of 2001, when parent company Interplay was in financial trouble. The BlueSky trademark was still owned by Titus Interactive until bankruptcy closed their doors in 2004.

Budge Studios is a game development and publishing studio based in Montreal, Canada. It was established in 2010 by David Lipes, Noémie Dupuy and Michael Elman.  The three founders previously established Wave Generation, providing audio production for major video game studios. When the iPad came to the market in 2010 and the App Store began to emerge, they saw an opportunity to make their own games. The studio focuses on children's entertainment and started making apps for The Walt Disney Company as well as based on well-known properties such as Dora the Explorer and SpongeBob SquarePants. In 2012 they switched their business model from being a provider of apps to a full-fledges publisher, acquiring the licensing rights to franchises such as Caillou, Chuggington, Strawberry Shortcake and Garfield. In 2014 the founders were awarded the Ernst and Young Emerging Entrepreneur Award for Quebec.

column1: Centre National du Cinéma et de l'image Animée

column2: MPath Interactive was a company which developed and licensed the MPlayer.com online multiplayer service for video games between 1997 and 2001, when it was bought by GameSpy Industries and absorbed into its GameSpy Arcade service.

Paon Corporation, Ltd., founded on 20th January 1999 in Japan, was a Japanese video game developer. Aside from working on a number of titles, they also bought the rights of some of Data East Corporation's games when the company went bankrupt, and gradually released them through the Wii's virtual console service. In March 2015 the company was merged into DP Inc. which was then renamed Paon DP Inc. A large amount of developers who were previously with Paon ended up at Picola Inc., which was formed at the same time (February 2015) as the Paon merger.

Radical Entertainment was a game development studio located in Vancouver, British Columbia (Canada) and founded in 1991. Radical worked on titles such as Scarface: The World is Yours (the 8th title from Radical that has sold over 1 million units and the 4th title to ship over 2 million units), Crash Tag Team Racing, The Incredible Hulk: Ultimate Destruction and The Simpsons: Hit & Run. They continued to work on licensed properties, but later switched to original IP and developed the Prototype games. In the early 2000s, the company also owned a division called 369 Interactive. In 2007, Radical was selected as one of Canada’s Top 100 Employers and one of British Columbia’s Top 30 Employers. In June 2012, parent company Activision Blizzard announced that all original development at the studio would cease, with some staff remaining to work on existing Activision projects. One cause of the closure, according to a statement by Activision, was the failure of Radical's Prototype IP to 'find a broad commercial audience'. The name Radical remained for team members contributing to Activision projects. In Destiny (2014), for instance, a group of programmers, designers and artists is credited as 'Activision: Radical'.

Rage Games Ltd. was an English game development studio founded as Rage Software Ltd. by Paul Finnegan in 1992. Originally creating games for third party developers, the first commercial success came with the football game Striker in 1992. The company was acquired B.C.E. Holdings plc in December 1994. It later changed its name to Rage Software plc and eventually Rage plc. This overview is about the English development studio, part of the larger holdings group. Because of the name change of the holding company, Rage Software Ltd.'s name was changed to Rage Games Ltd. in 1996. In the late nineties the company extracted itself from the merger. After setting up a sister company Swordfish Studios in September 2002, which then acquired Rage for one pound, the studio went into liquidation in January 2003 following the withdrawal of its manufacturing credit facility by its bankers. Members of the former Rage team are now still active at Venom Games, Juice Games, Swordfish Studios, and Moonpod.

Rockstar North, formerly known as DMA Design, was founded in 1988 by David Jones, Russell Kay, and Mike Dailly in Dundee, Scotland. The name DMA was taken from the Amiga programming manuals, where it stood for "Direct Memory Access". DMA Design was most known for developing Lemmings and early Grand Theft Auto games. In December 1996, the company was acquired by Gremlin Interactive. In September 1999, it was sold to Take-Two Interactive and continued developing games under the label of Rockstar Games; in 2002, it was renamed Rockstar North. Having established its studio in large spacious premises located in the heart of Edingburgh's Leith district, the company continued to develop installments in the Grand Theft Auto series and other products.
Strictly Limited Games is a publishing label of the German company United Games Entertainment GmbH, specializing in physical releases.

Developer Technosoft was established in April 1982 in Sasebo City of Nagasaki, Japan. The company originally produced consumer software such as a typing tutor, but soon entered the computer games market. Many of their titles were fast-paced action games like Thunder Force and Herzog, notable on platforms dominated by text-heavy strategy and adventure titles. In 1989, Technosoft turned their attention to home consoles, in particular the Sega Mega Drive, becoming the console's first third-party publisher with a port of their PC shooter Thunder Force II. Their Mega Drive games remain popular among fans for their fast-paced action and energetic cyber-rock soundtracks. The 32-bit era saw Technosoft move on to develop for the Sega Saturn and Sony PlayStation, but many of their later games lacked the polish that had earned the company its name. Technosoft released its last title, Neorude: Kizamareta Monshō, in December 1999. All assets were sold to pachinko company Twenty One in 2001, and Technosoft ceased to exist. The Thunder Force brand would later be licensed by Sega to produce one final entry in the series, Thunder Force VI. Several other companies were started by former Technosoft staff -- Arsys Software (later Cyberhead) in 1985, CAProduction in 1993, and Ganbarion in 1999. Additionally, several former Technosoft musicians including Toshiharu Yamanishi and Hyakutaro Tsukumo have continued to work together in the dōjin music scene under several names, including No Brand Sounds and Factory Noise & AG.
ACE Agency is short for Audiovisual, Communication & Entertainment Agency.

BioWare Corp. is a game development studio founded by medical doctors Ray Muzyka and Greg Zeschuk in February 1995. It is based in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. BioWare specializes in RPGs (role-playing games) and only released two products in other genres so far, their first game Shattered Steel (1996) and MDK 2 (2000). Among their most important franchises are Baldur's Gate, Mass Effect and Dragon Age series. They also created Neverwinter Nights (2002), the Star Wars-inspired RPG Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic (2003) and Jade Empire (2005). The company often has been working together with Black Isle Studios for Baldur's Gate games. Obsidian Entertainment, where most of the former Black Isle employees moved on to, also created the sequel to Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. Their in-house developed engines (Infinity, Aurora, Odyssey) have often been used for third party games. On 3 November 2005, the company formed an alliance with Pandemic Studios, backed financially by Elevation Partners. Through the operation, a holding company called BioWare/Pandemic Studios was created. BioWare's two co-founders and Pandemic's two co-founders, Andrew Goldman and Josh Resnick become shareholders and senior executives. John Riccitiello from Elevation became the company's CEO. On 11 October 2007, this partnership was bought by Electronic Arts. On 19 September 2006, BioWare announced the formation of a handheld development group, led by project director Dan Tudge. Earlier, on 13 March 2006, they opened an additional studio in Austin, Texas (BioWare Austin), headed by Gordon Walton and Richard Vogel. On 2 March 2009, an additional studio was opened, BioWare Montréal. After assisting with the Mass Effect series, it was merged with Motive Studios in August 2017. In August 2011, EA2D joined BioWare as BioWare San Francisco until its closure around March 2013. From December 2011 to November 2012, Victory Games operated as BioWare Victory. On 18 September 2012, it was confirmed both founders left the company. Ray Muzyka said to retire from the games industry entirely, stating "I've largely personally achieved what I wanted in videogames". Greg Zeschuk shared a similar sentiment, but said he would not work on games for a while and added: "[...] there’s a strong possibility that I won't be back".

D3Publisher of Europe Ltd. is a publisher and developer of interactive entertainment software. The UK office is part of the global D3Publisher brand which features offices in Europe, The United States of America and Japan. The European division was founded in 2005.
Dune Sound SAS was a French studio involved with voice recording. Following the acquisition by Keywords Studios on 28th July 2017 it was merged into Keywords Studios France SAS on 18th November 2018.

Based in San Rafael, California, originally founded in Cologne (Germany) in 1987 and privately held, Factor 5 LLC is a developer of interactive entertainment software and technology for a variety of console and computer platforms. The team members come from the hacker scene and demo programming. They originally called themselves Light Circle, but then changed their name to avoid associations with their not-so-legal past, and since there were 5 members it became Factor 5. The first project was the Amiga game Katakis (1988), an R-Type clone. They were sued by Activision Europe for copying the concept, and were only allowed to hold on to the right to sell the game if they did the Amiga conversion for R-Type. They complied, and after that, they programming the scrolling 2D shoot-em-up Turrican for the Amiga, inspired by Metroid and Contra. The game did remarkably well, so they created a sequel and then pondered porting it to other systems and consoles. In 1991, the team members decided to give up their studies and officially open the company. Another reason was they needed to have the status of an official company to receive a development system fro Nintendo. They went on to create many sequels to and conversions of Turrican, for consoles such as the Genesis and the SNES as well. In those years, they received financial backing from Softgold (Europe). They ended up in San Rafael when they met a new Lucasfilm Games producer in 1989: Kalani Streicher. At the time, Factor 5 did the German localization of Lucasfilm Games, of which Softgold was the distributor, and they visited the Skywalker Ranch in the US to sort out localization issues. They met again at the CES in 1992, where Kalani told the members he was impressed with Super Turrican on the SNES, and offered them a project at the company. There were six to choose from, and they picked Indiana Jones' Greatest Adventures (SNES). It was the first time they worked with a big license and a strict schedule. Next, Sony's PlayStation was launched and because they were quite tech-savvy, they were offered to do a PSX game for LucasArts. They made a modern version of BallBlazer: Ballblazer Champions, but had a hard time developing the game, because they had never done 3D before. The next project was the PSX conversion of Star Wars: Rebel Assault II - The Hidden Empire. In 1998, they turned to the Nintendo 64 console, as they preferred working with cartridges. They created Star Wars: Rogue Squadron 3D, Star Wars: Episode I - Battle for Naboo and the N64 port of Indiana Jones and the Infernal Machine. At that time, they were also working on a modern version of Turrican: Thornado, similar to One, but the game was first moved to the GameCube, and later cancelled. They couldn't name the game Turrican as Softgold still held the rights. Factor 5 has also created the multi-platform MusyX’ sound tool technology which pioneered 5-channel Dolby Surround Pro-Logic II sound for games in close collaboration with Dolby, the DivX’ video toolset for multiple game platforms, and, as a Nintendo technology partner, was involved in the creation of the Nintendo GameCube hardware. For the GameCube, they continued with the Star Wars license, creating Star Wars: Rogue Squadron II - Rogue Leader and Star Wars: Rogue Squadron III - Rebel Strike. In 2004, Factor 5 announced to start developing for next-gen consoles. In 2005, Factor 5 announced it would move away from producing franchise games and start developing their own IP.  They have become an exclusive partner of Sony Computer Entertainment of America and held up their reputation of stretching the limits of any new system with the release of a title for the PlayStation 3: Lair in September of 2007. Recently, Factor 5 has incorporated in the State of California and is now going under the name of Factor 5, Inc.

The company was established in Kobe, Japan, in 1983, and incorporated on May 29, 1985 as Home Data. They initially focused on developing mahjong and fighting games for the arcades. They also developed various shōgi games and most installments in the baseball series Kōshien. In 1993, on their tenth anniversary, their name was changed to Magical Company.
Media.Vision is a Japanese developer based in Tokyo. The company was founded on March 1st, 1993. They are best known for their Wild Arms series. As of 2012 the company has 80 employees.

Parker Brothers is most well known as the creator of numerous successful board games such as Monopoly, Clue, and Risk. The company has been manufacturing games for well over a century. George S. Parker founded the George S. Parker Company in 1883 to sell his first board game called Banking. When his brother, Charles, joined him in the business in 1888, the name was changed to Parker Brothers. The company remained family owned until 1968, when the company was purchased by General Mills. The company's first forays into electronic gaming came in the late 1970's and early 1980's, when they began to produce electronic versions of their popular board games. Parker Brothers entered the video game market in 1982. They originally produced games for the Atari 2600, Odyssey 2, Intellivision, Atari 5200, and ColecoVision consoles as well as for various computer systems. They primarily licensed successful arcade and computer titles from other companies and produced few original titles. After the video game crash of 1983-84, the company briefly left the video game business. In 1985, Parker Brothers joined Kenner Products to form a new company called Kenner Parker Toys, Inc. In 1987, Kenner Parker Toys was acquired by the Tonka Corporation.
