This development team was created for Hideo Kojima to be able to focus 100% on producing and directing his games, and not have to be burdened with all the paperwork at his old position as a vice president of Konami Digital Entertainment Japan division. Konami closed the subsidiary in 2015. In December 2015 Kojima Productions was relaunched as a new independent studio by Hideo Kojima.

Larian Studios is a Belgian game developer and publisher founded in 1996 and the only high profile developer in the country. They are located in Oudenaarde, near Gent, but have offices all over the world. They have released many software products such as educational titles and casino games, but specialize in role-playing games such as their original Divinity series and most recently also Baldur's Gate III. The company is led by the founder Swen Vincke. Their first game was the real-time strategy title The L.E.D. Wars (1997). It was a project used for short-term finance to convince publishers of the large project they were working on: The Lady, the Mage and the Knight (LMK). That game was however cancelled in 1999 after disagreements with co-developer attic Entertainment Software. In 2002 an isometric RPG was released as a second project: Divine Divinity, followed shortly by the sequel Beyond Divinity (2004). Next, they created the PC2TV game KetnetKick (2004) where children could create content that was displayed on the national children's channel Ketnet. It was later also adapted as the BBC children's MMO Adventure Rock for the British market. In October 2008 an updated version called KetnetKick 2 was released based on the same concept. In 2009 GulliLand was created as a similar concept for the French Jeunesse TV. In January 2010, the Divinity sequel Divinity II: Ego Draconis was released. That was their first title also to be released on a console platform. In 2011, the company released five educational games for children aged seven to eleven to teach mathematics. They were released as five titles in the Monkey Tales series and later also adapted for international markets. On 9 January 2012, founder Swen Vincke announced that all new Larian titles would be self-published, starting with Divinity: Dragon Commander in 2013. The company has a studio in Saint Petersburg, Russia called Larian Studios Saint Petersburg, most likely since around 2014. It is based on the team of Elverils, LLC, but it is not clear if Larian acquired the studio or attracted members of the team to set up a new division. Elverils previously worked together with Larian. On 14 January 2015, a Canadian studio was established as Larian Québec Inc. and on 21 January of the same month Larian Studios Games Limited in Dublin, Ireland. The company released Divinity: Original Sin - Enhanced Edition in 2015. Next Divinity: Original Sin II was released in 2016, an open world RPG and a sequel to the acclaimed Divinity: Original Sin. It was funded through a successful Kickstarter crowdfunding campaign, raising over $2 million. In 2020, the studio launched Baldur's Gate III, a new entry in the long-running Dungeons & Dragons franchise. It was launched in Early Access with gradual content updates. On 6 November 2019, a new development studio was established Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, called Larian GCL Sdn Bhd. The location was chosen specifically to establish a 24-hour cycle, passing work from Québec, Ireland, Belgium, Russia and Malaysia with different time zones. On 17 February 2021, the company announced the acquisition of Turbulenz, based in Guildford, United Kingdom. It was renamed Larian Guilford and assists with the development of Baldur's Gate III. On 2 June 2021, Larian announced the establishment of a new office Larian Studios Spain in Barcelona, Spain, as a seventh studio, following the acquisition of BlitWorks, who previously ported Divinity: Original Sin II to Nintendo Switch and brought Baldur's Gate III to Stadia. The name BlitWorks remained for publishing activities, but the development team was rebranded. On 3 August 2023, Larian released the full version of Baldur's Gate III on Windows, with other platforms following by the end of that year. The game quickly received unanimous acclaim from players and critics, becoming one of the all-time highest-rated games on multiple score aggregators. On 20 May 2024, the company announced the establishment of Larian Studios Poland.

Leaf is a Japanese software developer that focuses on eroge, predominantly visual novels. Their best-known game is To Heart (1997), which was re-released for console systems with the adult content removed. Aquaplus has been publishing their games for PC and consoles.

The original Ludigames S.A. was a mobile games company that was merged and absorbed into Gameloft S.A. in 2001. Since the merger, Gameloft has used the Ludigames name as a label on at least two occasions. It was first used as a publishing label for iPhone games in circa 2009. A few years later (starting in around 2015) the label was used for a web portal hosted by Gameloft's Montréal studio which featured HTML5 based browser games.

Mitchell Corporation was started as a distributor of coin-op PCB in the late 1980s by Koichi Niida and Roy Ozaki. Ozaki is still the president and Niida is still the vice-president. In the eighties, Mitchell was the exclusive overseas agent for most of the small video manufacturers in Japan. The companies represented included Visco, Video Systems, Seta, Metro, Home Data, etc. They handled most games aside from SEGA, Konami, Namco, Taito and the other giants. Previously, Mitchell was an import/export company set up in the sixties by Roy Ozaki's father, who was called Mitchell. Most recently, the company has created the games Puzz Loop and Polarium, and they produce titles for mobile platforms.

Formed by former Seibu Kaihatsu staff, Moss has taken over development of the Raiden series from their earlier employer, while also developing games for arcade or mobile phones. They do not hold the Raiden IP, but license it from Seibu. The company was established by Toshinobu Komazawa (formerly at Seibu Kaihatsu) who is currently CEO of the company. He set up the studio mainly to keep the series and the Japanese Raiden-like shooter genre alive when the fame of Seibu Kaihatsu as an arcade developer started to decline.

NinjaBee is a division of Wahoo Studios focused on self-funded creative efforts, established on 17th September 2004. They quickly started to focus on Xbox 360 Live Arcade games, and released Outpost Kaloki X and Cloning Clyde.
Founded in 1989 by Mark Steven Miller, Nu Romantic Productions produced audio for over 60 titles. It was closed in 1994, when Mark Steven Miller went to work as Audio Director for SEGA of America.
PikPok is the mobile division of the New Zealand company Prodigy Design Limited, also trading as Sidhe Interactive for console and PC games.

column1: Prison Games Sp. z o. o.

column2: Quantic Dream is a French company founded by David Cage in May 1997. The name is based on quantum physics, a science mixing mathematics, esoterism, and interactivity with the observer. After developing a prototype for an initial interactive entertainment using real time 3D technologies developed in-house, the company signed a deal with the English publisher Eidos Interactive. After two and half years of development, the company delivered its first product Omikron: The Nomad Soul featuring David Bowie as the composer of the original soundtrack and the first real time 3D virtual actor in history. In July 2000, French investors joined the company in order to develop the next generation of interactive entertainment. The company plans to combine cinema, digital television, the Internet, and interactivity for the mass-market. In January 2019 the Chinese company NetEase became a minor shareholder and on 31st August 2022 the company announced the complete acquisition of the studio, becoming a 100% shareholder.

column1: Shanghai Arts United Software Co., Ltd.

column2: Laser Soft was a subsidiary of  Telenet Japan and Yodobashi founded in October 1988 to focus on games for optical media, especially the PC Engine (TurboGrafx CD). It is known for the Cosmic Fantasy series of games. In June 1990 the shares by Yodobashi were taken over by Telenet, and in January 1991 Laser Soft was formally merged with Wolf Team. After that the label Laser Soft was kept for further games by Telenet for PC Engine and other systems until about 1992.

Starfish-SD Inc. is the Sales and Distribution arm of holding company Starfish Inc. It was created in 2004 when Starfish restructured, moving its operations to subsidiary companies. Starfish-SD handles publishing, distribution, and licensing for all Starfish-produced titles. Development is usually handled by either Starfish Kaihatsu Ltd. or Cromwell Inc., which are also subsidiaries of Starfish Inc.

Studio Saizensen (スタジオ最前線) is an independent developer based in Niiza-shi, Saitama-ken, Japan. The company was established in September 1997 by Toshinobu Kondō. In addition to video games, the company also does design and planning for card and tabletop games. In addition to Kondō, the company employs or has employed several other Treasure and Fill in Café alumni including Tetsuhiko Kikuchi and Masaki Ukyo.
Icon Games Entertainment Ltd. is an independent development studio based in Oxfordshire, UK. It was founded in 2002. The studio has created International Pool Championship (PS2) and Spinout (PSP).

Talespinners Studios is a UK company established on 26th April 2016. The studio specializes in outsourcing, providing writing, narrative design, setting & characters, editing, direction and consultancy.

UPL, short for Universal Play Land, was established in the early eighties (not even the old employees know the exact year) as Universal's (now Aruze) sales branch in the Kantō region. Its head office was in the Tochigi prefecture, while most of the games development was conducted in its Tokyo office. Although UPL did arcade games in a variety of genres, it is mostly remembered for its vertically scrolling shooters with a high level of tactical thinking. Though UPL did quite well in the arcades, it almost missed the bus when consoles arrived on the scene, and was a late comer on the NES, releasing its first home game in 1988. While this may be seen as one reason for UPL's 1992 bankruptcy, the main factor seems to have been the company's unsuccessful pachinko machine business.

Ubisoft Eood is a game development studio of Ubisoft Entertainment and it is located in Sofia, Bulgaria. The studio was opened in June 2006 and became Ubisoft's second game development studio in Eastern Europe. In 2008 the company employed 50 people.
Wastelands Interactive is a Polish game development studio focusing on history-themed titles, especially turn-based strategies.

Bad Animals, Inc. was founded in 1979 in Seattle, Washington (USA) as Steve Lawson Productions by Steve Lawson and his wife Debbie Lawson. The company started small with one 8-track analog studio offering audio production. By 1990 the company had grown, had opened additional studios and began music recording. In 1991 Steve joined forces with Nancy and Ann Wilson (of the rock group Heart) to construct Studio X, a world-class live recording studio. The company began using the name Lawson Productions, having dropped the "Steve" from its name. In 1992 Lawson Productions' name was officially changed to Bad Animals/Seattle (borrowing the name from the Heart 1987 record album "Bad Animals"). Studio X was sold in 1997 and the Wilson sisters sold their interest in the company back to the Lawsons. In June 1999 Bad Animals/Seattle was sold to 3 of its longtime employees Dave Howe, Mike McAuliffe, Tom McGurk along with Seattle native Charlie Nordstrom. Bad Animals focuses entirely on sound design, voice talent casting, recording & mixing, and original music for commercials, multimedia projects, interactive projects, episodic television, feature films and audio environments.

Founded in 1987 by Steve Kelly, Mike Montgomery and Eric Matthews the Bitmap Brothers were the original ‘rockstar’ developers - a small, but highly successful development team that prized quality over quantity, and depth over glitz. The company has been responsible for several memorable titles, released on a range of formats that have included 8, 16 and 32-bit home computers and consoles - from the Commodore 64 through to 21st century PCs and consoles. The first game from the Bitmaps, Xenon, was released in 1988, a sophisticated shoot-‘em up that, through a combination of cutting-edge graphics and challenging gameplay, became the first Amiga game to enter the UK top 40 charts. The sequel, Xenon 2: Megablast, was an even bigger success. Also in 1988, the Bitmap Brothers followed up the success of Xenon with the futuristic beat-‘em up ballgame, Speedball. Its sequel Speedball 2:Brutal Deluxe was their most critically-acclaimed game. A third title in the series, Speedball 2100 on the PlayStation, was released in September 2000. A 3D version entitled Speedball Arena was abandoned mid-project. Other hits included TV tie-in Magic Pockets, much-delayed Steampunk shooter The Chaos Engine, and real-time strategy game Z. Their last game was World War II: Frontline Command. This was a WW2 RTS that used the 3D engine from Steel Soldiers. At one point the studio was split into two studio sites - one in Wapping, London, the other in Harrogate in the north of England. In 1998, Kelly and Matthews both stepped down from the board to concentrate on games design and programming respectively, Mike Montgomery took on the role of Managing Director and successfully drove the company forward, investing in personnel and equipment that enabled the company to develop a new range of next-generation games software. Employing over 20 designers, programmers and artists, the Bitmap Brothers remained fiercely independent and entirely privately owned.

exozet games is a leading independent development studio which creates high quality games and applications for mobile devices and titles for PC and consoles (NDS, Wii, Xbox360). Mobile games include the award-winning Three Investigators adventure series, Ingenious, Catan and many more. exozet games is part of the exozet group with a staff of more than 150 employees and has offices in Berlin, Potsdam, Vienna and Zagreb. exozet games works for renowned companies from a range of sectors including games publishers, media companies, advertising agencies and brand owners. exozet games’ services include design, project management and production, quality assurance and consultancy on sales and marketing.

Gamebridge is a European publishing company, launched as a joint venture between Interchannel, a Tokyo based developer and publisher of video games alongside other media, and Bergsala, the official Nintendo distributor for the Nordic region. The company's goal is to bring new concepts from Japan to Europe, a practice similar to what 505 Games and Ghostlight Ltd. have been doing in the UK. The company also entered a partnership with Rising Star Games, to handle the firm’s sales and marketing initiatives throughout the PAL territory. The company's CEO is Shigeki Takeuchi and the first titles were announced in March 2009.

Founded in 1979 by Toshikazu Sato, Jordan develops software, digital content for mobile phones and the Web, and is involved in the travel industry. They were fairly prolific video game developers during the 1990's, particularly for the Super Famicom (SNES) console. In the second half of the 2000's they resumed game development after a long hiatus, focusing on Nintendo DS and the Wii.

Lucid Games is a UK game development studio first announced in February 2011 and led by Pete Wallace. It consists largely of former developers of Bizarre Creations, which was closed by Activision Blizzard in the same month.

Marmalade Game Studio, initially Ideaworks Game Studio, is the game development division of Marmalade Technologies Ltd The game team was originally established in 2005, but the game development division only became a distinct operation in mid-2009. Initially focusing on smartphone games, from then on the focus was broadened to consoles as well.

NDL, the developer of 3D graphics technology behind many leading PC packages and games, is applying its expertise to products that help developers create better 3D games in dramatically less time. Better, Faster Game Development NDL’s newest product, Gamebryo’, is based on NetImmerse technology used in the development of more than 70 titles including blockbuster hits that have won numerous industry awards such as Mythic Entertainment’s Dark Age of Camelot, Bethesda Softworks’ Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, and Irrational Games’ Freedom Force. It allows developers of games for the PC, PlayStation 2, Xbox, and GameCube to spend more time making their games look great and play well, saving time and money in the process. Beyond games, NDL technology is finding use in 3D applications on the Web, in CAD, and in simulation and training. A History of Technical Innovation NDL was founded in 1983 by Turner Whitted (a computer graphics pioneer, 1986 SIGGRAPH Computer Graphics Achievement award winner, and member of the National Academy of Engineering) and Robert Whitton. Our high-quality rendering software product, rPlus, was used in such products as Caligari, trueSpace and Autodesk’s AutoCAD. The company has also played key consulting roles in diverse projects for clients such as Adobe Systems, IBM, the Environmental Protection Agency, and Interactive Magic, a PC game developer and publisher. Since 1997, first with NetImmerse and now with Gamebryo, the company has developed software in use by video game developers and developers of other 3D applications. NDL is located in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. http://www.ndl.com/about_overview.cfm

Pole To Win America is a company that offers quality assurance, localization, focus group testing and customer relation services. It was founded on 1st August 2009. It is a 100% subsidiary of the Japanese company Pole To Win Co., Ltd.

Red Kite Games Limited is a game development studio based in Yorkshire, England. On 1st February 2019 the Sumo Digital group announced the acquisition of the company. Best known as a work-for-hire team, the studio continued to operate under its own name as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Sumo Digital while also providing services to other studios.

Revolution Software is a UK game development studio established in 1990 by Charles Cecil, Tony Warriner, David Sykes and Noirin Carmody. The company focuses on adventure titles and its first release was Lure of the Temptress in 1992. The early titles were all developed using their proprietary Virtual Theatre engine, which was used for the last time in the second Broken Sword game Broken Sword: The Smoking Mirror (1997). The studio is especially known for the 1994 dystopian adventure Beneath a Steel Sky, and the Broken Sword series with four games released between 1994 and 2006. Around 2000 the studio worked on the licensed titles Disney's Story Studio: Mulan and Gold and Glory: The Road to El Dorado, and launched In Cold Blood as an original IP. Following the fourth Broken Sword game Secrets of the Ark: A Broken Sword Game in 2006, no new titles were released for a few years. Instead, the studio worked on a director's cut and a remastered version of earlier installments in the series. The traditional PC focus was expanded by making them available on new platforms such as Nintendo DS, Wii, Android and iOS. In July 2012, a fifth game in the Broken Sword series, Broken Sword 5: The Serpent's Curse, was announced through a Kickstarter campaign based on crowd funding. When the target was reached on 5th September 2012, stretch goals were made available along with option to greenlight the development of Beneath a Steel Sky 2. Broken Sword 5 would ultimately release in December 2013, while a sequel to Beneath a Steel Sky titled Beyond a Steel Sky would release in June 2020.

Secret 6, Inc. is based near San Francisco, California, US. It was founded in 2005 as a company for art outsourcing with their production studio The Studio of Secret6, Inc.. They grew into a full development company, specializing in 2D and 3D flash games, and later games for iOS-compatible mobile phones. In November 2018, Secret 6 Madrid SL was opened.

Smilegate Entertainment is a South Korean game company. It is established in 2002 and is headquartered in Pangyo. The company develops, publishes, and services online games on mobile and PC platforms. Smilegate is best known for the first-person shooter CrossFire (2007).

Tozai, Inc. is a company founded in 1996 by Sheila Boughten and Scott Tsumura. Tozai, a Japanese word meaning "East and West" or "the whole world", was formed to promote and expand IP licensing opportunities between developers and publishers throughout the world. Tozai, Inc. develops and publishes games under the brand of Tozai Games.
Type-Moon is a Japanese company that specializes in development of visual novels, often with adult content. It was founded in 2000 by author Kinoko Nasu and illustrator Takashi Takeuchi.

Bethesda Game Studios is the in-house development team of Bethesda Softworks LLC. The studio is located in Rockville, Maryland (USA), and is lead by Todd Howard. It was founded in 2001. In 2015 a subsidiary studio, Bethesda Game Studios Montreal was opened. The studio head is Yves Lachance, formerly of Behaviour Interactive.
Blueberry Soft is a Japanese company which publishes DVD Player versions of hentai visual novels in Japan.

Certain Affinity (CA) was founded in 2006 in Austin, Texas. The company’s 120 full-time employees (as of 2016) include veterans from dozens of successful game studios. Max Hoberman, CA’s founder, serves as President and Creative Director. A 10-year veteran of Bungie, Max was one of the key people responsible for the success of the Halo franchise, having led efforts to bring the game online as Multiplayer, Interface, and Online lead for both Halo 2 and Halo 3. The company started its work with multiplayer maps for the Halo series and co-development on Left 4 Dead.  Notable releases since then include co-development on Call of Duty: Remastered, DOOM, Call of Duty: World at War and Call of Duty: Black Ops, downloadable competitive and cooperative content for Halo: Reach, Halo Anniversary and Halo 4, as well as the original strategy game Age of Booty and original action role playing game Crimson Alliance.

This English company was started as The Big Red Software Company by Paul Ranson in 1989. They primarily developed conversions, budget games and licensed titles, working closely with Codemasters in their early years. Later, their eponymous racing game was successful. In 1995, Big Red Software was acquired by Eidos Interactive. The division was renamed Corrosive Software in about 1997 and was a development unit of Eidos. The division completed the game Assault Corps but it was never released. Eidos closed down Corrosive Software in 1998.

Cyberlore Studios, Inc. was incorporated in 1992 by the team that created the SSI Gold Box hit, The Dark Queen of Krynn. The first project under the Cyberlore banner was another SSI Advanced Dungeons and Dragons game, Al-Qadim: The Genie's Curse. The game required the development of an entirely new engine for overhead-perspective, real-time play. By adding the necessary staff, the company completed "Genie" in fourteen months. Released to excellent reviews, the game has since been translated into four languages with world wide sales in excess of 90,000 copies.  Cyberlore and SSI teamed up again with Entomorph: Plague of the Darkfall. Using an updated version of the "Genie" engine, this game completed for the PC in late September 1995, and was one of the first Windows 95 games on the market. The Macintosh version followed in November 1995.  Cyberlore's smash hit, WarCraft II: Beyond the Dark Portal, was finished at the end of April '96. Published by Blizzard Entertainment and welcomed by glowing reviews, it exceeded sales expectations and easily earned its place in the elite pantheon of WarCraft's quality products. Computer Gaming World crowned it the best expansion set of the year. In August '97 Cyberlore developed Heroes of Might and Magic II: The Price of Loyalty expansion for 3DO. It immediately joined the top ten best-selling games. Critics loved this turn-based strategy war game calling it "addictive," and with Computer Gaming World giving it a five star review. Not only did this set capture the look and feel of the original game, it added several new play-enhancing features.  Spring of '98 saw the release of Deadlock II:Shrine Wars, published by Accolade. A sequel to one of 1996's best-selling, turn-based strategy games, Deadlock 2 takes the original game to the next level with new units, buildings, technologies and an all-new interface. It is also be the first application of our phonetic editing system, used to create the game's animated alien characters.  In March, 2000, Cyberlore released Majesty®: The Fantasy Kingdom Sim’ to phenomenal reviews. Published by Hasbro Interactive, Majesty has garnered high praise from press and gamers alike. It earned Choosing Children's Software's Innovative Game of the Year Award and landed in CGW's list of the top five strategy games of the year. Cyberlore ported Majesty to the MacIntosh, and MacPlay released it in December, 2000 to five star reviews.  Cyberlore completed the feature packed expansion set, Majesty: The Northern Expansion, in 2000. It includes a bunch of new missions, monsters, buildings, spells and great multi-player enhancements.

INTENSE, Ltd. is a game development studio based in the Chuo ward of Tokyo, Japan. The company was established in July 2002, and primarily focuses on handheld, mobile, and downloadable games. The company is best known for their many room escape games.

Kepler Interactive was formed in 2021 by Alexis Garavaryan, a games industry executive who previously co-founded Kowloon Nights, a game development investment fund that has contributed to a number of indie studios. While the company is a publisher, they employ a co-operative model somewhat unique in the games industry, where many of their development partners get ownership stakes in the company and are encouraged to evaluate and assist in each other's projects. They also provide more traditional publishing services to third-party studios. They are partially owned by Chinese conglomerate NetEase, who took a minority stake in the company in exchange for $120M in funding. Since its inception, they have seen sizeable and quick success, releasing a number of hit titles and reaching $50M in revenue in 2022. As of 2023, it has also used the Kepler Ghost subsidiary for publishing, funding and marketing independent titles.

Kerberos Productions is a gathering of experienced video game developers, with over 35 years of collective experience, based in Vancouver, BC, Canada. Before forming their own company, the team was responsible in the development of both Homeworld: Cataclysm for Sierra and Treasure Planet: Battle at Procyon for Disney Interactive. Team members have also worked on over a dozen hit games, including Homeworld, Ground Control, Team Fortress, and Counter Strike. They intend to establish a reputation in the PC gaming industry of applying their experience towards a high standard of PC games. They are a unified group of industry veterans who don't just make video games, they play and understand games.

Legend Entertainment Company was a Northern Virginia-based developer started in 1989 by Bob Bates and Mike Verdu. Their early games were illustrated text adventures. In 1993, they broke from the text tradition with Companions of Xanth which was their first game to feature a point-and-click interface. Since around 1993-1994 they have used different distributors for each game. If nothing else is noted below, they have distributed the game themselves. In spite of their relative success up to fall 1995, they decided to stop publishing games themselves but instead focus on doing development work for other companies. Then in 1999, Legend was acquired by GT Interactive. GT was subsequently acquired by Infogrames, which later changed its name to Atari. Atari closed Legend Entertainment in late 2003, after the Unreal II: eXpanded MultiPlayer add-on had been released.

Liquid Violet is an audio production company based in London, England. Founded in 2008, it was incorporated on 7th January 2011. The studio initially focused on voice production and casting. In January 2014 Keywords International plc announced the acquisition of the studio, in a deal worth up to £1.6mln. Liquid Violet was the first studio bought by Keywords at the start of an acquisition spree, following Keywords' IPO onto the AIM market the year before and its plan is to consolidate what it saw as a fragmented sector of audio production, localisation and other development services. In 2018 a dedicated facility was built and in 2019 services were expanded into English dubbing and original animation voice production.

Living Books was created in 1992 by Mark Schlichting. It was formerly a Broderbund Software and Random House joint venture company. Its first title was Just Grandma and Me. In 1998, their last title in the Living Book series was D.W. the Picky Eater. As of 1999, the Living Books brand is no longer in development. Their interactive storybooks are adaptations and originals from Mercer Mayer, Marc Brown, Jack Perlutsky, Eli Noyes, Kevin Henkes, Stan and Jan Berenstain, Jannell Cannon, Dr. Seuss, and several others. In 2010, the former Living Books has been released as apps by Wanderful Inc. (which Mark Schlichting also founded).

Looking Glass Studios, Inc. was a development studio based in Cambridge, MA (USA). It was formed in 1992 through the merger of Blue Sky Productions and Lerner Research. The most prominent developer at the studio was Warren Spector. Some of the most important franchises the team worked on are Flight Unlimited, the Thief series, and the System Shock games. The company was shut down three months after releasing Thief II: The Metal Age and about 60 employees were let go when their publisher Eidos was hit with a financial crisis. Employees trickled down to studios such as Mad Doc Software, Ion Storm Austin and Irrational Games where their influences are still visible in the Deus Ex and BioShock franchises.

Mythic was a game development studio based in Fairfax, Virginia (USA). It was recognized for its massively multiplayer online role-playing games and it was a subsidiary of Electronic Arts before its closure. The company was initially founded in 1995 as Interworld Productions by Mark Jacobs and Rob Denton. Both of them already had a long history in online game development at that time. Mark Jacobs founded Adventures Unlimited Software in 1984, responsible for commercial online RPGs such as Aradath launched that year (with a monthly subscription fee), and online versions of Dragon's Gate (1985) and Diplomacy. Rob Denton previously co-founded Interesting Systems in 1990 and was responsible for the multi-user BBS text-based RPG Darkness Falls (initially released in 1991 as Tempest). Much of the game code would later serve for the Mythic game Dark Age of Camelot. Many of the original developers of the individual companies eventually ending up working for Mythic. The company name Interworld Productions was changed to Mythic Entertainment in November 1997 when it was found out there was already another Interworld. Mythic was very prolific with the releases of online games in the mid to late nineties. The studio was responsible for Castles II Online (1995), Rolemaster: Magestorm (1996), Invasion Earth (1997), Rolemaster: Bladelands (1997), Silent Death: Online (1997), Splatterball (1997), Aliens Online (1998), Godzilla Online (1998), Starship Troopers: Battlespace (1998), Darkness Falls: The Crusade (1999), Darkstorm: The Well of Souls (1999), Spellbinder: The Nexus Conflict (1999) and Independence Day Online (2000). They covered a wide variety of genres, ranging from regular RPGs to space-based battles and team-based first-person shooters. Some of these were developed in cooperation with other companies (such as Centropolis) and were often only available to US players, through AOL or the GameStorm service, owned by Kesmai Corporation. The studio's real breakthrough title was the fantasy MMORPG Dark Age of Camelot based on the story of King Arthur. Development was started in 1999. In 2000 the company was financially backed by Abandon Entertainment and the title was released in 2001, with Anarchy Online, Ultima Online and EverQuest as its main competitors. It was the studio's first MMOG (massively multiplayer online game). Previous titles were all played in smaller teams or squads. The game is still maintained today and it received numerous expansions over the years. Following the release Mythic started work on a new game in 2002, Imperator Online. It was based on an alternate history where the Roman Republic never disappeared and eventually evolved into an empire covering multiple planets and with access to space travel. The project was eventually cancelled in 2005. In June 2006 Mythic Entertainment was acquired by Electronic Arts, which had no MMORPG division at the time, and renamed EA Mythic. The studio would, among else, maintain and develop new content for Ultima Online. After an internal restructuring the company's name was changed back to Mythic Entertainment in July 2008. In an interview that month Mark Jacobs explained that the name was changed back because of an open attitude EA had taken to the development studios it owned at the time. Mythic's next title was the fantasy MMORPG Warhammer Online: Age of Reckoning, based on the popular Warhammer universe. It was launched in September 2009. The year before, in January 2008, EA had also acquired the acclaimed (offline) RPG development studio BioWare Corporation and on 24 June 2009 it was announced EA would restructure both Mythic and BioWare as a single RPG/MMO division headed by BioWare General Manager Ray Muzyka. Mythic general manager and co-founder Mark Jacobs had resigned the day before and was replaced by Rob Denton. By June 2010 the company was renamed BioWare Mythic and eventually completely integrated into the main BioWare RPG group. The studio name returned as a developer of mobile games, first the free-to-play action RPG Ultima Forever: Quest for the Avatar for iOS in August 2013 followed by the free-to-play game Dungeon Keeper in December 2013. On 29 May 2014, it was reported parent company Electronic Arts closed the division. Work on mobile titles was relocated to other studios, while some former Mythic staff would establish Broadsword Online Games, to which the maintenance of Ultima Online and Dark Age of Camelot were transferred under license from EA.

NetherRealm Studios is a game development studio based in Chicago, Illinois (USA). It is a subsidiary of Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment. Before becoming NetherRealm, it was known as Midway Chicago, Midway Games' original development studio that developed all their arcade games. Later, it focused solely on games for home and portable consoles, with titles such as Blitz: The League (2005), Stranglehold (2007) and Game Party (2007). It was based in the same facility as Midway Amusement Games and just across the street of the main Midway office. On 12 February 2009, Midway filed for bankruptcy and on 1 July 2009, most of the game assets, including the Midway studio, were sold to Warner Bros. Shortly after, the studio was renamed WB Games Chicago. Almost everyone not involved with the Mortal Kombat franchise was laid off, including the team that had been working on the Hero open-world superhero game since 2006. Chip Sineni was one of those employees and he went on to found Phosphor Games in 2009, to continue the project building it up again from scratch and he took along many former Midway Chicago members. In June 2010, the division was renamed NetherRealm Studios, after the NeatherRealm universe where the Mortal Kombat series is set. It is also led by the series co-creator Ed Boon. The first NetherRealm title was Mortal Kombat in April 2011, as a reboot of the series. The company would expand the franchise with Mortal Kombat X (2015), Mortal Kombat 11 (2019) and yet another reboot with Mortal Kombat 1 (2023). A second title, Batman: Arkham City Lockdown for iOS, was released in December 2011. In June 2012, a third title was revealed, the fighting game Injustice: Gods Among Us. It was released in April 2013.

Omnibus Japan Inc. (株式会社オムニバス・ジャパン) is a Tokyo-based audio post-production, computer graphics, and visual effects company established in April 1987 as a joint venture between Omnibus Company of Toronto, Canada and Tohokushinsha Film Corp. After the bankruptcy of Omnibus shortly thereafter, Omnibus Japan became a fully-owned subsidiary of Tohokushinsha and remains so as of 2023.

Polys Entertainment began as an internal development studio of Sony Computer Entertainment Inc. Under that name, the team developed two Motor Toon Grand Prix racing games for the PlayStation. In 1998, one year after the completion of their monumentally successful game Gran Turismo, it became an independent company and was renamed Polyphony Digital Inc. The offices are located in Tokyo, led by Kazunori Yamauchi, the director of the Gran Turismo series. Polyphony Digital Inc. is a subsidiary of Sony Computer Entertainment Incorporated and part of the SCE Worldwide Studios group.

Remedy Entertainment Ltd. is a Finnish development studio founded in 1995 and based in Espoo. Many of the founding members were previously part of the demo scene group Future Crew. The studio's first game was the top-down racing shooter Death Rally (1996), followed by the two Max Payne games (2001 and 2003) featuring a titular protagonist in a story of hard-boiled revenge. The game popularised the use of bullet time in games, a technique best known from The Matrix movies, mixed with action sequences reminiscent of John Woo movies, but entirely set in against film noir backdrop. After having sold the movie options in 2001, a film based on the story starring Mark Wahlberg was eventually released in 2008. Max Payne 3 was released in 2012, but it was designed by Rockstar Vancouver and the series writer Sam Lake was not involved. The company released its fourth game, the action thriller Alan Wake, in 2010. Despite having released a small number of games in its relatively long history, the studio does fine as all of their titles have been received very well, both by the press and in sales numbers. Alan Wake was the studio's first title not initially released on the PC. It remained an Xbox 360 exclusive for two years and had a disappointing start in sales, although according to Remedy team leader Oskari Häkkinen the sales continued well post-launch. In 2012 the PC version was made available with a number of tweaks and the studio also released the more action-focused spin-off Alan Wake's American Nightmare as an Xbox 360 XBLA game. A remastered version of the original game was released in 2021. The studio is responsible for the popular benchmark application 3DMark. Initially created as Final Reality in 1997, Remedy soon established the separate company Futuremark Oy, referencing the demo group's name, to handle the application. In January 2008 Futuremark established its own game development studio as Futuremark Games Studio.

Saturn Plus specializes in computer games development. The company entered the Russian gaming market in 1998 and is known as a "quest and adventure games developer." The company specialized in the development of comic-parody graphic quests about the heroes of Soviet and Russian jokes.

Ubisoft opened its Casablanca studio (Morocco) in February 1998, headed by Stéphane Faureau and the team has been responsible for contributions to games such as Peter Jackson's King Kong: The Official Game of the Movie and Prince of Persia: The Two Thrones, as well as responsible for the production of titles for the Nintendo DS including Star Wars: Lethal Alliance and the two Rayman Raving Rabbids games. In 2007, the studio employs 50 team members. The company was closed on 13 June 2016.

Wadjet Eye Games is an independent software developer incorporated by Dave Gilbert on 17th October 2006. The first commercial game, The Shivah, was released in August 2006, followed by The Blackwell Legacy in December 2006 and Blackwell Unbound in September 2007. In February 2009 Emerald City Confidential was released, an adventure based on the The Wonderful Wizard of Oz universe of the novel by L. Frank Baum. While all other Wadjet Eye projects were previously completely independent, this title was made for PlayFirst, Inc. It had a larger development team and did not use the Adventure Game Studio engine.
Addictive Games is a division of Prism Leisure Corporation Plc.
Founded in 1990, absorbed into Sammy in 1992, later spun off again into Yumekobo.

A small Japanese developer founded in 2000 by ex-Riverhillsoft employees. Started out by making mobile games. Currently owns the rights to the J.B. Harold, Tōdō Ryūnosuke Tantei Nikki and World Neverland series.

Arkane Studios is a development studio based in Lyon, France and it is owned by ZeniMax Media Inc. It was founded on 1st October 1999 with an initial investment of 1,150,000 Francs ($180,000) with developers coming mainly from Electronic Arts and Atari. The company is currently headed by Raphaël Colantonio. In 2000 they shopped around a demo of the action RPG Arx Fatalis to secure a publisher. It was picked up by JoWooD Productions Software AG and the game was released in 2002, followed by a 2003 Xbox release, published by Dreamcatcher. In 2004, the company signed with Ubisoft to develop a title under the Might and Magic brand, powered by Valve's Source engine. Dark Messiah of Might & Magic was released in October 2006. In 2008 an updated Xbox 360 version was released as Dark Messiah: Might and Magic - Elements. In July 2006 Arkane Studios LLC was opened, a second office based in Austin, Texas (USA). In December 2006 the first-person shooter The Crossing was announced, but it was later put on hold. Between 2006 and 2007 the company worked on Return to Ravenholm for Valve, a game in the Half-Life series, but it was eventually cancelled. The team also contributed to the multiplayer development of Call of Duty: World at War (2008). In July 2009 2K Marin signed up Arkane to contribute design, animation and art to BioShock 2. In August 2010 the company was acquired by ZeniMax Media. On 7th July 2011 a new game was announced, the stealth-based assassination game Dishonored. It was released in October 2012.

Armor Project is a company run by Yuji Horii. As creator of the Dragon Quest series of games, he has created Armor Project primarily for the development of Dragon Quest properties. Armor project currently has a exclusive production contract with Enix, now Square-Enix.
AsRec SAS was a French studio involved with voice recording. Following the acquisition by Keywords Studios on 28th July 2017 it was merged into Keywords Studios France SAS on 31st August 2018.

column1: BANDAI NAMCO Entertainment Asia Pte. Ltd

column2: Beyond published computer games in the UK in the 80s, most notably Mike Singleton's early titles. The label was initially owned by EMAP, the publishing company behind titles such as Computer & Video Games. The company was sold to British Telecom and became part of Telecomsoft. Beyond also had two sub-labels - Monolith and Nexus - designed to publish arcade-style games, while Beyond was to concentrate on adventure and strategy.

Cauldron was founded in 1996 by David Durčák, Marian Ferko, Maroš Stano and Peter Rjapoš, and it resided in Bratislava, the capital of the Slovak Republic. The development studio operated with two teams. The company was acquired by Bohemia Interactive in 2013 and renamed to Bohemia Interactive Slovakia. By early 2020, the company ceased operations. On 6 February 2020, THQ Nordic announced the acquisition of the studio's staff and the formation of Nine Rocks Games.

Codemasters Birmingham is a development studio of The Codemasters Software Company Limited and it is based in Birmingham, United Kingdom. It was first announced in 14th November 2008 when Codemasters reported to have acquired the Birmingham division of Swordfish Studios, a development studio that had been active since September 2002. The studio was initially led by Trevor Williams, former managing director of Swordfish Studios. In October 2009, it was confirmed he left the studio. Alex McLean took over, the former co-founder of Pivotal Games.

Consult Computer Systems was formed in 1986 as a small 2 man team to develop IT solutions for local small businesses. The 2 members were Glenn Benson and David Kelly. This business plan wasn't working and another approach was needed so an idea was hatched to develop games. Whilst looking for a graphic artist they made their initial contact with Mike Singleton. Through this contact they were contracted to do some preliminary work on a new project called Dark Sceptre and then employed a graphic artist David Price. Mike Singleton was developing other ideas and put their name to Melbourne House and were given the contract to develop Throne Of Fire. For this job they employed Sinclair Spectrum programmers Jim Bagley, Dave Sharp and graphic artist Dave Wharton while Glenn Benson coded the CPC version. During the development of Throne of Fire, Consult were offered the contract to complete Dark Sceptre by Beyond. This was the real birth of Consult. They moved into offices and employed another programmer Chris Pink and another graphic artist. More Later..............
Crazy Labs is a publishing label for casual games developed by TabTale.

DOMO is an internal development team of Softstar. The group was formed by Cai Minghong in 1986, before Softstar was founded, but began working on games after officially becoming part of the company. The team included prominent designers such as Bao Hongxiu, Alan Kuo, Shin Ruei Wu, and others. They are best known for developing the Xuanyuan Jian games.

DQ Entertainment Ltd is an Indian studio with divisions devoted to animation, games and other new media. DQ is short for Data Quest. In games, the studio contributed to the 2008 DS title Zubo and the first season of the 2007-2008 Sam & Max games.

Dire Wolf Digital is a game development studio based in Denver, Colorado (USA). The company was founded by Scott Martins (President), previously founder of Worlds Apart Productions, and studio head of Sony Online Entertainment Denver after Worlds Apart was acquired by Sony. The formation was announced on 13th July 2010. Other initial employees are Paul Dennen (Creative Director), Kieran Yanner (Art Director), Ryan Anderson (Technical Lead), and Bruce Mitchener (Server Architect).

Eden Games is a game development studio. It was originally owned by Atari and based in Lyon, France. The company was founded on 4 January 1998 as Eden Studios by Stéphane Baudet, Frédéric Jay and David Nadal. All three of them previously worked together at Infogrames as a part of the internal Eden development group. By forming the company, Eden became independent. The studio initially signed contracts with Infogrames for two V-Rally games, but asserted its independence by signing a publishing agreement with Electronic Arts in 1999. In May 2002, the company was sold to Infogrames (that later became Atari), which already held 19.8% of the company's shares. In September 2003, the name was changed to Eden Games S.A.S. Most recently, the studio is known for the Alone in the Dark reboot (2008) and the Test Drive Unlimited series. In May 2011, it became known the team of 80 people faced redundancies of over 50 jobs. Eden felt it was a victim of mismanagement by Atari and decided to go on strike to negotiate on the redundancy plan, get fair compensation, and be involved with the future of the studio after the restructuring. The studio was closed on 1 March 2013, but reopened on 31 October 2013. In 2011, a number of developers left to found the studio Blossom Minds. Eden Games, long under Atari’s ownership, was placed into judicial liquidation on 29 January 2013, effectively shuttering the studio. Despite a promise by Atari earlier in 2012 that the studio "had not closed", the liquidation marked its end as part of Atari. However, the studio rose again: on 31 October 2013, former employees relaunched Eden Games as an independent development operation, no longer associated with Atari. This revival was made possible thanks to funding by investment firms ID Invest and Monster Capital  Under its new independent structure, Eden Games shifted its focus primarily to racing games for mobile platforms and later for consoles. Its first post-relaunch release was GT Spirit on Apple TV in December 2015. They then created the Gear.Club franchise, developed with support from publishers like Microids and Apple, and in partnership with Codemasters and Electronic Arts on F1®. The success of Gear.Club Unlimited on Nintendo Switch led to an expanded partnership to bring Gear.Club Unlimited 2 to next-gen consoles (Xbox Series X, PlayStation 5), announced for Q4 2021. From 2017 to 2021, Eden Games operated as a subsidiary of Engine Gaming & Media (also known as Engine Media). During this time, they continued to build their racing portfolio, including titles like Gear.Club Unlimited 2 and Gear.Club: Stradale. In April 2022, Engine Gaming & Media sold its interest in Eden Games to Animoca Brands for approximately USD 15.3 million (~USD 16 million). Animoca, a Hong Kong-based leader in blockchain-based entertainment and metaverse gaming, acquired Eden to bolster its REVV Motorsport ecosystem and develop new Web3/blockchain-based racing games featuring NFTs and play-to-earn mechanics. Animoca’s CEO Yat Siu noted that Eden’s 25 years of racing game expertise would bring significant value to its metaverse ambitions. Eden Games remains active and is still based in Lyon, France, now as part of Animoca Brands. The studio continues to work on racing games across mobile, PC, and console platforms, and is involved in blockchain/metaverse game development under Animoca's umbrella. The studio has also developed several racing titles for Microids. The company is led by two original founders, David Nadal and Jean-Yves Geffroy.

Ensemble Studios was a game development studio based in Dallas, Texas (USA). It was established in 1995 by Tony Goodman, John Boog-Scott and Rick Goodman. Previously Tony Goodman had founded the information technology company Ensemble Corporation in 1991 together with John Boog-Scott, John Calhoun, and Thad Chapman. Ensemble Corporation was acquired by USWeb Corporation in 1997, Ensemble Studios was acquired by Microsoft in 2001. Ensemble Studios is most famous for having established the Age of Empires series of strategy games, which had seen installments for over ten years (1997-2007) under Ensemble's direction. In September 2008, it was confirmed Microsoft would shut down the studio following the release of Halo Wars in late February 2009, as a fiscally-rooted decision. In a leaked internal email from March 2021, Phil Spencer stated it was due to the studio "losing its passion". The closure of Ensemble led to the formation of many new development studios by former employees.  Tony Goodman, along with a number of veteran developers, announced in February 2009 to have founded the studio Robot Entertainment. A second team of about 35 developers announced to have founded Bonfire Studios (now Zynga Dallas) in the same month, headed by David Rippy. Dusty Monk established Windstorm Studios. The brothers Paul Bettner and David Bettner founded Newtoy, Inc. (now Zynga With Friends). The brothers Tommy Bean and Michael Bean established Pixelocity Software (after briefly working at Robot Entertainment) Jeff Ruediger co-founded the mobile game development studio Fuzzycube Software in March 2009. Graeme Devine established GRL Games in 2010.

Halo Studios, initially 343 Industries, is a game development studio based in Kirkland, Washington (USA). It was created as a subsidiary to Microsoft Game Studios in 2007 to handle the further development of the Halo franchise after Bungie became an independent company once again. The company's original name was a reference to 343 Guilty Spark, an AI in the Halo universe. 343's first project was Halo: Waypoint, launched in 2009 as an application for post-Halo: Reach games. It provides player statistics, updates and browsing enhancements. The next project that 343 worked on was Halo: Combat Evolved - Anniversary, an enhanced remake of the original Halo: Combat Evolved. In 2011, it was announced that 343 would be not only developing Halo 4, but also two further titles, which are said to make up The Reclaimer Trilogy, and would serve as a sequel trilogy to the first three Halo games. These would eventually become Halo 5: Guardians (2015) and Halo: Infinite (2021). The company would also handle the remastered versions of prior games ported to PC and newer Xbox consoles - Halo Wars: Definitive Edition and Halo: The Master Chief Collection. On 6 October 2024, the company was renamed to Halo Studios, despite already having a Halo reference in their original name, as part of a company restructure. On the same day, they unveiled their Project Foundry development testbed which uses Unreal Engine 5.

The two founding members of the two Finnish game companies Bloodhouse Ltd. and Terramarque Ltd. established Housemarque Ltd. in early 1995. Both companies had developed games for the Amiga previously. As PC game markets really started to emerge after the collapse of Amiga manufacturer Commodore in 1994, Housemarque was established in order to take advantage of the growing PC game markets. The company is headquartered in Helsinki, Finland. The studio started with the development of 3 PC CD-ROM titles: Super Stardust (1996), Alien Incident (1996) and The Reap (1997) from 1995 to the end of the fiscal year 1999. Although none of the games were commercial hits, they all received good reviews among the game press. Internationally distributed computer games were not the only products the company was doing. Other activities include the development of an on-line world called Con Quest, consulting for the Finnish National Lottery Company (Veikkaus) and small advertainment games. In early 1999 Housemarque signed a contract with Infogrames to develop Supreme Snowboarding (known as Boarder Zone in the US) for PC CD-ROM. Sights were set for the Christmas release. As the game had been in development well before signing a contract with Infogrames, their snowboarding game had already gained some reputation being one of the most visually stunning games around. For instance, 3DFX showed the game at their stand at E3 1998 in Atlanta. Supreme Snowboarding was also one of the few games presented at the official launch event of Pentium III processors in February 1999. Intel presented the game at the Game Developers Conference in March. After releasing TransWorld Snowboarding for the Xbox in 2002 as the sequel to Supreme Snowboarding the company released the snowboarding game Flo Boarding for Nokia's N-Gage in 2003, and started development on the internal technology for a PS2 title. In 2004 the karaoke game Staraoke was released for the PC. The following years more mobile games were released: The Chronicles of Narnia 3D (2005) for J2ME and BREW, and Gizmondo Motocross 2005 (2005) for Gizmondo. In 2007 they released Super Stardust HD as a downloadable game for the PlayStation 3, continuing its early series. Since then the company has mostly been focused on downloadable games for the Xbox 360 and PS3, such as Golf: Tee It Up! (2008), Super Stardust Portable (2008) for the PSP, Dead Nation (2010) and Outland (2011). In 2011 the studio made its first iOS game Furmins and three Angry Birds games were ported to the PS3 and Xbox 360 as Angry Birds Trilogy (2012). In 2014 Resogun was a launch game for the PlayStation 4 as a spiritual successor to the Super Stardust games. In March 2014 the 2010 title Dead Nation was released as an enhanced version for the PS4 as Dead Nation: Apocalypse Edition. Despite development for a wide range of platforms, the studio has always had close ties with the PlayStation console platform since the PS3 with exclusive titles such as Super Stardust HD (2007), Dead Nation (2010), Resogun (2013), Alienation (2016), Matterfall (2017) and Returnal (2021). On 29th June 2021 Sony announced the studio's acquisition as a first party developer part of the PlayStation Studios family.
Human Code, Inc. was a development studio founded in 1993. In 2000 the company was acquired by Sapient and a large part of the team then became part of Sapient Interactive.

Inertia Software (InertiaSoft Ltd) is an independent software development company founded in 2000. The company is based in near the city of Ely in the United Kingdom, and primarily develops games for the PC.

InstaLOD produces technology to automate workflows for 3D productions such as polygon optimization, remeshing, UV unwrapping, material merging, CAD to 3D conversions, baking and more. InstaLOD is part of the Abstract Group of companies.

Ladyluck Digital Media is located in Makati City, The Philippines. The company published and developed entire games for several years. Currently LadyLuck is mostly involved in creating game assets for other development companies.
Left Field Productions was an American development company founded on Jan 5, 1994 by Mike Lamb, Jeff Godfrey, and John Brandwood. The company owned the Impulse Games trademark.

column1: Marc Graue Voice Over Recording Studios

column2: Mercury Steam Entertainment S.L. is a game development studio based in San Sebastián de los Reyes, Madrid, Spain. It was founded by former members of Rebel Act Studios, and the team who established the company consisted of Raúl Rubio-Munárriz, Alberto Sendín, Carlos Rodríguez, Darío Halle, Emilio Gutiérrez, Enric Álvarez, Ignacio Navas, Mercé Salichs, Pablo Rubio and Rafael Jiménez The company debuted with American McGee presents SCRAPLAND. On 22nd December 2020 Nordisk Games announced the acquisition of a 40% stake in the company.
New Blood Interactive is a publishing company founded in 2014 by Aaron Alexander, Kreyg DeZago and Dave Oshry. The company specializes in retro-styled "boomer" shooters.
PIPE studio is a combined Russian/Ukrainian game development company.

Phosphor Games is a game development studio based in Chicago (USA). It was founded during 2009 by Chip Sineni. He previously worked at Midway Chicago along with many of the other Phosphor team members. When Midway was put up for sale in 2009 and Warner Bros. bought the Chicago studio, it was only really interested in continuing the Mortal Kombat franchise and everyone else not involved with that project was laid off. The team Sineni was involved with had been working on Hero since 2006, an open-world superhero game. They did a two-week crunch when rumours about Midway being up for sale were started to try and get a publisher interested, but eventually everything was put up for sale, including that IP. The Phosphor Games studio only had a physical office about a year after the lay-offs, but it still included many of the original Hero members. The project resurfaced at Phosphor as Project Awakened, but everything had to be redone from scratch as the IP and work could not be transferred. The studio's first post on its website was on 7th November 2009 and work on the title was announced in January 2011. Before that the studio had already done contract work for Kinect Adventures! (2010), Bulletstorm (2011) and Gears of War 3 (2011). Between 2011 and 2012 the studio released two mobile games: The Dark Meadow (2011) and Horn (2012). Both have a high production value and rely on the UnrealEngine3 3D engine for visuals.

Reality Pump Sp. z o.o. is a game development company located in Krakow, Poland. It was established in 2001 as a continuation of TopWare Programmy following the acquisition of a 51% stake in the company by ZUXXEZ Entertainment AG after the bankruptcy of TopWare CD-Service in February 2001. Next to Reality Pump, a part of TopWare Programmy was split off as Toontraxx. The roots of the company go back to the Polish development team MDF in the 1990s.  Initially continuing TopWare Programmy's success in the TopWare Earth series with Earth 2160 in 2005, the company is now best known for the Two Worlds RPG series.
Development team at Telenet Japan, successor of the earlier Reno team. In 1993 Riot was folded back into its mother company.

Headquartered in Andover, Massachusetts, the company was founded in 1999 as Mad Doc Software by Dr. Ian Lane Davis, an AI and gaming expert who began his career at Activision. In 2000, it was joined by part of the staff of the closed Looking Glass Studios. Since its inception, the company has completed Star Trek: Armada II, Jane's Combat Simulations: Attack Squadron, every Empire Earth title since The Art of Conquest and Dungeon Siege: Legends of Aranna, while also developing the Surround Light’ API for Boston-based Color Kinetics, a leader in high-tech full-spectrum lighting. In March 2008, they completed their reworking of Bully for the Xbox 360 as Bully: Scholarship Edition for Rockstar. In April of that year, the company was acquired by Rockstar Games and renamed Rockstar New England.

Bend Studio is an in-house Sony development studio located in Bend, Oregon. The original company was founded as Blank, Berlyn and Co in 1993 by Marc Blank (one of the authors of the original mainframe Zork in 1977) and Michael Berlyn, and then soon renamed to Eidetic. They first published productivity software, crossword puzzles and other word games for the Apple Newton, until they turned to Playstation titles in 1999 with Syphon Filter. In 2000, Eidetic became part of Sony and gained the informal name Sony Bend. Shortly thereafter the company was officially named Bend Studio. In 2005 it became part of the SCE Worldwide Studios group.

Schell Games is a full-service game design and development company, specializing in creating innovative interactive and transformational experiences. With its headquarters in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Schell Games was founded in 2002 by one of the world's top game designers and renowned author, Jesse Schell, and is made up of highly talented artists, programmers, producers, and game designers. Schell Games focuses on creating memorable experiences through online, mobile, and social games, interactive theme park attractions, console and handheld games, internet-enabled toys, and virtual worlds.

Vertigo Studios Amsterdam is a Dutch game development company located in Amsterdam, The Netherlands. It was founded in 2005 as Woedend! Games and changed its name to W!Games in 2007. It was established by Bas van Berkestijn with the help of Jan-Pieter van Seventer, Mike van der Voort, Marcel du Long and Harm van Dinter. In the fall of 2010 the company merged with game development studio Karami Games (lead by founders of Guerrilla Games) to become Vanguard. The company's first project was the Windows and Wii game My Horse & Me (2007). This was followed by Greed Corp. in 2010 and Gatling Gears in 2011. Both games are set in the Mistbound universe.

Warashi Inc. (株式会社 童) was established in August 1995 by Noriyuki Takasaki and a group of other former Athena staff. Their first title was the 1996 arcade shooter Shienryu, a spiritual successor to Athena's 1993 release Daioh. Though they mostly produced mahjong games and mobile software, they also made the occasional shooter, such as the 2006 release Triggerheart Exelica, which has been ported to the Dreamcast, Xbox 360, and PlayStation 2 since its original arcade release. The company's website has been inactive since 2011, and the current status of the company is unknown. Recom was started by former staff in 2007.
Wolverine Studios is a game development company founded in May 2006 by Gary Gorski.

Talbot, Inc. was established on June 5th, 2007.  The company's Representative Director and President, Ken Yoshioka's two-year-old son, randomly spouted 'Talbot' one day, which was how the company got the name.  The company's shark logo represents the company's values. In 2007, their website claimed they donate 1% of profits to their shark research activities. They worked on contributing to future titles created by Harvest Moon creator Yasuhiro Wada.  Some of Talbot's core staff, where long-term staff members from Victor Entertainment Co.

iBeta LLC is a quality assurance and testing company founded in July 1999 and located in Colorado (USA). The company also offers localization in many languages. In 2011 Glenn Kletzky is the company's President and Chief Executive Officer.

24 Bit Games is a game development studio based in Johannesburg, South Africa. It was founded in 2012 by CEO Luke Lamothe. They are focused on technical development using the Unity game engine, often porting games to additional platforms, providing co-development and optimization. On 16th November 2023 the studio's acquisition by Annapurna Games was announced. 24 Bit Games previously already handled co-development and porting for many titles published by Annapurna. It was Annapurna's first acquisition of a game studio.

Armature Studio is a game development studio located in Austin, Texas. It was originally founded in 2008 by Mark Pacini, Todd Keller and Jack Mathews, respectively former Game Director, Art Director and Principal Technology Engineer at Retro Studios, responsible for Nintendo's Metroid Prime franchise since 2000. Since its inception, Armature Studio has worked on numerous blockbuster video game franchises. including Borderlands, Metal Gear Solid and the Batman Arkham series. 2016 saw the release of ReCore, a project in conjunction with Keiji Inafune of Mega Man fame and Microsoft Studios; as well as Dead Star, an original IP, with Sony third party. On 11th October 2022 Meta announced the acquisition of the company.
Audio Network  is an international film, television and games music group with offices and music composers/artists in UK, Europe, United States, Canada and Australia.

Black Forest Games is a German game development studio based in Offenburg, Germany. Its existence was first announced in July 2012 and it was created as a new company after Spellbound Entertainment AG filed for insolvency in March 2012 after failing to close a round of investment. In July, along with the launch of the studio, CEO Andreas Speer said new funding and new resourced had been found. Out of the 65 people from Spellbound, 40 joined Black Forest according to Speer, with key creative and management members remaining. Its first game, Giana Sisters: Twisted Dreams, was released in October 2012 with the help of Kickstarter funding to complete development.

Brain In A Jar is an independent development company located in Cheshire, United Kingdom and founded in 1998 by Matthew Gabriel and Carl Darlton. The company specializes in racing simulations and has secured licenses for various platforms including Playstation 2, Nintendo Wii, Xbox, PC, and Xbox 360.

Chequered Ink Ltd. is an independent studio which develops both fonts and video games. It was founded in June 2015 in Bath, Great Britain, by Allison James and Daniel Johnston. As of 2022, they have created over 1,000 fonts.

This company legally represents Chris Sawyer, the creator of such games as Transport Tycoon and RollerCoaster Tycoon, both as a developer (until 2004, with brief returns for mobile ports) and a licensor of the two franchises to MicroProse/Infogrames/Atari (via Marjacq Limited representation).

Climax Entertainment is a Japanese video game development company based in Shinjuku, Tokyo. It was founded in April 1990 by Kan Naitoh, who left Chunsoft to establish a new company. Climax Entertainment is best known for Landstalker (1992) and other games that imitated its isometric action platforming gameplay.

G.rev Ltd. is a small independent Japanese development studio based in Yokohama, focused primarily on arcade games, and particularly known for scrolling shooters, although they have also created other games. The company, initially employing only 5 members, was formed from former employees of Taito's arcade division, who left in order to be able to continue pursuing the arcade market.  In addition to their independent works, they have also collaborated with fellow shooter developers Gulti and Treasure on games like Ikaruga and Gradius V.  The company's CEO and founder is Hiroyuki Maruyama and the original team consisted of people who have worked on Taito arcade shooters such as G Darius and Ray Storm. As of June, 2008, the company's size has grown to 11 employees.

Humming Bird Soft was a computer game-developing brand of its parent company MAC, based in Osaka (Japan). They are best known for their role-playing games such as the Deep Dungeon series and various adaptations of Record of Lodoss War. In some of their RPGs Western-style gameplay was incorporated into storylines of Japanese background and anime visual aesthetics.

Infinity Ward is a development studio based in the USA and founded by Grant Collier in 2001. The company has exclusively worked on the Call of Duty series, a line of warfare games. A part of the development team originally worked on Medal of Honor: Allied Assault at 2015, Inc.. Initially focused on PC titles, the series branched out to consoles with the release of Call of Duty 2 for the Xbox 360 in 2005. The studio is owned by Activision. In 2002 it acquired a 30% equity, and the remaining 70% was acquired in 2003. In the spring of 2010, a substantial amount of people left the company. It started as a conflict between Infinity Ward managers Vince Zampella and Jason West, and publisher Activision, over royalties for Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2. Both Zampella and West left the company, forming the development studio Respawn Entertainment. Other developers left as well, including lead designers Steve Fukuda and Zied Reike, programmer Rayme Vinson, lead artist Chris Cherubini and senior animator Bruce Ferris. In late April 2010, more developers were confirmed to have left the studio for Respawn: Mackey McCandlish, Jon Shiring, Todd Alderman, Rayme Vinson, Chris Cherubini, Mark Grisby and John Paul Messerly. In December 2017, the formation of the Polish division Infinity Ward Poland was announced. The studio was incorporated on 13 July 2018 and is led by Michał Drobot.

Introversion Software Limited, the self-proclaimed "The last of the bedroom programmers, the first of the children." is a video games development studio based in the United Kingdom. It was founded in June 2001 by Thomas Arundel, Chris Delay and Mark Morris, who met when they were undergraduates at Imperial College London. The company develops for personal computers and is best known for Uplink: Hacker Elite (2001), Darwinia series (2005-2010) and DEFCON series (2006-2017) and Prison Architect (2013).

KING Art is an independent game developer in Germany.  Since 2002 they have been pioneers in the area of extensive browser games, and have accumulated expert knowledge during the production of more than 30 successfully completed browser game projects. In 2008 they developed own adventure game engine, which was used for the production of The Book of Unwritten Tales and The Critter Chronicles. The Critter Chronicles is the prequel to The Book of Unwritten Tales. The Book of Unwritten Tales received rave reviews and became one of the best-selling adventure games in a decade. There was a 2,5 year gap between the German and the English release (April 2, 2009 vs. October 28, 2011). KING Art also did concept work, puzzle design and almost all dialogues for dtp’s Black Mirror 2. In 2013 KING Art Games ran a successful Kickstarter campaign for the turn-based strategy game Battle Worlds: Kronos. In 2014 they had another successful Kickstarter for The Book of Unwritten Tales 2. Currently they are working on the action-RPG game The Dwarves, which is based on the identically named bestselling novel by Markus Heitz. KING Art also produces browser games like My Free Zoo and Undermaster, with up to 10 million players worldwide.

Iridon Interactive is a producer of console and computer games based in Kungälv, Sweden. The company is carving a niche for itself by producing original action and arcade oriented titles for the value-priced market, and is currently developing for the Xbox’ video game system from Microsoft, Nintendo® Game Boy® Advance, and multimedia PCs. The company was originally conceived in June 1997 by current C.E.O. and Executive Producer, Björn Larsson. Iridon Interactive was formally incorporated as a publishing entity of computer games in February 1998. The company’s initial publishing endevours began with the concentration of producing and licensing of third-party titles from external development teams. At the time, Iridon was the first (and to date the only) Swedish company ever to enjoy a full publishing status membership of ELSPA. The head office in Sweden hosts a number of producers and creative personnel who manages both in-house and external development teams, hired temporarily for specific projects. This has been Iridon’s production model since day 1, not entirely unlike how the vast majority of movies are being produced in today's Hollywood. By utilizing territorial distribution and licensing partnerships across the world, Iridon titles are available in more than 36 countries including USA, Canada, Japan, Germany, France, Japan, UK, South Korea, Russia, Middle East, China, and India to name a few.  Publishing and distribution partners include Simon & Schuster, KOCH Media, Majesco Games, THQ, ValuSoft, GlobalStar Software (Take 2 Value), MicroMouse Co. Ltd., EcoFilmes SA, FriendWare SA, Sold-Out Software UK, HD Interactive, Mindscape, Nordic Softsales, EcoFilmes, ComGame 576, Play Poland, and Snowball Interactive.

Paragon Software Corporation, based in Greensburg, Pennsylvania, was founded in 1985 by Mark E. Seremet and F. J. Lennon. The company's biggest successes were titles based on licenses from Marvel Comics and Game Designers' Workshop. Paragon had a long relationship with MicroProse Software, who had distributed their games since at least 1988. MicroProse acquired Paragon outright in July, 1992. As part of MicroProse, the Paragon team developed Challenge of the Five Realms and BloodNet. Soon after, many of the former Paragon principals moved on to co-found or work for Take-Two Interactive, and what was once Paragon ceased to exist.

This company was started by John Miles. John developed the widely acclaimed Miles Sound System, technology which has been used in over 3,200 games. In 1995, the Miles Sound System was acquired by RAD Game Tools, and in 1998 John Miles joined them full time in their Kirkland, Washington, headquarters.

Namco Tales Studio was a Japanese development studio responsible for developing the Tales of... series of games for Namco (later Namco Bandai). The subsidiary was what remained from the original development house Wolf Team. When this subsidiary was formed in March 2003, 60% was owned by Namco, 34% was owned by Telenet Japan, and 6% was owned by Namco Tales Studio director Eiji Kikuchi. Since the merger of Namco and Bandai into Namco Bandai Holdings, the company bought out Telenet Japan's stake in this subsidiary, and owned 94% of the subsidiary. In November 2011 Namco Bandai announced to absorb the Namco Tales Studio into the main company on 1st January 2012.

Pink Noise Localization is a leading multimedia and video game localization provider in Spain.  Services for the Video Game industry include Localization, dubbing, locutions, subtitling and testing. Leading companies like Microsoft, Sony, Ubisoft, Jowood, Ncsoft, Square-Enix, Sega, Konami, among others,  have trusted Pink Noise for their localization and audio recording needs.

column1: Pole To Win Korea Co., Ltd.

column2: Realmforge Studios is a German development studio of which the formation was announced on 14th November 2008. It was launched by the publishing company Kalypso Media and the development studio Boxed Dreams, but it was largely funded by Kalypso Media which is also the majority shareholder. At its launch, Boxed Dreams was still completing its PC title Ceville, but the ten members of the development team were absorbed into the new studio. After the adventure game Ceville in 2009 the team released the quirky TV station management game M.U.D. TV: Mad Ugly Dirty Television in 2010. In 2011 a new franchise was launched with Dungeons, a dungeon management game similar to the Dungeon Keeper series, but with the goal of making the heroes happy. The series would continue on into the 2020s, and is still active. The studio would also revive the Startopia IP with Spacebase Startopia in 2021. Next to original development projects, the team contributed to other game productions, notably in the Patrician IV: Conquest by Trade, and has taken over post-launch maintenance and DLC development for Tropico 6 from Limbic Entertainment on 3 December 2020.

Riot Forge is a publishing label within and owned by Riot Games, Inc. that complements Riot’s research and development program. It is used for externally developed singleplayer games in the League of Legends universe. It was announced on 5 December 2019, and is scheduled to close after the release of Bandle Tale: A League of Legends Story.

Robot Entertainment is a game development studio that is comprised of a part of the team of the former Ensemble Studios. The formation was announced in February 2009. While they developed the final patches for Age of Empires III and its expansions, as well as Age of Empires Online, the studio is best known for its Orcs Must Die! series.

Imagexcel was a Canadian developer, active since the 1980s. In 1995, the company was acquired by Alternative Reality Technologies and was probably renamed to GameTek Canada. After ART was purchased by Take Two Interactive, it became an internal development division of Take Two Interactive Canada, Inc. and, starting in 1999, publicly called Rockstar Canada. In 2002, the public name was changed to Rockstar Toronto to avoid confusion with the Rockstar Vancouver. Sometime between 2004 and 2007 the division was incorporated as Rockstar Toronto, Inc. (although the entity was probably called Alternative Reality Technology, Inc. for some time) as subsidiary of Take Two Interactive Canada. In 2012, the company became Rockstar Games Toronto ULC.

Rocksteady Studios was founded in 2004, and is based in Finchley, North London. Prior to starting Rocksteady, Jamie Walker and Sefton Hill worked at Argonaut Games, one of the UK largest independent developers as creative director and head of production respectively. The company's first release was the action shooter Urban Chaos: Riot Response (2006). Their second title was Batman: Arkham Asylum, a third-person action game based on the Batman comics license. This was the start of the Arkham series of games. The studio was acquired by Time Warner in 2010, making them a subsidiary of Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment.
