RWS Studios LLC (the official abbreviation of Running with Scissors) is a North American game developer based in Tucson, Arizona. The company is led by Vince Desi and focuses on the development of the controversial Postal series.

Sega Sports Japan was an internal division of SEGA. There were several small development division operating within the company:  G9 Team Team Aquila Team Andromeda Team Vega  Around 1998, they were folded back into the main company and the names were no longer used. It operated as Sega Sports Design R&D for about four years, after Smilebit was merged back into Sega on July 1, 2004. Most recently, the staff is spread across the various consumer R&D divisions at Sega. Former head of the studio Takayuki Kawagoe moved up to the position of overseeing the majority of Sega's output on consumer devices.

Signal Space Lab Inc. is a studio based in Montréal, Quebec, specializing in immersive XR entertainment, video games, and audio production. It was established in 2014 by Jose Aguirre. Most likely the company is in some ways a successor to Wave Generation Inc. that specialized in audio and where Aguirre worked as Post Production Director. Possibly, the three founders David Lipes, Noémie Dupuy and Michael Elman focused more on their game development and publishing company Budge Studios Inc. they established in 2010 and Aguirre moved on to focus on audio at Signal Space.

Slipgate Ironworks, originally founded as Interceptor Entertainment is an independent game development studio based in Herning, Denmark and it was established in 2010. It was founded and is led by CEO and president Frederik Schreiber. Most of the team members have a background in indie games and modding and then got a job in the industry, at companies such as Sony Online Entertainment, Epic Games and Naughty Dog. The studio's first project was started as a mod called Duke Nukem 3D: Reloaded, a remake of Duke Nukem 3D. It originally started as a fan project, but through agreements with Gearbox Software, 3D Realms Entertainment and Apogee Software, Interceptor was eventually granted a personal non-commercial license to the Duke Nukem franchise. After the initial announcement in the fall of 2010, the game was put on hold in September 2011. Initially called Duke Nukem Next-Gen and in November 2010 officially Duke Nukem 3D: Reloaded, the game became standalone and would use Unreal Engine 3. In 2013, Schreiber spoke about the delay and stated that the game was put on hold because of the disappointing reception of Gearbox' title Duke Nukem Forever (2011). He stated that Reloaded was a better game and that showing or releasing it would destroy Forever's sales opportunities, which is why Gearbox had it put on hold. In 2013, the studio's first games were released. Working together with Apogee, Interceptor worked on ports for Duke Nukem (PC) and Duke Nukem II (PC/iOS). In July 2013 Rise of the Triad was released for PC, a remake of the 1994 first-person shooter Rise of the Triad: Dark War and maintaining the spirit of the original game. It was originally announced as Project Rogue. The team has another first-person shooter in development currently called Pathfinder. It is also based on an established franchise, but yet to be revealed. In February 2014, the first traces were revealed of Duke Nukem: Mass Destruction, a top-down action role-playing game. At the end of February, Gearbox (owner of the Duke Nukem IP) sued 3D Realms / Apogee Software Ltd. (creator of the Duke Nukem IP) over that game's development. The legal status is unknown, but in early March, Interceptor bought 3D Realms / Apogee Software Ltd. The company does not own the separate company Apogee Software LLC, which holds for instance the rights to Rise of the Triad, the franchise Interceptor developed a reboot for, as well as the rights to the name Apogee. The company filed for insolvency in December 2016 and was known as Slipgate Studios since April 2017. On 21 March 2019, they renamed themselves to Slipgate Ironworks to resolve confusion with a VR game studio of the same name, while John Romero agreed to give them the name and trademark of his former company Slipgate Ironworks (2006-2009).

Spellbound was founded by Armin Gessert in 1994 who was one of the three developers of the game The Great Giana Sisters (first released for the C64 in 1987). The Spellbound team initially produced graphics for the company Attic and thus took part in the creation of the role-playing game "Das schwarze Auge III" ("The Black Eye III"). This collaboration led to a commission from the company Fantasy Productions. They were to develop a game for the most successful series of German science fiction novels "Perry Rhodan" of Pabel publishing house. Spellbound’s first title was a strategy game called Perry Rhodan: Operation Eastside released in 1998 under the label Fantasy Productions. The Games The first game completely developed by the company on her own was the economic simulation Airline Tycoon. Infogrames (ATARI) published the title in 1997. The game never actually managed to enter the top ten, but it turned out to be a successful long seller in various territories and can still be found among budget titles in stores. In 1998 Airline Tycoon First Class came out, followed by Airline Tycoon Evolution in 2002; both of these add-ons were distributed by Monte Cristo. In 2003 the last add-on for the time being was introduced: Airline Tycoon Deluxe. In December 1998 the Spellbound team began with the development of their second original game. It was designed to be a real time strategy game and was supposed to take place in a location, which at that time had not been exploited in computer games to a large extent before: The Wild West. The game was called Desperados: Wanted Dead or Alive and it turned out to be Spellbound’s biggest success and most critically acclaimed title so far. The game received praise from the press for its AI and an innovation called "Quick Actions" which allowed the player to plan their moves in advance. Just like the first part of "Airline Tycoon", "Desperados" was distributed by Infogrames (ATARI). In 2001 it was at the top of the game ratings (charts) in some countries for several weeks. The game’s cinematics won the "Animago award" in 2001 and the game itself is still ranked second in the "all-time-best-list" of the German magazine "PC-Games" in the category for strategy games. An expansion to "Desperados" featuring new locations and characters was supposed to follow but was not released due to reasons which have not been completely uncovered up to today. Supposedly, there were company politics involved on publisher Infogrames’ side which involved budget and market focus. Ever since, some fans of "Desperados" have been waiting and yearning for an add-on or a sequel to the game. Another term that is often mentioned in this context is the so-called "Webisodes". These were additional levels Spellbound had planned to release via their website – possibly instead of a full-size add-on – to allow players of "Desperados" to continue the gaming experience. Due to the success of "Desperados", Spellbound was able to expand its team. To be able to ensure a smooth game production with the increased team, the company introduced a form of "Extreme Programming" (a.k.a. "XP") to the development process in 2001, which was adjusted to the needs of game production. This "XP" process was introduced by technical director Stéphane Becker. The first game created using these new methods was Robin Hood: Die Legende von Sherwood ("Robin Hood: The Legend of Sherwood"). "Robin Hood" was produced in cooperation with the French publisher Wanadoo Edition, today known as MC2.  For "Robin Hood" the Spellbound team refined the techniques which had been developed for "Desperados". The 2D-engine "Desperados" had used was improved and a new system of compression for sprites was introduced. All sprites were equipped with dynamic lighting processes and the "Quick Actions" were extended considerably. "Robin Hood" was released in 2002. The game achieved top scores of up to 96% (Gen 4) in the press. "Robin Hood" could also repeat the success of "Desperados", in particular because of its cinematics which won the "Animago Award" as well. In 2003 Spellbound Entertainment Ltd. expanded its product range by two more genres. The company published its first action adventure with Chicago 1930 and its first shooter with Rauchende Colts ("Smoking Colts"). By releasing "Rauchende Colts" Spellbound entered the market segment of low budget games.  Additionally Spellbound Entertainment Ltd. appeared as publisher of its own products for the first time by releasing "Rauchende Colts" and "Airline Tycoon Deluxe" in 2003. Both the company and the press were not pleased with the game "Chicago 1930". It did not meet the former’s expectations in sales. As a consequence, Spellbound released a large portion of the team who worked on the title. The core team of the original "Desperados" stayed with the company. Among the employees who were laid off were Stéphane Becker, Jean-Michel Stenger and Martin Kuppe who went on to found a new company in Strasburg called Creative Patterns which employed most of the original "Desperados" team members.  In 2003, Spellbound began production of its first 3D real-time game, the sequel to "Desperados". Featuring an all new 3D engine, two perspectives (isometric and third person), a new character as well as new abilities for all heroes and new Western sets and developed by a new team, Desperados 2: Cooper’s Revenge was longingly awaited by fans of the original. Published by ATARI, the game was released in Germany on April 27th 2006.  Right after the completion of Desperados 2: Cooper’s Revenge production of an add-on titled "Desperados 2: Conspiracies" began. Shortly before production was complete, publisher Atari pulled out and left the team stranded with an almost finished game. Just like the add-on of its predecessor, the Desperados 2 Add-on was threatened to be never released despite being nearly complete. Luckily, Spellbound found a new publisher in Russia, Noviy Disk. Finally, German publisher digital tainment pool (dtp) brought the game to Germany and released it under their Anaconda label on June 6th, 2007. The Location   Located in the city of Kehl am Rhein in the state Baden-Württemberg in south-western Germany, Spellbound has always had a history of being a French-German developer. With the French city of Strasburg being right across the river Rhein opposite to Kehl the company could always employ people from both countries with both their individual and cultural backgrounds. It is that cultural diversity which the company believes has always proven to be advantageous for game development. In 2011, the company moved to Offenburg to make room for their extended personell (40 to 120). Legacy   A number of employees (Stéphane Becker, Jean-Michel Stenger and Martin Kuppe) left the company in 2004 to found the French game development studio Creative Patterns. They eventually took along artists Isabelle Gadbled and Fabrice Weiss, and game designer Vincent Lalyman. Closure   In February 2012, the company founded the subsidiary Spellbound Entertainment GmbH in Berlin which was supposed to develop browser and mobile games. However, in March 2012 Spellbound Entertainment AG had to file for insolvency and was closed in July 2012. The majority of the remaining staff joined Black Forest Games, founded by former Spellbound key personnel.

Having worked on Quake 3 Fortress and other high-profile mods, Splash Damage, Ltd emerged from the amateur scene and was established in May or June 2001, originally to create custom content. The company partnered with id Software and Activision, creating additional art for Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Tides of War. The company started working on the multiplayer part of Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory, a commercial expansion pack to Return to Castle Wolfenstein. Eventually, it was decided to cancel the single-player portion and put out the multiplayer part for free. It became a successful online class-based team game and was used in many leagues. Next, Splash Damage did the multiplayer design in the Xbox version of Doom³ and in 2007 they finished Enemy Territory: Quake Wars, the spiritual successor to Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory but now set in the Quake universe. In the 2010s, they developed Brink, the multiplayer portion of Batman: Arkham Origins, Dirty Bomb and did additional development in the Gears of War series. In the 2020s, they released console ports of Maneater and contributed to The Expanse: A Telltale Series.

Trinigy GmbH is an internationally oriented, independent company focusing on the development of advanced 3D graphics technology with its headquarters based in Eningen, Germany. The company was founded in 2003 by Dag Frommhold and Florian Born. Its North American office, Trinigy, Inc. is located in Austin, Texas, and was opened in August 2007. It serves as a Sales and Technical Support Center and caters to the needs of development studios and publishers in the US and Canada.

Two Tribes is a company based in The Netherlands and has been operating since 2000. The studio develops for a wide range of platforms, such as Game Boy Color, Nintendo DS(i), Wii, Windows, Macintosh, N-Gage and mobile phones. Two Tribes has created a number of original titles, starting with Toki Tori in 2001, as well as ports of existing titles to new platforms.

UDS, Unique Development Studios AB, is an interactive entertainment developer with offices in Norrköping, Sweden (HQ), Gothenburg, Sweden and London, UK. The company was founded in 1993, now developing on Microsoft Xbox, Sony PlayStation 2 and PSone, PC, Nintendo Gamecube and Gameboy Advance platforms. In 1999, UDS opened up its Gothenburg office, home to online division GlobalFun as well as further core games development. September 2000 saw UDS acquire London-based developer, King Of The Jungle, to increase its access to the British development community. Today we are 80 full-time employees, all of which are among the best in their respective fields. We utilise a combination of own cutting-edge technologies and middleware. Our publishing partners have included Sony Computer Entertainment Europe, Acclaim, Infogrames, EIDOS, Codemasters, Mattel and many other industry leaders. UDS also has good relationships with the world of Hollywood, working closely with the likes of Fox Interactive on a number of licensed properties. Here at UDS, we recognise the interactive entertainment industry is the most fun, challenging and rewarding business you can be in. And we think our games illustrate that belief. (Source: http://www.uds.se/company/)

Unknown Worlds Entertainment, Inc. is an independent game company founded in May 2001 by Charlie Cleveland in San Francisco, California (USA). The team consists of Charlie Cleveland (Game Director), Max McGuire (Technical Director), Cory Strader (Art Director) and Matt Regan (Artist). The company mostly works on games behind the scenes developing technology and tools, design and artwork, the first of which was Natural Selection released in 2002. The sequel, Natural Selection 2 (NS2), is currently in the development stages.

column1: Warner Home Video México S.A. de C.V.

column2: ZyX is the adult brand of Contents Traffic. They debuted in 1994 and have been mostly focusing on Japanese-style adventure games and visual novels.
Established on 4 January 1994, Étranges Libellules (also known as ELB) was a French-based multiplatform publisher and developer. They were closed on 28 June 2012.

Asylum Entertainment is an experienced and award winning video game developer based primarily in the major brand name children’s market. Asylum has completed over 20 titles on multiple platforms for some of the biggest and best publishers and licence holders in the world including EA, Riverdeep, Vivendi, BBCW and Cartoon Network. Asylum uses a number of leading edge technologies and develops for all gaming platforms, currently focused on developing for Online PC, NDS, Xbox 360 and PS3. Asylum is passionate about its work and always aims to surpass client expectations.

Backflip Studios was a mobile game development studio started by Julian Farrior, a former Yahoo executive, in 2009. It was based in Boulder, Colorada (USA). In 2013 toy and entertainment company Hasbro bought a 70% stake for $112 million. On 25th October 2019 Hasbro confirmed the studio's closure.

Blade Interactive Studios is the future of gaming Blade is a developer of innovative, state-of-the-art, interactive computer games designed with you in mind. The driving force, creativity and experience, coupled with a desire to continually push back the boundaries of technology, provide the building blocks for excellence.  Our focus is the creation of original products. At Blade we are constantly striving for perfection, to provide that edge that makes the difference between a good game and one that is truly outstanding.  Our teams comprise of some of the most talented individuals in the industry. Many have more than 15 years experience, with skill sets that span the entire spectrum of computer and console formats, and in-depth hands-on knowledge of multiple game genres, from racing, platform and role-playing through to sports simulations.  History Blade was founded in 1998 by a group of industry veterans with a goal of creating some of the most technically advanced computer games for the next generation hardware and to establish new, high-quality, high-visibility brands, games that you can't put down.  With that philosophy and a strong physics bias to the company and the desire to create our own little FIFA we developed the very successful Snooker simulations, World Championship Snooker (published by Codemasters). Building on the success of both the PS and PS2 versions, we are now creating further versions, which will simply blow you away!  Source: Selected articles from Blade Interactive Official Company Website - Corporate - Company Profile http://www.bladeinteractive.com
Germany's Federal Ministry of Economic Affairs and Energy, which was over the course of the Federal Republic of Germany merged with other ministries at certain times.

Climax was the first and main development division of The Climax Group, with work dating back as far as 1996. The company originally worked under the name Climax and in 1999 the entire office was moved to Fareham. As the company then expanded with more divisions, the name Climax Fareham was soon introduced for all work done at that location. On 1st July 2002, the business relocated to the Gunwharf Quays in Portsmouth and was renamed Climax Solent. The division has been responsible for the development of Sudeki and Serious Sam: Next Encounter, and took over development of Silent Hill: 0rigins in 2007 when Climax LA closed down. In November 2004, the company became part of the Climax Action brand. By the summer of 2006, the main company stated that it wanted to change Climax into a one location, one studio developer with a single management team and this was achieved by early 2007 when most of the team moved on to the Portsmouth. By January 2008, the Kingston office where Climax London and Climax Handheld Games used to be housed, was closed. Climax Solent then returned to the state it was in almost ten years before: the single operating development division of the Climax Group, but now operating as Climax Action.
Fat Bard LLC is the company of audio duo Zach Fendelman and Patrick Crecelius.

Kuju London, established in 2000, is a regional development studio of Kuju Entertainment Ltd. Since February 2008 it is lead by Bradley Crooks. On 29th July 2008 the company was renamed Headstrong Games.

Intac Co., Ltd. (short for International Translation Center) is a localization and translation company based in Tokyo, Japan, and founded in May 1991. The company expanded and opened other offices in several locations including:* Intac (UK) Co.  Limited - London, England (opened Sept. 2000) * Intac Vision Inc. - Bangkok, Thailand (opened Aug. 2002) * Intac Vision Singapore Pte Ltd * Intac (Shanghai) Co., Ltd. - Shanghai, China
Ketchapp is a French mobile publishing company. On 27 September 2016, Ubisoft announced the acquisition of the company.

Kheops Studio is a video game development company established in September of 2003 in Paris, France, and co-founded by Benoît Hozjan and Stéphane Petit. The company is best known for their PC adventure games which contain historical and cultural themes and elements. The company's latest project is the episodic adventure The Fall Trilogy. The first, Chapter 1 - Separation was released in December 2009. The final two chapters are in development with expected release in 2010. The company was closed circa January 2012

Media Station, Inc. was a developer of various educational computer games. Their best-known games are the Disney's Animated Storybook series of interactive storybook games similar to the Living Books series (in which the company actually made an entry) but based on famous animated films.
Microids Indie is a publishing label of Microids SA (previously known as Anuman Interactive SA) for independently developed games. It was launched in November 2016.

Oxford Digital Enterprises Ltd., also known as ODE, was a software development studio founded in 1983 by David Pringle when he met Gareth Blower while working on mainframe computers. Their first program was called Macbeth and based on the play by William Shakespeare. Their first popular game was Titanic: The Recovery Mission, released in April 1986 by Electric Dreams Software and they also did Trivial Pursuit for Domark in the same year. In 1993 Oxford Digital was acquired by Empire Interactive Europe Ltd. and became Empire Oxford, an internal Empire studio. The new team included all of ODE's employees.

Paws, Inc. was established in 1981 by American cartoonist Jim Davis as an outlet for licensing characters from his Garfield comic strip for various merchandise, which had become very lucrative. In 1994, Paws, Inc. acquired the rights to Garfield from United Features Syndicate, which had syndicated the strip since its inception in 1978, and began producing it with Universal Press Syndicate (now Universal Uclick) distributing. Paws, Inc. is headquartered in Albany, IN, and today continues to produce the Garfield strip and license the character for merchandise (including, of course, video games). In 2019, Paws, Inc. was acquired by Viacom.
Retrospec is a team of coders, graphics artists and computer musicians who have gathered together to create remakes of old 8 bit games and new original games with a decidedly retro feel.

Creative Assembly Sofia is a development studio owned by SEGA and a division of Creative Assembly studio. It is based in Sofia, Bulgaria. The company was initially founded in 2001 as Black Sea Studios by Vesselin Handjiev (aka Frujin). Notable titles Black Sea developed include Knights of Honor (2004) and WorldShift (2008). On 14 July 2008, Black Sea Studios was acquired by Crytek and renamed Crytek Black Sea. Crytek announced to close the studio on 20 December 2016. On 7 March 2017, the studio's acquisition by SEGA was announced, after which it was positioned as a division of Creative Assembly. Also in 2016, some former developers of this studio would establish Black Sea Games, also in Sofia. The two are not to be confused.
A joint shareholder-ship by QubicGames S.A. and PlayWay S.A. plus other minor shareholders for publication of games primarily on the Switch.

Sidhe Interactive is a game development studio founded in 1997 in New Zealand. The company is an officially licensed developer for Microsoft (Xbox, Xbox 360), Sony Computer Entertainment Europe (PSOne, PS2, PSP, PS3), Nintendo of America (GBA, DS, Wii), and Apple (iPhone, iPod Touch). It is also a co-founding member of the New Zealand Game Developers Association and the New Zealand Institute of Screen Innovation. The company is officially registered as Prodigy Design Limited.

Sigma Team is an independent company headquartered in Novosibirsk, Russia, which publishes its own products worldwide. Founded in 2003, their activity is developing and publishing computer games. The company has partners in more than 10 countries including Germany, Italy, Poland, and Czechia. Sigma Team also cooperates with many online game portals ­– MSN Games, Yahoo Games, Shockwave among them.

Sim-wings was founded in 1999 by German developer Thorsten Loth. Later in 2000 Manfred Spatz joined the team. Sim-Wings is effectively a brand name, not a company, under which a team of developers headed by Thorsten release add-ons for flight simulators. Ibiza for FS2000 was the first title released by Sim-Wings.

Stern Electronics was formed in 1977 when Sam Stern purchased a pinball and arcade game company called Chicago Coin. Stern entered the video arcade game business in 1980 with the release of Astro Invader, which they licensed from Leijac (Konami). Berzerk, their second release and first original, became a major success. Stern produced few original arcade games, but licensed several games from foreign companies such as Konami (Scramble, Super Cobra and Pooyan) and Valadon Automation (Bagman and Super Bagman), which they manufactured and distributed in the United States. Stern was hit hard by the great video game crash of 1983-84, and in 1985 they left the arcade game business and sold their pinball division to Data East. In 1996, Data East sold their pinball division to Sega. In 1999, Sega decided to exit the pinball industry as well and sold their pinball division to Gary Stern, son of Sam Stern. Gary Stern reestablished Stern as a pinball company, and since that time, the company has been the sole remaining manufacturer of pinball machines in the world.

Founded in January 1995, Related Designs originally focused on developing medium priced games as well as advertising and online games. The experience gained in the production of a number of smaller titles led to the development of the company's biggest success - the real-time strategy game A*M*E*R*I*C*A, developed for the German publisher Data Becker. The game was listed for eight continuous months in the German Media Control PC games charts with the best position attained in February 2001. In March 2001 "America" was voted "Game of the month" by Germany's largest computer game magazine "Computerbild-Spiele". Having sold more than 250.000 copies worldwide the game marked the company's entry into the segment of full price PC games. The next titles released in 2003 were two real-time strategy games: Castle Strike, in which the player controls one of three tribes in medieval times, and No Man's Land, which features 300 years of history of North America, both of which underlined the focus of Related Designs to producing real-time strategy titles. As of 2006, they have handled the Anno / A.D. series of games. Ubisoft Entertainment acquired a 30% share of the company in April 2007 and became the company's exclusive publisher. They would fully acquire the studio on 11 April 2013. In 2014, the company was renamed to Blue Byte Mainz, and would work closely with Blue Byte's main Düsseldorf studio.

The company name Williams Electronics, Inc. was used since at least 1967 on flyers for electro-mechanic arcade machines. It is unknown to what exact entity this refers to as Williams Electronics, Inc. was incorporated in 1974 (Illinois). This may originate from the purchase of Williams Manufacturing by Seeburg Corporation in 1964. The name was changed to WMS Industries Inc. in 1987, shortly after Williams Electronic Games Inc. was formed to take over the arcade and pinball business. WMS Industries and Williams Electronic Games Inc. made headline news with their $8 million acquisition of Bally Midway Manufacturing Co., Inc. in 1988. The purchase included all of Bally Midway's coin-operated amusement game manufacturing business. More importantly for the videogame industry, it also included Midway, which had become very successful in the development of coin-operated arcade games as well as videogames. Midway Manufacturing Company  was incorporated and added to the WMS group of subsidiaries at this time. In 1992, Williams began to manufacture pinball machines with the Bally name after acquiring the exclusive name rights. In 1994, WMS Industry purchased Tradewest and formed Williams Entertainment Inc. which published, developed and distributed their own unique games as well as those made by their fellow subsidiary Midway Games. Then in 1996 WMS Industries acquired Time-Warner Interactive Inc., which included Atari Games. It is believed that this purchase kick-started the 1996 formation of Midway Home Entertainment Inc., a division of Midway Games Inc.  Williams Entertainment Inc. was merged into the new corporation and an Atari Games Division was formed. In 1998 Midway Games Inc. was spun off and sold to its stockholders to become independently owned and operated. In Oct. 1999, WMS Industries announced to shut down all pinball operations and the Atari Games division to focus on slot machine development.

SoftLab Laboratories was founded in 1988 by pioneer adventure game developer William R. Fisher III. Bill Fisher developed and released his first independent, shareware game, Last Half of Darkness, for MS-DOS in 1989. SoftLab released several other games in the early 1990s including The Nine Lives of Secret Agent Kat, an RPG/adventure with an espionage plot. The company was called William R. Fisher III Studios in 1994 when the game The Romantic Blue was commercially released on CD-ROM (published by CrystalVision Software). Also released that year was the shareware game Death by Dark Shadows. In 2000, an updated version of Last Half of Darkness was released for Windows on CD-ROM, developed and published by WRF Studios. The company continues to develop and publish games in the Last Half of Darkness franchise.

column1: Yash Future Tech Solutions Pvt Ltd

column2: keen games is a German development studio founded in 2005 by Antony Christoulakis, Jan Jöckel and Peter Thierolf. They were the remaining three of six founders of the German studio NEON Software GmbH when it was shut down at the end of 2005 because of the owner JoWooD Entertainment AG's financial difficulties. The keen games management then purchased the rights to most of the old NEON games as well as the NEON name, making it the spiritual successor. The studio continued its work on licensed titles such as Dance Dance Revolution: Disney Channel Edition (2008), What's Cooking? Jamie Oliver (2008), and G-Force (2009), but also created or contributed to very different types of titles such as Anno 1701: Dawn of Discovery (2007), Dawn of Discovery (2009) and Sacred 3 (2014). On 18th April 2012 Keen Flare GmbH was announced, a joint subsidiary between keen games and mobile games developer and publisher Flaregames GmbH to develop mobile games. Keen games holds an 49% interest, flaregames 51%.
Amanita Design is an independent game  development studio founded in 2003 by Jakub Dvorsky. The company creates flash games, films and animations.

Bihou Co., Ltd. was founded in 1993 and is specialized in creating background art for anime television series and movies, but are also involved in video games. In some cases they are credited under the names Studio Bihou or Bihou, Inc.
As of February 2020, the company has become a publishing label for Baltoro Games Sp. z o.o.
Founded in 1998, Coresoft is a video game developer based in Lake Forest, California.

Don't Nod Entertainment SARL, doing business as DONTNOD Entertainment, is a Paris based independent video game studio founded in August 2008 by Hervé Bonin, Aleksi Briclot, Alain Damasio, Oskar Guilbert and Jean-Maxime Moris. In 2008 the studio won the French Innovative Companies Competition prize for its 3D real-time fluid simulation technology.

Delphine Software International (DSI) developed computer and video games between 1988 and 2004. Delphine Software International game designs and developments are lead by Paul Cuisset until Motoracer. Then, two games were developed in parallel by two internal teams. DSI was based in Paris, near the Champs-Élysées until the year 2001. They then moved to St Ouen, near Paris. Delphine Software International belonged to the Delphine Group until Dec 2002. Doki Denki then bought the company, and closed it in 2004.
Dogenzaka Lab is a label of D3Publisher Inc. which develops and publishes visual novels.

Exigent Game Art Pvt. Ltd. is an art outsourcing company based in India and a division of Exigent Global Inc.. For its work the studio often cooperates with the Chinese division Exigent Computer Software (Shanghai) Inc.

Thorsten Knop, Thomas Friedmann and Thomas Häuser founded the German development company Funatics Development GmbH in 1998. In 2000 it was acquired for 75% by Phenomedia, but when that company filed for insolvency in May 2002, Funatics had to follow suit and soon all staff was laid off and operations shut down. The company resurfaced in September of the same year, but then with the name Funatics Software GmbH for legal reasons following the insolvency.

Images Software Ltd. was a game development studio established circa 1988 by Karl Jeffrey. It is known for classic titles as Back to the Future Part II, Bubsy II, and The Hunt for Red October, as well as ports of many games. The studio initially developed for Activision, with ports of Wonder Boy in Monster Land for instance, but later they also worked for Ocean and US Gold (e.g. porting G-Loc Air Battle). Initially focusing on Amiga, Atari ST and ZX Spectrum, Images later moved on to the Game Boy, NES and SNES. The company has close ties to The Climax Group, also founded by Karl Jeffery, and may be linked to Images' desire to publish its own games. After 1994 no new products appeared, and most likely the company was continued as The Climax Group.

Just1337 Studio is a small game development studio founded in Croatia in 2015 by Jurica Šinko, after the success of his Steam key reseller KupiKey. Their first game was the space shooter ShipLord, which was released near the end of 2015 after successfully passing through Steam Greenlight.
Limbic Entertainment GmbH is a German game development studio established in 2002 by Stephan Winter and Alexander Frey.

MachineGames is a Uppsala, Sweden based developer founded in 2009 by seven former members of Starbreeze Studios. In 2010 the company was acquired by Zenimax Media Inc.. It was also announced that the company was working on a AAA title powered by the id Tech 5 engine by id Software.  On 6 February 2013, a resume hinted at a new Wolfenstein game, and on 7 May 2013, the game was officially announced as Wolfenstein: The New Order. It was released in May 2014. MachineGames would continue creating games in that franchise instead of id Software. They would assist the latter in the rebooted Doom games, as well as create additional episodes for the  enhanced versions of Quake (2021), Quake II (2023) and Doom + Doom II (2024).

Mediatonic is a game development studio that creates browser-based and casual games. One of the co-founders is Paul Croft. In 2020, a parent company was founded, Tonic Games Group. On 2 March 2021, Epic Games acquired Tonic Games and Mediatonic.
Russian licensed developer of games for the platforms Nintendo DS, Nintendo Wii, PSP, iPhone.

Molleindustria (literally "loose industry") is a team of Italian artists, designers and programmers who create free, controversial games to fuel the discussion about social and political implications of videogames. Their titles include Orgasm Simulator, Enduring Indymedia, Queer Power, McDonald's Video Game, Operation: Pedopriest, Faith Fighter.

New Frontier was a Spanish game development studio active from around 1989 to 1993 and known for its many ports for the MSX, ZX Spectrum and Game Boy platforms. Known members include Isidro Gilabert ("Zydro" - programming), Dabyd Herrero ("Dabyd" - programming), Kevin Fustor ("Fustor" - graphics/music), Ruben Gomez ("Robin" - graphics) and Alberto Jose Gonzalez ("MC Alby" - music), along with an unidentified music designer known as "medi". In 1993 Isidro Gilabert founded the development studio Bit Managers and that was the end of New Frontier. Most members appear to have gone along with him, except for Kevin Fustor and Dabyd Herrero who have no further credits beyond the New Frontier games.

NDCube Co., Ltd. is a Japanese game development studio founded on 1 March 2000 as a joint venture between Nintendo and Dentsu, a Japanese advertising company. Since 2010, the company has been a fully owned subsidiary of Nintendo.  In later years, the company has been best known for developing games in the Mario Party and Wii Party series. A large number of employees have a background at Hudson Soft Company, the previous developer of the Mario Party series.  The company's offices are located in Tokyo and Sapporo.
PixQuake is a game development studio based in Belgrade, Serbia. It is established and owned by  Svetislav Jevtić.

column1: Pole To Win Shanghai Co., Ltd.

column2: Pyramid is a Japanese game developer based in Shinjuku, Tokyo. It was founded in September 2001 by Atsushi Ii.

Péndulo Studios is a game development studio founded in 1994 in Madrid, Spain by Rafael Latiegui, Ramón Hernáez and Felipe Gómez Pinilla. The company is known for creating 2D point-and-click adventure games. Péndulo's first title was Igor: Objective Uikokahonia (1994) followed by Hollywood Monsters (1997). At a time when other companies were turning away from adventure games, the studio had its international breakthrough success with Runaway: A Road Adventure (2001), which would eventually form a trilogy with Runaway 2: The Dream of the Turtle (2006) and Runaway: A Twist of Fate (2009). The second title was also the first in the series to be taken to other platforms aside from Windows: the Wii and the Nintendo DS. That experiment was however not repeated for the titles afterwards. After finishing the Runaway trilogy, Péndulo revisited its second game Hollywood Monsters with the sequel The Next Big Thing (2011). The team released Yesterday in March 2012. It was their first game that moved away from the typical quirky characters and humour Péndulo is known for. It has a much more darker atmosphere and a twisted plot. In 2019 Blacksad: Under the Skin was released, the company's first title to use 3D visuals.

Redsteam is an art studio founded by Arthur Hugot, global art director at Gameloft in 2009. The studio was originally based in Shanghai but has since moved to Singapore. As an internal studio of Gameloft it produces pre-production assets such as concept art, environment designs, illustrations and 3D models for many of the company's games.
Sanzaru Games Inc. is a California, USA based company founded in January 2007 by seven former Activision developers. One of these is Glen Egan, currently CEO of the company.

Software House Parsley (ソフトウェアハウスぱせり) is (alongside U・Me Soft) an adult brand of a company otherwise known as Square and based in Kanazawa, Japan. It has no relation to the better-known company with the same name. Parsley is best known to Western audiences for its dating simulation game with RPG elements, True Love (1995). Parsley debuted with Celery (1989) and has developed games in various genres, primarily for the PC-98 system. Its longest-running series, however, is the RPG franchise Mugen no Meikyū, which debuted on the Windows platform.

Studio Mühl is a localization, translation and recording company owned and founded in Germany by Ulrich Mühl. The company specializes in translating from English to other languages and from German to English. The company was still operating in 2007.

Twisted Pixel Games, LLC is a game development studio founded in 2006 by Frank Wilson, Josh Bear and Michael Wilford. The studio's first title, The Maw, was released in early 2009 for Windows and as an XBLA game on the Xbox 360. On 12 October 2011, the company announced to have been acquired by Microsoft Game Studios. On 30 September 2015, the company became independent again. On 11 October 2022, Meta announced the acquisition of the company.
Founded in Jan 2006, Unico Inc. (有限会社ウニコ) is a Japanese development company involved in the planning and production of computer software.

Virtools was a French software development company, creators of the Virtools Dev engine (a.k.a. NeMo). The engine was used for video games, live performances, car manufacturing and movie pre-production from late 1990s to mid-2010s, and was widely recognized as having spearheaded visual scripting and fast prototyping. The company worldwide headquarters was located in Paris, France. Other regional headquarters were located in Montreal, Canada; Woodland Hills, California; and Tokyo, Japan.
Virtuos Xi'An is a division of Virtuos Ltd. and it is based in Xi An, China.

Vision Software was a game development studio based in New Zealand. It was founded as Art Computer Software in 1989 by Paul Andrews, Cameron McKechnie, Rodney Smith and Mark Sibly. The name was changed to Vision Software in 1991. They had a tight relationship with fellow New Zeeland software company Acid Software, formed by Mark Sibly in the early nineties. The studio made two Amiga games for CRL Group PLC: Sirius 7 (1990) and Sorceror's Apprentice (1990), but did not receive any money for it for CRL.

Turbine is a game development studio founded in 1994 and based in the USA. Its focus is on MMORPGs, with titles such as Asheron's Call, Dungeons & Dragons Online and The Lord of the Rings Online. On 20 April 2010, Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment announced to have acquired the company. In December 2016, its MMO team branched off to create Standing Stone Games and continue the maintenance and development of Dungeons & Dragons Online and The Lord of the Rings Online. In November 2018, the company was renamed to WB Games Boston.

Buzz Monkey Software, LLC was founded in 2001 by four senior Dynamix employees: Randy Thompson, Jon Milnes, Steve Cordon and Barry Drew. The company offers full game development, ports, and consulting for current- and next-generation consoles. They also have experience with online games and emerging technologies such as SpeedTree foliage generation software, Novodex physics engine/hardware, and the Image Metrics facial motion-capture system. Since June 2012, the studio belongs to Zynga and was renamd to Zynga Eugène.

1518 Studios is a video games and tech services outsourcing company involved with art, end-end game development, live ops, porting, product development, and staff augmentation. It is based in California, USA. Its formation was announced on 11th February 2021 when Pole To Win announced the acquisition of the art outsourcing studio 5518 Studios, merging it with their game development brand Orange Rock under the new company 1518 Studios. It is led by Kasturi Rangan, previously CEO at Orange Rock.

5TH Cell Media LLC was founded in 2003 by industry veterans Joseph M Tringali, Jeremiah Slaczka and Brett Caird. The company is an authorized developer for the Nintendo DS and Nintendo Wii. Before that, the company created both original and licensed games for mobile platforms, as well as casual PC games. The company's studio is currently located in Bellevue, Washington.
APC&TCP is an old German computer club turned publisher, now the major publisher in the Amiga market. It has close ties to the German Amiga magazine Amiga Future.

Animation Magic was a software company founded in Gaithersburg, Maryland by Dale DeSharone after he left Spinnaker Software, along with his friend Igor Razboff in 1992. The company also had a branch in St. Petersburg, Russia and a subsidiary named Advanced Technical Group in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Much of their software was based on CDs, making extensive use of traditional 2D animation.

ArenaNet, located in Bellevue, Washington, and originally established as Triforge, Inc. in March, 2000, is a game development company founded by ex-Blizzard employees Pat Wyatt, Mike O'Brien and Jeff Strain. They developed the prestigious game network Battle.net as well as hit games like StarCraft, Diablo and Warcraft. The name was changed to ArenaNet in August, 2000 and NCsoft Corporation acquired the company in December 2002. ArenaNet is a wholly-owned subsidary of NCsoft.

column1: Awesome Games Studio Sp. z o. o.

column2: BV Maxflow is a Belgian company that operates the browser games distribution portal Crazy Games.

Babaroga is a mobile games development company in business since 2002, creating only the most cutting edge content across multiple platforms. Games include both original IP titles and high-profile licenses. Babaroga delivered the original version of Downtown Texas Holdem (Downtown Wireless), a bestseller since its release. SimCity (EA Mobile) is on EU’s top-ten list. Muppets Puzzle Party (mDisney) received the GOLD AWARD on mobilegamefaqs.com. Babaroga developed the highly profiled mobile version of SPORE (EA Mobile). Babaroga's publisher relations have been commendable. At GDC ’06, a VP from mDisney presented a session called Developer-Publisher Relationship Dynamics: From Creating to Distributing Mobile Content, using Babaroga and the Muppets game they did as the basis for the lecture. Babaroga's original IP, Konstruxis, won Grand Prize at GDC ’06 in Motorola’s CODE:MOTO competition. The next year, BEES! was a finalist in Motorola’s MOTODEV competition at CTIA.

Balio Studio was founded on 12th January 2009 as Vetasoft by the Baglio brothers, Adriano Baglio, Frédéric Baglio, and Massimo Baglio, as the result of their passion for new technologies and especially for mobile applications and video games. The studio develops mobile apps on all major platforms as well as games for consoles and Windows. The company is based in Mons, Belgium, in the Initialis Park. On 26th October 2023 the name was officially changed from Vetasoft to Balio Studio. The name Balio Studio had however already been used for quite some time as a registered trademark.

Bleem! is a publishing label of Piko Interactive, unveiled on 4 January 2021. The name originates from the Bleem! Company, a studio that was working on commercial PlayStation emulators for the PC and SEGA Dreamcast between 1999 and 2001, financially burdened by lawsuits from Sony Computer Entertainment.
Centresoft Limited was one of the largest independent distributors of interactive entertainment software in the United Kingdom. The company was acquired by Activision in December 1997.
Dejobaan Games is an independent, Cambridge, MA (USA) based game development studio founded in 1999. It is owned by Ichiro Lambe.
Digital Pictures was a multimedia company established in California in 1991 by Tom Zito after he left Axlon. The company specialized in Full-motion video (FMV) filming for video games.

Epic Games Brasil is a game development based in Porto Alegre, Brazil. It was founded in 2007 as Aquiris Game Studio by Amilton Diesel, Mauricio Longoni and Israel Mendes. The company was acquired by Epic Games on 19 April 2023.

Finji is the development and publishing studio of Adam Saltsman and Rebekah Saltsman. Established in 2014 and based in Austin, Texas (USA), it was originally started in 2006 as Last Chance Media, LLC, which is still the official company name, and the name Finji was introduced in 2014 as the name the company uses to do business. They previously worked together at Semi Secret Software where Adam was one of the co-founders.

Irrational Games LLC was a development studio founded in in 1997 by Ken Levine, Jon Chey and Robert Fermier. The original studio was located in Boston, MA (USA) and was dubbed Irrational Games Boston. In 2005 it was relocated to Quincy, Massachusetts, just outside Boston. In April 2000 an additional studio was established in Canberra, Australia: Irrational Games Australia. The company initially focused on role-playing games. Irrational Games is known for such titles as System Shock 2, Freedom Force and Freedom Force vs The 3rd Reich, Tribes: Vengeance, SWAT 4, SWAT 4: The Stetchkov Syndicate, BioShock, BioShock 2 and BioShock: Infinite. On 9th January 2006, the company was acquired by Take-Two Interactive. On 10th August 2007, Take-Two Interactive announced that the US and Australian offices of the company had been renamed 2K Boston and 2K Australia respectively. In December 2007, a third studio was established, 2K Marin, in Novato, California (USA). Initially it only consisted of five people from 2K Boston. The original name eventually made a return when Game Informer reported on 8th January 2010 that the original name Irrational Games would be restored, to respect the studio's legacy. Irrational Games is claimed to have been closed in 2014, but some of its key staff remained. Twelve staff members of Irrational Games founded Ghost Story Games, including creative director Ken Levine and art director Shawn Robertson, but although they are effectively the replacement of Irrational Games and had managed the "closed" studio's social media profiles after its formal "closure", Ghost Story Games distance themselves from the Irrational Games' portfolio and wish to create their own path. They are still a subsidiary of Take-Two Interactive.
GlobalStep Services Pvt. Ltd. is the Indian arm of GlobalStep LLC.
HexaDrive Inc. is a Japanese company. The team ported the Xbox 360 version of Rez, under the title Rez HD (January 2008).

Hidden Path Entertainment is an independent game development studio founded by Jeff Pobst, Mark Terrano, Michael Austin, Dave McCoy and James Garbarini. Hidden Path has released two games so far, the trivia title Wits & Wagers (2008) and the tower defense game Defense Grid: The Awakening (2008).

Human Head Studios was a game development studio based in Madison, Wisconsin (USA). Founded in 1997, Human Head began as a single-team development studio. The company then expanded to over 25 veteran developers across two teams. The studio closed down on 13 November 2019, immediately following the release of Rune II. Right away, a new studio Roundhouse Studios was established with the same staff and based in the same office, with the help of Bethesda Softworks, but would itself close on 7 May 2024.

InterServ is a publicly traded company on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (6169). It is a full-service game developer and publisher in the Greater China area, with over 80 members in in Taiwan and over 150 in their production center in Shanghai. The company was founded by Sheree Tsao in 1989. InterServ began as a CD-ROM and software developer, specializing in educational software including English, mathematics, and Chinese language games. In 1995, InterServ releases their first game Karma: Curse of the 12 Caves, across PC, Saturn, and PlayStation platforms.  In 2000, InterServ expanded its operations into to China by opening a full production studio in Shanghai. This expansion led to more growth in size and capability, adding more artists and increasing the capability in game development and art asset production.  In 2002, InterServ continued its expansion by opening an office in Irvine, California. InterServ also went public on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, making it one of the largest public game development companies in the world. Since then, InterServ has released several game titles for PC and consoles.

IntraCorp Inc. was the parent company of video game subsidiary Capstone Software and operated until 1996. Capstone was also a video game company. IntraCorp Inc. went bankrupt in 1996 and closed its doors along with Capstone Software.

Kure Software Koubou (呉ソフトウェア工房) is a game developer based in Saitama, Japan. The company was founded in 1985 by Eiji Kure, who formerly designed games for Bullet-Proof Software. The company debuted with the overhead shooter Gamma5 (1986), followed shortly afterwards by the 3D RPG Argo.  Silver Ghost (1988) was the first game to utilizes Kure's trademark "gocha-kyara" (ゴチャキャラ, "mixed-up characters") system, which combined elements of real-time strategy with role-playing and action. Their subsequent games (including their most popular series First Queen) focused on that system with a varying emphasis on its genre aspects.  Their activity slowed down significantly after they released First Queen: The New World, the first 3D installment of their flagship franchise. Since then they only produced remakes of earlier First Queen games and a few casual downloadable sports titles.
Locadile is a translation agency owned by Tommy Nordkvist and Stefan Hahn. It was started in 2019.

NVLMaker is the name of a GUI editor developed for the KiriKiri/KAG engine by the programmer Siying Wang, a native of Xiamen, China who currently resides in Osaka, Japan. NVLMaker is also the name under which certain games created using the NVLMaker software are published on Steam. It is currently unclear which corporation owns the NVLMaker publisher brand on Steam, as Siying Wang owns two companies:  Xiamen Navila Software Co., Ltd. (Xiamen, China) Navila Software Japan LLC (Osaka, Japan)

column1: National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, LLC

column2: Pandemic Studios, LLC was a game development studio based in Los Angeles, California. It was founded in 1998 with an equity investment by Activision and lasted more than ten years, until the closure in 2009. It was helmed by Josh Resnick (President) and Andrew Goldman (CEO) who both worked at Activision previously. The studio's first titles, Battlezone II: Combat Commander (1999) and Dark Reign 2 were both sequels to Activision games. In 2000 Andrew Payne and Adam Iarossi left the Los Angeles studio to start the satellite studio Pandemic Studio Pty Ltd in the Brisbane suburb of Fortitude Valley (Australia). The studio was also referred to Pandemic Brisbane or Pandemic Australia. The Australian team's first title was Army Men RTS (2002). Later, the division would work on the Destroy All Humans! franchise with the titles Destroy All Humans! (2005) and Destroy All Humans! 2 (2006). The US company continued to work for a large number of publishers, such as Midway, THQ, Electronic Arts and LucasArts. In 2003, Midway terminated Pandemic's contract, which led the studio to sue the publishing company. In the same year, the company moved from its Santa Monica location to Westwood. During those years the studio worked on Triple Play 2002 for EA (2002), Star Wars: The Clone Wars for LucasArts (2002), Full Spectrum Warrior as a new franchise for THQ (2004), Star Wars: Battlefront (2004) and Star Wars: Battlefront II (2005) for LucasArts (2004), and Mercenaries: Playground of Destruction as another new franchise for LucasArts (2005). In 2006 Full Spectrum Warrior: Ten Hammers was released. In November 2005 the company formed an alliance with with BioWare Corporation, backed financially by Elevation Partners. Through the operation a holding company called VG Holding Corp was created. BioWare's two co-founders Greg Zeschuk and Ray Muzyka, and Pandemic's two co-founders Andrew Goldman and Josh Resnick, became shareholders and senior executives. John Riccitiello from Elevation became the company's CEO. In October 2006, it was announced a second development team at the Australian branch had been formed, which led to the creation of several Destroy All Humans! titles where the US studio partially contributed to the first title. On 11 October 2007, it was announced VG Holding Corp, including both BioWare and Pandemic, would be acquired by Electronic Arts, effective January 2008. On 7 January 2008, the company officially became a part of the EA Games label. Two more games were created the next years: Mercenaries 2: World in Flames as a second title in the Mercenaries series (2008 - but now for EA) and The Lord of the Rings: Conquest (2009). Meanwhile, a team at the Australian studio got into trouble working on a movie adaptation of The Dark Knight and was eventually let go. Following a major restructuring by Electronic Arts, the Australian studio was set "free" and a small team was left with the rights to the open world game tentatively called The Next Big Thing, but working independently and no longer as a part of Pandemic or EA, which means the Australian studio was officially closed. The US studio continued to work on the free-roaming World War II title The Saboteur. Following an announcement by Electronic Arts in November 2009 that it would cut 1,500 jobs at its different development outfits, Pandemic Studios was hit hard and on 18th November it was confirmed the studio would be closed down, following the completion of development on The Saboteur and its release at the end of 2009. EA said the Pandemic brand and franchises would live on and a core IP team was folded into Electronic Arts Los Angeles. The rest of the team was let go, including its top executives: former studio CEO Andrew Goldman, former studios president Josh Resnick and vice president of product development Greg Borrud. At the end of November, a new title by the trimmed-down Pandemic team was announced: Mercs Inc, a new entry in the Mercenaries series. Development was supposed to be done at the new location of Playa Vista, as a part of EA Los Angeles, but the game was never released.

column1: People Can Fly, Sp. z o.o.
column2: People Can Fly is a development studio founded in February 2002 and located in Warsaw, Poland. The company is known for the Painkiller franchise but also collaborated with Epic Games, Inc. on the PC version of Gears of War. On 20th August 2007 Epic announced to have obtained a majority interest in the company. For Epic, People Can Fly assisted with the design of multiplayer maps for Gears of War 2. In February 2011, Bulletstorm was released, an entirely new first-person shooter franchise. Immediately following the release the team started working on the sequel Bulletstorm 2, but Epic eventually decided the studio should work on another project, putting the sequel on hold. In May 2012, it was revealed the team is working on Gears of War: Judgment, a prequel to the first game in the Gears of War series. It was released in March 2013. On 13 August 2012, Epic Games announced to have acquired the company. Just the day before Epic confirmed that founder and creative director Adrian Chmielarz left the company, along with lead artist Andrzej Poznanski and principal artist Michal Kosieradzki. The company was renamed Epic Games Poland on 1 November 2013. On 24 June 2015, the studio announced the return to an independent studio as People Can Fly. Known subsidiaries  People Can Fly (Newcastle) (founded in 2018) People Can Fly Rzeszów (founded in 2018) People Can Fly New York (founded in 2019) People Can Fly Łódź (founded in 2020) People Can Fly Montreal (acquired in 2021 as Game On) Incuvo (acquired in 2021) People Can Fly Chicago (acquired in 2021 as Phosphor Studios) Lviv studio (mentioned only in January 2022, inactive after Russian invasion of Ukraine started a month later) People Can Fly Krakow (founded in 2022) PCF Publishing (Dublin)

column1: Pole To Win Singapore Pte. Ltd., Taiwan Branch

column2: Purple Software is a Japanese company which develops erotic visual novels. It is not to be confused with Purple Software Ltd, a British company which developed video game adaptations of classic card and board games.

Red Orb Entertainment was a game division of Brøderbund Software, Inc. established on 21st May 1997. The division was conceived by Ted Simon and lead by Vice President and General Manager Ken Goldstein. Red Orb (Broder when spelled backwards), was founded for regular games to distinguish them from its library of edutainment titles. The Red Orb division included a complete development studio and publishing operations. In addition to publishing its own creations, the division published games from other developing companies. When Brøderbund was acquired by The Learning Company on 31st August 1998, it became a publishing label for the Mindscape, Inc. division.
RYZIN, LLC is an art production studio located in Los Angeles CA, they provide AAA art to many leading games.  They provide concept for weapons, vehicles, props, and environment art.
Scottgames is the one-man development endeavour of Scott Cawthon.

Sixteen Tons Entertainment is a label of Promotion Software - Agent for Interactive Medien GmbH. Located in Germany, Sixteen Tons Entertainment is developing Games for PC and Consoles. The company was founded in 1998 by game developer veteran Ralph Stock. The original team already worked together since 1984. [Source: Company website]

The Behemoth is an independent console game developer that specializes in making collectible games that are fun to play and beautiful to look at. The company was founded in in 2003 by Dan Paladin and John Baez to turn the flash game Alien Hominid into a full console game. The company is headquartered in San Diego, California.

The Dreamers Guild was a North American developer incorporated on Jun 4th, 1991 by Joe Pearce, Robert McNally and their friends. In 1994 they moved to Chatsworth, California. The company closed down in 1997.

TiMi Studio Group is a video game development studio based in Shenzhen, China and with offices in Los Angeles, Chengdu, and Shanghai. It is a subsidiary of Tencent Games and it was established in 2014. The studio was formed as a merger between Jade Studio, Wolong Studio and Tianmeiyiyou Studio in 2014.
TikiMan Productions, Inc. is a voiceover production company founded by Chris Borders in 2002.

Toadman Interactive is a game development company based in Stockholm, Sweden, founded in 2013 by Robin Flodin and Rasmus Davidsson. Initially, the company operated as a work-for-hire consultancy studio, contributing to various gaming titles such as Killing Floor Calamity, Escape from Dead Island, Dead Island 2, Bloodsports TV, Stylista and Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide. In 2017, Toadman Interactive expanded its horizons by venturing into developing its own games. The debut title under their independent development was Immortal: Unchained. Concurrently, the company went public and established a new office in Berlin. The year 2018 brought about strategic acquisitions. They acquired Artplant, which included offices in Oslo and Tver. Toadman continued its expansion in 2019 with the acquisition of Antimatter Games. Additionally, they acquired Sold Out and purchased the marketing agency Petrol Advertising. In 2020, Toadman Interactive underwent organizational restructuring with the announcement of the formation of Enad Global 7 as its parent company. While Artplant and Antimatter Games remained part of Toadman, Sold Out and Petrol became integral parts of EG7. Ola Nilsson assumed the role of CEO for Toadman Interactive, succeeding Robin Flodin. This period also marked the publication of Westmark Manor on platforms like Steam and GOG, developed by Nodbrim Interactive. In 2021 the leadership team expanded to include individuals such as Rasmus Davidsson, Annika Fogelgren, Andreas Jonsson, Daniel Mesonero, and Daniel Stakhovskiy. Collaboration with Fatshark resulted in the release of Warhammer: Vermintide II - Chaos Wastes. The year 2022 presented challenges globally, prompting Toadman Interactive to relocate its Tver Studio out of Russia. In response to the conflict in Novi Sad, Serbia, Toadman Interactive opened a new studio in 2023, providing refuge and employment opportunities for individuals affected by the crisis.

Triumph Studios is a game development studio founded in Delft, The Netherlands in 1997. They are best known for their Age of Wonders franchise, a series of 4X turn-based strategy games. In June 2007 the first game in a new franchise, Overlord, was launched. On 30 June 2017, the company was purchased by Paradox Interactive AB, along with the Age of Wonders intellectual property. The rights to the Overlord series would remain with Codemasters, however.

Ubisoft Leamington was founded as FreeStyleGames in 2002 in Leamington Spa, UK, primarily by ex-staff from the nearby Codemasters and Rare studios. The company first developed the break dancing title B-Boy (2006) for the PSP and PS2. In September 2008, FreeStyleGames employed a staff of 55 people full-time. On 12 September 2008, the company was acquired by Activision. The team was reported to be working on localized downloadable content for Guitar Hero: World Tour. For Activision, FreeStyleGames created the DJ Hero series, a spin-off of the Guitar Hero franchise focused on turntable mixing. The second game was released in October 2010. In February 2011, Activision Blizzard announced to reduce the workforce of the development studio, axing a number of jobs. On 18 January 2017, the company was sold to Ubisoft and subsequently renamed Ubisoft Leamington. On 27 January 2025, the studio's closure was announced.
U・Me Soft is (alongside Software House Parsley) an adult brand of a company otherwise known as Square and based in Kanazawa, Japan. It has no relation to the better-known company with the same name.
jmtb02 Studios is the flash development studio of John Cooney.
lightUP is the independent game development studio of Juliano Ferreira de Lima.

13AM Games is a game development studio based in Toronto, Canada, established in 2014. One of the co-founders is Alex Rushdy, acting as CEO of the company. The studio debuted with the platformer Runbow in 2015. Released across multiple platforms, total downloads reached almost two million in 2022, with a significant number of those coming from Xbox Live Games with Gold. The game was originally intended as a small project the developers could put on their resume and move on, but the success led to new projects at the studio. In 2016 Pirate Pop Plus was released, a game by dadako for which 13AM provided additional development, porting and the publishing. They recouped their investments quickly, but found out the publishing side took away a lot of their development time. In 2019 the action platformer Double Cross was released. In 2022 the studio released Dawn of the Monsters, a cooperative beat 'em up with giant monsters in cities inspired by kaiju and tokusatsu. It was published by WayForward Technologies. 13AM Games previously worked together with WayForward to get their character Shantae in Runbow. They showed them an early concept of Dawn of the Monster and were offered a publishing contract. The company has received support from the Canada Media Fund and the Ontario Media Development Corporation for the development of their titles. For technology the studio uses Unity as a multiplatform game engine, FMOD as the sound engine, as well as Krita and Spine for art and animation.
Abylight Studios SA, active since 5th May 2015, is most likely the international name used for publishing and other activities by the Spanish company Abylight, S.L.
BiP Media, SARL is a French development studio established in 2004 by Sophie-Anne Bled and Thierry Platon.

The company was founded as Pixel Planet in September 1999 in Brighton, England by Tony Beckwith. In November 1999 it was already acquired by The Climax Group and renamed Climax Brighton. Before its acquisition, the studio was working on the game Stunt Driver for the Dreamcast, to be completed in 2001, but it was eventually cancelled because of the console's quick demise. In November 2004 the studio was re-branded Climax Racing and almost four years later, on 28th September 2006, the company was acquired a second time, by Buena Vista Games, Inc. (now Disney Interactive Studios). One year later, in July 2007, the name was changed into Black Rock Studio. The company was always known for its racing games. Its last title was the action racing game Split/Second (2010). On 1st July 2011 Disney confirmed that the studio was set to close, with 40 people to be made redundant. In May of the same year, staff numbers had already been reduced. The studio was working on an unannounced project after Split/Second, but Disney did not greenlight it. The studio's ex-employees founded several new studios: Roundcube Entertainment, ShortRound Games, Boss Alien, West Pier Studio and Studio Gobo.

Bytex is a Quality Assurance and Work For Hire developer studio based in Saransk, Russia. It was established in 2004 by Dmitri Karasev. On 22 September 2021, Embracer Group AB, through its wholly owned subsidiary Saber Interactive, announced its acquisition to acquire the company (100%) and its more than 240 employees. Bytex and Saber already worked together on projects previously. Karasev remained CEO and Bytex continued to operate as a subsidiary under Saber. When Saber Interactive split off from Embracer in 2024, Bytex would remain with the former.

CD Projekt RED Sp. z o.o. is a Polish game development studio established in February 2002 as a sister company of the Polish publisher and distributor CD Projekt Sp. z o.o.. In September 2003 the studio moved from Lódz to a new office in Warsaw and started working on its first project, the role-playing game The Witcher, based on the books by Polish fantasy author Andrzej Sapkowski. It was released to great acclaim in October 2007 and differentiates itself from its RPG contemporaries through the adult themes and language, and dark universe. Instead of focusing entirely on the sequel right away, the development team contributed to the browser game The Witcher: Versus (July 2008) and released a revamped version of its first title as The Witcher: Enhanced Edition in September 2008. The team is working on three announcement projects, of which one will likely be a sequel. The team is working on three announcement projects, one of which is The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings. Abandoning the Aurora Engine used in the first game, the team has developed a brand new engine for the sequel as well as other games. In 2009, CD Projekt's holding company CDP Investment agreed to perform a reverse takeover with former Polish computer manufacturer Optimus S.A. in order to gain the company's position in the Warsaw Stock Exchange. In the process of this, Optimus was renamed to CD Projekt RED S.A. on July 2011, and in October 2011 CD Projekt RED Sp. z o.o. was merged into the freshly rebranded company.

Camouflaj, LLC is a US development studio based in Bellevue Washington, USA. It was established on 18th February 2011 by Ryan Payton who previously worked at Microsoft as a Creative Director and Narrative Designer and at Konami as an Assistant Producer. The studio debuted with the episodic stealth game République in 2013. In 2018 a VR version République VR was released and in 2020 Marvel Iron Man VR was made available as a VR game based on the Marvel franchise, exclusive to the PS4 with PSVR. On 11th October 2022 Meta announced the acquisition of the company.

Deep Shadows is a software developing company based in Kiev, Ukraine. It was founded in 2001 by the authors of the Vital Engine: Sergey Zabaryansky and Roman Lut. They began working together as a team in 1998. Lut came to the game industry from demo making. By the time of their meeting, two of his demos were the prizewinners on the well-known Russian demo-party "Enlight". Meanwhile, Zabaryansky worked in two USA software companies before. In 1999 they started to work in GSC Game World on Codename: Outbreak (Venom). Zabaryansky was producer and lead programmer of this game. Lut was a programmer and level designer. Having finished successfully this project, they left the company and founded Deep Shadows to develop a new RPG/action title based on Vital Engine 2. This game eventually became Boiling Point: Road to Hell (2005). The company continued developing free-roaming action games with role-playing and driving elements afterwards.

Hoplite Research is an "interactive think-tank devoted to innovation in entertainment technologies" founded in 1997 by Manny Granillo. The first product seems to have been Corps Command, a PnP strategy ruleset for those who like to play with tin soldiers. 2000 saw Extreme PaintBrawl 2, a sequel to the last Build Engine game, and 2002 Hooters Road Trip for PC and Playstation. A planned sequel, Hooters Road Trip Overdrive for the X-Box, never came to pass and not much more was heard of Hoplite Research.
Makers of one of the most widely-used DOS sound code libraries in the world, the Sound Operating System.

Kabam is game company founded in 2006 with the name Watercooler. Initially the focus was on the development of social network applications for corporations. In time, Watercooler shifted direction, becoming one of the first developers on Facebook creating sports and entertainment communities. In 2009 a new type of project was started, the strategy game Kingdoms of Camelot for social networks. In August 2010 the company was renamed Kabam. The studio has offices in San Francisco and Austin (USA), Strassen (Luxembourg) and Beijing (China). In June 2012 it was reported the company acquired the development studio Wild Shadow Studios.

column1: Konami Computer Entertainment Nagoya Co., Ltd.
column2: Konami Computer Entertainment Nagoya (コナミコンピュータエンタテインメント名古屋, KCEN) was a development studio based in Nagoya, Aichi, Japan. It was established by Konami in March 1997 at the same time as studios in Sapporo and Yokohama, and was primarily responsible for developing ports, sports games, and licensed titles for its parent company. The studio was shuttered by Konami in December 2002.

Longbow Digital Arts Inc. is an independent game developing company and a family business located in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Formed in 1998, the company publishes and distributes their games online. In 2010 McNally family members who are principals in the business are:  Jim McNally, President and Game Designer Philippe McNally, Lead Artist and 3D Modeller Wendy McNally, Art Adviser

MDNA games is a Swedish development company, based in Norrköping. Co-proprietors are husband and wife Mikael and Eleen Nyqvist. They started out as film makers but find making games more satisfying. MDNA has been developing the Carol Reed Mystery games since 2004 and release one game a year on average.
MG Desenvolvimento de Games Ltda, better known as Mother Gaia Studio, is a Brazilian game development studio established in 2008.

Max Design GesMBH was a game developer based in Schladming, Austria. The company was founded in 1991 by the brothers Albert and Martin Lasser together with Wilfried Reiter. They mainly focused on business simulation games. The company became defunct on April 15th, 2004.
Mode 7 Games is a game development studio founded in 2005 by Paul Taylor and Ian Hardingham.

NEON Software was a German development studio founded in 1993 by  Antony Christoulakis, Boris Triebel, Jan Jöckel, Michael Büttner, and Peter Thierolf. The latter previously co-founded Kaiko in late 1990. A little later Matthias Wiederwach (also with Kaiko) joined as a shareholder. After some games commissioned for advertising NEON picked up the development of the tentatively named platformer Timet: the Flying Squirrel that was originally started at Kaiko. Aiming to become a console developer NEON struck a deal with publisher Ocean Software Ltd., who attempted to launch Mr. Nutz as a mascot with a SNES game. Because of the thematic similarities, Timet became Mr. Nutz: Hoppin' Mad as a sequel to Ocean's Mr. Nutz (1994). After the Amiga release work on a SEGA Mega Drive port was started but eventually never finished because of Ocean's dwindling interest in the platform. Ocean was satisfied with the work however and NEON signed a deal for four more games for multiple platforms. NEON started work on the PC role-playing game Vanished Powers (eventually unreleased) and completed the action game Tunnel B1 in 1996. Shortly after the release Ocean ran into financial difficulties and was acquired by Infogrames (now Atari). Some payments to NEON were still due and the studio was forced to lay off about 20 people. In a dispute with the other four founders Büttner and Wiederwach left the company. Büttner moved on to X-ample Architectures where Viper was completed for Ocean in 1998. NEON took a different direction. After completing Mars Taxi (1997) the studio focused on mostly licensed Game Boy Color games for different publishers such as Janosch (1999), Pumuckls Abenteuer bei den Piraten (1999), Tabaluga (1999), Maya the Bee: Garden Adventures (2000), Pumuckls Abenteuer im Geisterschloss (2000), Die Maus: Verrückte Olympiade (2001), Santa Claus Junior (2001), and Santa Claus Jr. Advance (2002 - GBA), but also titles like the action shooter Armorines: Project S.W.A.R.M. (1999) and the BMX game Dave Mirra Freestyle BMX (2000). The company was purchased by JoWooD in 2000. Triebel left in 2003 and went on to co-found the development studio ZEAL GmbH. NEON's last title was the PS2 game Legend of Kay (2005). JoWood ran into financial difficulties and in late 2005 NEON was closed and all developers were let go. Former employees went on to work at other German developers and some founded the German studio 49Games GmbH. The three remaining owners, Christoulakis, Jöckel, and Thierolf, founded keen games GmbH & Co. KG in 2005 with some other developers.
NatsumeAtari Inc. is a Japanese company established in October 2013 through the merger of the Japanese companies Natsume Co., Ltd. and Atari Inc.
Next Level Games is a game development studio based in Vancouver, Canada. It was established in 2002. On 5th January 2021 Nintendo announced the acquisition of the company.

Nimble Giant Entertainment, originally founded as NGD Studios, is a game development studio located in Buenos Aires, Argentina, specializing in video games and entertainment software. The company has also developed their own in-house, proprietary NG3D Engine, which is currently used exclusively for their game Regnum Online.

Rowan Software was a software company located in the United Kingdom and founded in 1987. The studio specialized in flight simulators. Rowan Software's last game was Battle of Britain (2000). The company was acquired by Empire Interactive Europe in December 2000.
Screen 7 have been developing and collaborating on point & click adventure games since 1997, and began publishing independent adventure games in August 2012.

Shiny Entertainment is a video game development studio based in Newport Beach, California (US). Shiny was founded in 1993 by David Perry after he left London for the US. The company was originally known for its humorous games, such as the Earthworm Jim series, which spawned a successful line of action figures, comic books and a syndicated television cartoon series on the Universal Cartoon Studios/Warner Kids Network. Shiny was acquired by Interplay in 1995 and in the following five years they released MDK (1997), Wild 9 (1999), Messiah (2000) and Sacrifice (2000). The critics' acclaim for their titles was not always reflected in the sales numbers, and in 2002 the company was acquired by Infogrames (later Atari), which meant a drastic change for the company's focus. Shiny released two games based on the Matrix films franchise: Enter the Matrix (2003) and The Matrix: Path of Neo. Although less polished than their previous games, those were Shiny's biggest successes. In February 2006, Atari announced to restructure and sell Shiny. Founder David Perry resigned to spend more time raising interest for potential buyers, to rejoin afterwards. He announced to do this to avoid stepping on anybody's toes inside Atari, as he was also a member of various boards.
