Technology: 2D isometric MUH Works and 3D real-time KAPOW Systems 3D. Playstation 2 and Microsoft Xbox developer status.   Present and former partners: Warner Bros, EA, Ubisoft, Valusoft, Tivola, Pan Vision, Living Books, Vision Park, BMG Interactive, Bonnier Multimedia, Danish Centre for Human Rights, Nordea Bank, Jyske Bank, Advertising agency Nørgård Mikkelsen, Danmarks Kirkelige Mediecenter (publisher of material for the Danish Lutheran Church).   Owners: Chris Mottes (CEO), Simon Jon Andreasen (Creative Director), shareholders and employees. In January 2009 the studio announced that the title Faith and a .45 had been put on hold indefinitely. It was a story about two outlaws set during the Great Depression. Because no publisher could be founded, it became too costly to finish it in time.
DevilishGames is the name used by the Spanish company Spherical Pixel S.L. for its indie game projects.

Erbe Software, S.L. is a young Spanish software company founded at the end of 2018, being a subsidiary of the commercial company PROTOCREDIT. The company is named in honor of the distributor that operated during the so-called Golden Age of Spanish software Erbe Software, S.A..

column1: Eurofins Digital Product Testing Belgium NV
column2: Testronic Laboratories Belgium is a QA testing facility located in Diepenbeek, Belgium. It was previously known as Professional Multimedia Test Centre (PMTC).

Flashbulb Games is a Danish independent studio based in Copenhagen. It was founded by the members of Press Play ApS after Microsoft closed the studio in March 2016 and the company was incorporated on 29th April 2016. The studio announced Pioneers as its first project. In the same year the company was renamed Flashbulb Games.

Forgotten Empires LLC originally started as a modding team for Age of Empires II: The Conquerors, releasing a popular unofficial expansion called Forgotten Empires, which received over 1 million downloads since its release in late 2012.  Microsoft Studios called the team to port the unofficial expansion to Age of Empires II: HD Edition. The resulting full expansion The Forgotten was released in November 2013, but also marked the end of the development cycle for the unofficial Forgotten Empires expansion for the original game (even though it is still available for download).  In the following two years, the company created completely new expansions exclusive to the HD re-releases of Age of Empires II: HD Edition and Age of Mythology: Extended Edition (for which they also provided localization), being The African Kingdoms and Rise of the Rajas, and Tale of the Dragon, respectively. They were also heavily involved in the development and post-release support of Age of Empires: Definitive Edition, Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition, Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition, and Age of Mythology: Retold. They have also co-published Retaliation: Enemy Mine in 2015. On 8 June 2022, Keywords Studios announced the acquisition of the studio for $32.5 million.

Free Lunch Design is an independent game developer founded in 1998 by Johan Peitz. Based in Gothenburg, Sweden, the company's objective is to develop fun, high quality games with focus on gameplay that can be enjoyed by everyone. During the years Free Lunch Design has produced a multitude of games for the PC platform including the immensely popular Icy Tower with millions of players all around the world. The company was acquired by Muskedunder Interactive in 2008.

Freem Inc. has operated Freem!, a platform for distributing freeware games, since February 2000. It also provides a stock music and illustration library, tutorials on game creation, and game creation tools.

Frognation Ltd. was originally founded in 1997 to distribute European music through their own music label in Japan. Later the same year, they expanded to localization video games and anime. Frognation is incorporated in the UK and has offices in London and Tokyo.

Frontier Foundry was a publishing label of Frontier Developments, mostly assigned to externally-developed games. It was launched in the summer of 2019. The first title to carry the label, Struggling, was released on 27th August 2020. Eight titles were released in total. The last one was The Great War: Western Front on 30th March 2023. In June 2023 the company announced to cease all activity relating to acquiring new third-party titles, closing the label. Frontier said the business did not meet its expectations of a positive return on investment within the first year of each title.

The development studio GRIN was founded by brothers Bo and Ulf Andersson in 1997 in Sweden. The studio's headquarters were in Stockholm. The company's first release was Ballistics (2001 - PC, Arcade), the first game ever to use pixel-shaders. Next, the team created Bandits - Phoenix Rising (2002 - PC) and several arcade machines, as well as Military and Civilian simulators. All of its titles were powered by the proprietary, in-house developed DIESEL engine, which was also offered for licensing. Bugbear Entertainment used it for its FlatOut racing game and Fatshark AB, a studio partially owned by GRIN, used it to create the shooter Lead & Gold: Gangs of the Wild West. The company also had a quality assurance studio in Indonesia. GRIN went on to develop two games for Ubisoft. Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon: Advanced Warfighter (2006 - PC) and Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon: Advanced Warfighter 2 (2007 - PC) are both tactical games continuing the Ghost Recon franchise with separate games for the Windows platform. In 2009 the company saw heavy layoffs, likely to the weaker-than-expected sales of three titles completed in the first half of the year: Wanted: Weapons of Fate, Terminator: Salvation and Bionic Commando (a heavily enhanced remake of the classic Bionic Commando). In May it was first reported more than 200 staff (about 50% of the workforce) had been let go from the Stockholm, Gothenburg and Barcelona offices. In June it was reported both the Barcelona and Gothenburg had been closed, with the Stockholm employees told not to come to work. On 12th August the company was officially closed. The Andersson founders cited an unbearable cashflow situation in their goodbye statement, blaming delayed payments by too many publishers. It also contained a reference to an unreleased title the studio was working on. Prior to the closure about 25 ex-employees founded the development studio Outbreak Studios. In April 2010 a new studio was announced, Might and Delight, based around a small group of the GRIN team that worked on Bionic Commando Rearmed. A third studio with former GRIN employees, Whiteout, was announced in August 2010. The two Andersson brothers founded the game development studio Overkill Software in 2009.

Founded in June 2009, Gaming Minds Studios GmbH is an internal development studio of Kalypso Media GmbH and located in Gütersloh, Germany. The studio is led by Daniel Dumont (CEO) and Kay Struve (Technical Director), and consists of a team of fifteen developers formerly employed by Ascaron Entertainment. On 7 November 2023, a sister studio in Paderborn was founded.
Garage 227 Studios is an American and Brazilian independent game development company founded in 2014, with studios in São Paulo and office in Los Angeles.

Gravity Co., Ltd. (그라비티 주식회사) is a South Korean game developer and publisher. The company was founded in April 2000 in Kangnam-ku, Seoul. They developed their first game, the single-player RPG Arcturus (2000), in cooperation with Sonnori. Since then the company has been focusing exclusively on online RPGs such as Ragnarök Online.
IV Productions is short for Ivan Venturi Productions, named after the founder Ivan Venturi.

IllFonic is a game development studio based in Colorado, USA. It was founded in 2007 by Charles Brungardt, Kedhrin Gonzales and Raphael Saadiq. The studio's debut was Nexuiz in 2012, an arena shooter and commercial remake of the 2005 game Nexuiz. The studio also has offices in Tacoma, Washington and Austin, Texas.

Infinity Plus Two is an Australian game development studio. It was founded as in 1989 and became wholly independent as Infinity Interactive in January 2003 when it was spun off from the Strategic Studios Group by Steve Fawkner, creator and lead designer of the Warlords series of PC games.  On 4 January 2011, the Australian development studio Firemint announced to have acquired Infinite Interactive. On 3 May 2011, Electronic Arts announced to have acquired Firemint, making Infinite Interactive a part of EA as well. As of 25 July 2012, the company once again became independent. On 14 January 2021, it was acquired by 505 Games. Owner Steve Fawkner worked as an independent developer in the 1980's, creating titles for many platforms from the Sinclair Spectrum to the Commodore Amiga. He then moved to the Strategic Studios Group where he created, maintained and expanded the Warlords franchise on the PC. Infinite Interactive is now best known for the Puzzle Quest series. Infinite Interactive's founding members are (in alphabetical order):  Dean Farmer (AI & System Programmer) Janeen Fawkner (Producer, Art Director) Steve Fawkner (Lead Designer, Programmer, Musician) Andrew Gillard (3d Modeller, Texturer & Animator) Nick McVeity (3d Engine Programmer) Chris Proctor (Textures & Level Design) Mick Robertson (Interface Design & Programming) James Tutton (Sound & Video Editor)
Inter Heart (インターハート) is a Japanese game developer founded in 1992 in Yokohama. The company specializes in eroge development.

Interstel Corporation was a company originally established as Cygnus by Trevor C. Sorensen. He had made a game for DEC computers called Starfleet in 1981 and the company was created to market Star Fleet I: The War Begins, an adaptation for home computers. Together with his partners the company was incorporated in 1986 to form Interstel Corporation and from then on the name Cygnus was no longer used. In the same year Interstel Corporation became an affiliated label of Electronic Arts. In 1988 one of Interstel's games, Empire: Wargame of the Century, was named as Computer Game of the Year by Computer Gaming World magazine. Star Fleet II: Krellan Commander was released in 1989. A hostile takeover bid forced Sorensen to sell his shares and leave Interstel in 1990, and the company ceased operation in 1992. Before that, many titles were released, developed in-house or by external teams. Sorensen's worked continued at Supernova Creations, a studio he co-founded in 1991.

Kai Magazine Software is a small group of Spanish indie video game developers for retro consoles, retro computers and PC. Games have been released for SEGA Genesis (Mega Drive), MSX and Intellivision.

column1: Kodobur Yazilim Bilişim Tasarim Arge Sayayi Ticaret Ltd. Şti.

column2: Kouyousha Ltd. (有限会社光遊社), founded in April 1996, is involved in software development for games, mobile apps, and toys. They also specialize in general 2D/3D graphic design work.

LDW Software (Last Day of Work) is San-Francisco based independent game development studio. We develop and publish software for Palm OS, Windows Mobile’ Pocket PC and Windows PC. We specialize in games that bend the definitions of existing genres and run in true real-time.  Our latest line of games use real time gaming engines. These games appear to continue functioning even when the device is turned off, giving a truly unique sensation of continuity.  Our line of casino game applications are leaders in the market for games that teach correct casino play. Although you can never beat the casinos, it is possible to use statistically correct strategies to reduce the 'casino-edge',increase your long-term expectation at the casino and make you a better player.

Liquid Entertainment is an American independent video game developer based in Pasadena, California. The studio is led by President Ed Del Castillo and CEO Holly Newman. It was co-founded in March of 1999 by Ed Del Castillo and Mike Grayford.

Lonely Troops is an independent game development team from Slovakia. The two-man team was founded in 2004 by brothers Jaroslav Kurcik and Tomas Kurcik. Their first game, War on Folvos, was released in 2006.

Magitech Corporation was founded in 1993, by the company director, Ming-Sheng Lee. In the fall of 2001, Magitech released its first game title, Takeda, in the North American market. Takeda was also released in China, Taiwan, and Japan. Most recently the company has developed two more franchises in addition to Takeda and its sequels: Sango and Strength & Honour.

Magnetic Scrolls was a British game developer founded in 1984 by Anita Sinclair, Ken Gordon and Hugh Steers and located in London, England. They mostly developed text adventure games, until the popularity of that genre began to fade and they were acquired by MicroProse in 1992. They collaborated with MicroProse in the development of The Legacy: Realm of Terror. In 2017 several former members of the company founded Strand Games with the intention of re-releasing and re-mastering Magnetic Scrolls games on modern devices.

Metalhead Software is a game development studio based in Victoria, British Columbia, Canada. It started in 2009 and on 5th May 2021 Electronic Arts announced the acquisition of the company. It is best known for the Super Mega Baseball series.

Metropolis Software is a development studio with headquarters in Warsaw, Poland. The company was founded in 1992 and in February 2008 it was acquired by CD Projekt Sp. z o.o. In the nineties Metropolis developed point-and-click adventure games such as Teenagent (1995) and The Prince and the Coward (1999). Later they pursued a more action-oriented focus with the Gorky series, often introducing stealth elements as well. Their most recent title is Infernal (2007), a 3D shooter where the protagonist also wields magical powers.

Microïds Canada Inc. was a development division of Microïds located in Montréal, Québec, Canada. Over half of Microïds' employees were based in this location. Microïds Canada Inc. was a North American division of French video game developer Microïds. The Canadian company was founded in 1999. In 2003, they merged with MC2 to form MC2-Microïds. In 2005, they briefly shortened their name to MC2 before they ultimately they reverted back to the Microïds Canada Inc. name.  In March 2005, Ubi Soft acquired Microïds Canada. Ubisoft Canada Inc, Ubisoft's Montreal branch, got 50 of the employees who were integrated into Ubisoft's Montréal development teams.

After trading as Mutation Software since 1990, in 2005 thru 2006 founder, owner and developer Adrian Cummings changed the business name to Mobile Amusements (incorporating Software Amusements) and is currently supplying games content as a developer to publishers, portals and distributors around the globe.

Omnitrend Software, Inc. was founded by Thomas R. Carbone in 1979 and is a privately held business software company that branched out into computer game development during the 1980s. The company developed the three-game Universe series, Paladin, the Breach games, and two Rules of Engagement games. The company left the field of game development in 1993. Today functions as a developer of communications software with wireless messaging is a cornerstone to most of its product lines, including the PageMaster™ and ServScan™ series.

Onoma was a development studio based in Montréal, Canada and originally established as Square Enix Montréal by Square Enix in 2011. On 2 May 2022, Embracer Group AB entered into an agreement to acquire the studio along with Crystal Dynamics and Eidos Montréal from Square Enix. The acquisition was completed on 22 August 2022. From then on the three studios formed Embracer's 12th operative group under the leadership of Phil Rogers and his management teams. Following the acquisition, the studio was renamed Onoma. On 17 November 2022, it was announced that the studio was being closed.

Owlchemy Labs is a US game development established in 2010 by Worcester Polytechnic Institute graduate Alex Schwartz in Boston, Massachusetts, US. Currently its headquarters is based in Austin, Texas, US. Their debut title was the physics racer Snuggle Truck (2011), followed by co-development with Dejobaan Games on AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! for the Awesome (2011) and AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! (Force = Mass x Acceleration) (2012), as well as supernatural log-chopper Jack Lumber (2012) and quirky choose-your-own-adventure game Dyscourse (2015). From then on the studio focused on created extended reality (XR) and virtual reality (VR) titles often with a humourous tone, such as Job Simulator: The 2050 Archives (2016) that won the Game Developer's Choice Award for best VR/AR Game in 2017, Rick and Morty: Virtual Rick-ality (2017), Vacation Simulator (2019) and Cosmonious High (2022). In addition to standalone titles, Owlchemy Labs has released several experimental and accessibility features (like Hand-Tracking and Subtitles Updates), and also founded VR Austin, one of the largest VR-focused meetups in the US with over 2,000 members. Before that, the founders started the Boston Unity Group and the Winnipeg Unity User Group. On 10th May 2017 Google announced the acquisition of the company. Alex Schwartz left the company on 18th July 2018. Former CTO Devin Reimer became CEO and Andrew Eiche became CTO. Schwartz left to start a new company absurd:joy in June 2019 and took studio director Cy Wise with him.

The history of Philips P.O.V. Entertainment Group begins in the Cinemaware offices in the late 1980s. A core group of Cinemaware employees, comprising David Riordan and David Todd among others, banded together as Mass Media Inc. In turn, they were hired by Philips Media to form a production unit called Philips P.O.V. Entertainment Group in 1991. Over a four year period, Philips P.O.V. created 11 award-winning titles for Philips Media, including Voyeur, Caesars World of Boxing, and Thunder in Paradise Interactive for Philips' CD-i platform. Mass Media left Philips in 1995 to develop exclusively for Time Warner Interactive, was later acquired and shut down by THQ and still exists today as a privately held California corporation, designing and producing entertainment software.

[Source: Press Release dated July 8, 1996] "Founded in 1991, Presto Studios Inc., is a San Diego based CD-ROM production company best known for its award-winning photorealistic adventure game, The Journeyman Project. With the release of The Journeyman Project in 1993, Presto earned a reputation as an industry trend-setter. The company continues to grow and push the limits of interactive entertainment with titles such as The Journeyman Project 2: Buried in Time, the stunning next-generation sequel to The Journeyman Project, which was released in 1995, and has sold over 200,000 copies to date."

Purple Tree is game development studio with its headquarters in Buenos Aires, Argentina. It was established in 2012 and also has offices in Canada. Key people at the company are Ezequiel Heyn (Game Design), Alfredo Hodes (Lead Developer) and Pablo Cerrutti (Art Director).

Mainframe Entertainment, founded in 1993, was one of the leading companies in the area of CG animation for television, direct-to-video DVD, theatrical feature films, interactive games and commercials, with offices in Vancouver (Mainframe Vancouver) and Los Angeles (Mainframe USA). The company worked on well-known international brands such as Barbie, Hot Wheels, Spider-Man, Casper and Popeye. Its claim to fame, however, was its production of the pioneering CGI animated series ReBoot (which spawned the PSX game ReBoot, as well as the acclaimed Transformers spin-off Beast Wars (also made into a game called Beast Wars: Transformers. In 2006, US-based IDT Entertainment, which held a 62% majority stake in Mainframe, sold the company to another major Canadian player in the digital entertainment market, Rainmaker. After the merger, the team was integrated in the new company as a new division, Rainmaker Animation. However, the individual studios kept the Mainframe name after the renaming.

Sharing a premises with Rockstar's European publishing office, Rockstar London is located on King's Road just on the outskirts of the prestigious Chelsea area of London.  Rockstar London was formed in late 2005 bringing on a small skeleton crew to fill key positions. Recruitment began in earnest in early 2006 and the studio has grown steadily since.  The first title developed at this studio was the controversial title Manhunt 2, with the studio taking over development from Rockstar Vienna that was shutdown in 2006.  The London studio then went on to complete Midnight Club: L.A. Remix.  In June 2008 the studio was nominated for the Develop Industry Excellence Awards 2008 in the category of Best New UK/European Studio losing to Kuju's studio Double Six in the final vote tally.

Sanuk Software Co., Ltd. was incorporated in 2003 in Bangkok by Yan Marchal. From 2003 to 2006, it used to be an outsourcing facility working on a wide range of projects of diverse natures (art, programming...) on diverse platforms. A major change took place in 2007, as the company specialized in full-cycle game development on Nintendo DS and Wii, and started trading under the name of Sanuk Games. Since then, it has released more than 15 games with diverse publishers such as Atari, Avanquest, BHV, Bigben Interactive, Mindscape, Ubisoft.

SkyFallen Entertainment was a Russian computer game and middleware developer, that was founded in 2002 as a small studio, staff consisting only of few people with programming experience, expanding later to crew of more than 162 designers, artists and other specialists. As of 2012, the company ceased to exist.

Another Henk Rogers company- this time, the company is a legal holding company with worldwide rights (except for the former USSR) that sub-licenses the Tetris name and concept to other companies, including Henk Rogers' other two companies, Bullet-Proof Software and Blue Planet Software.
TriDigital Studio is an independent company which specializes in artwork, 3D graphics, animations and video cinematics. The company was founded in Moscow, Russia, in 2001.

Turn 10 Studios is a game development division of Microsoft Studios and it was established in 2001. It is located on the Microsoft Redmond, Washington premises and was created as a first-party developer for racing games. The studio has uniquely worked on the Forza Motorsport franchise, a licensed race simulation game series with four installments so far. The first game in the series was released in 2005. All Forza games are exclusive to the Xbox console, as a direct rival for Sony's Gran Turismo series.
Ubisoft Da Nang is a game development studio part of the Ubisoft group of companies. It is based in Đà Nẵng, Vietnam. It was established in June 2020.

Vector Unit Inc is an independent American game development studio founded by Ralf Knoesel (Technical Director) and Matt Small (Creative Director) in December 2007. The two got to know each other at Stormfront Studios many years before and worked together on some titles. The studio consists of a small internal team and works with outside contractors. The studio's first title, the arcade boat racer Hydro Thunder Hurricane, was released in the summer of 2010.

Vlambeer (Dutch for "bear in flames" or "bear on fire") is the independent studio of the Dutch developer Jan Willem Nijman. It was established on 1st September 2010. At first it consisted of Rami Ismail as well. During most of Vlambeer's history, Nijman was the main designer and Ismail was focused on programming and the business development. Initially they made flash games to gather funds for their own projects. These commissioned titles were tagged as developed by "Not Vlambeer" and often do not include traces of the Vlambeer names of the developers. Examples of these are Radical Fishing (2010, for Bored.com) and Dinosaur Zookeeper (2011, for Adult Swim). The developers often prototype new ideas and release them to get feedback from players. The first title released using the studio name was the freeware shooter Super Crate Box (2010). The team also made one of the three promotional indie games for Serious Sam 3: BFE (2011). Their take is called Serious Sam: The Random Encounter and it was released in October 2011. Other major titles by the studio are Ridiculous Fishing (2013), Gun Godz (2013), Nuclear Throne (2013) and Luftrausers (2014) all for a wide variety of platforms. After ten years, on 1st September 2020, the studio announced the upcoming Ultrabugs would be the studio's last title after which the studio will close its doors. On 4th April 2024 Nijman announced he bought Ismail's shared and was now the sole owner of the studio. He also stated wanting to preserve the classic Vlambeer games, and make sure they get the maintenance they need to stay playable far into the future.

Warp Inc. is a Japanese development studio founded by Kenji Eno in 1994. It is a continuation of his earlier work at his studio Eim Ltd. The company first approached The 3DO Company to work on games. Next to the titles credited here, the company also created Totsugeki Kikan! Megadasu!! (1994 - also appears to be known as Totsugeki Karakuri Megadasu!!), Trip'd (1995) and Oyaji Hunter Mahjong (1995), Short Warp (1996), Enemy Zero (1997), Real Sound: Kaze no Regret (1997 - a game without any visuals) and D-2 (1999). The company got known mostly through the D series. Real Sound was also envisioned as a franchise, but although a sequel was announced, it was never produced. D-2 was the company's last game due to troubled relations with SEGA where it was a second party developer. Another game was in development, but never completed. Eventually the company was renamed Superwarp and intended to enter the IT business, but that never took off. The company appears to have been closed eventually. In 2006 Kenji Eno announced to have started a new development company, From Yellow To Orange.

Attic was a German software developer founded in 1989 and closed in 2001. Attic was founded by Hans-Jürgen Brändle, Jochen Hamma and Guido Henkel in the German town of Albstadt. All were equal partners in terms of ownership over the company. The company's logo showed the silhouette of a bat and was probably chosen in accordance with the name because -- like many other IT-firms -- the company started out with a small number of people working in their own home which then grew into a fully-fledged business. The "golden" years The young company collaborated with Starbyte Software (another now defunct German software company) who owned the license of Germany's most popular pen-and-paper RPG "Das Schwarze Auge" ("The Dark Eye"). This lead to Attic developing the famous "Nordlandtrilogie" ("Northlandtriolgy"), known outside Germany as "Realms of Arkania: Blade of Destiny", "Realms of Arkania: Star Trail" and "Realms of Arkania: Shadows over Riva", a series of computer role-playing games based upon said franchise. The games were very successful, received good press reviews and were also translated internationally which is how a bigger audience than just the German RPG players was able to dwell in the world of Aventuria. Breaking up In a 2002 interview with German magazine "PC Games", Guido Henkel said that he had grown tired of making the same kind of game over and over again while the other members wanted to keep "milking" the popular "The Dark Eye" brand since they still saw potential profit in it. Due to the high cost of licensing the brand, the company barely made a profit on the games although they sold well. This lead to a disagreement about the company's strategy. Soon after Guido Henkel left Attic the company was said to "go downhill". Where are they now?  Guido Henkel left Attic for the USA were he met his future wife and focused on making games for mobile devices with his own company G3Studios. Hans-Jürgen Brändle passed away in 2005 in Las Vegas. Jochen Hamma still works in the games industry as a consultant, teacher and project leader. He educates students at the Berlin-based Games Academy and was the project leader on Spellbound Studios' PC games "Desperados 2" and its stand-alone Add-on "Helldorado".  The attic company website (www.attic.de) is now defunct and redirects to www.fantastic-realms.com which is hosted and owned by Jochen Hamma. The future of "The Dark Eye" As of 2006, a PC RPG based on "The Dark Eye" is being produced by German developer Radon Labs in Berlin. The game "Das Schwarze Auge: Drakensang" is considered to be the unofficial successor or sequel to the aforementioned trilogy and would be the fourth computer game based on the pen-and-paper RPG.

nDreams Ltd is a UK-based game development and product company established in October 2006 by Patrick O'Luanaigh, former creative director of Eidos. On 16 November 2023, the company was acquired by Aonic.

AdventureSoft Publishing used to be Adventure International UK in the early 1980's, which was in turn changed to Adventuresoft UK in 1986, when Adventure International in the US folded. In the late 80's and the early 90's they also published horror adventure games under the Horror Soft brand.

Agua MassMedia specializes in localization for the video game industry, providing the sector for services in translation, dubbing and beta testing. Ever since their formation in 1993, they have since handled over 200 projects, most of which were for the Spanish market.

Animation Arts was founded in 2003. As of December 2011, Animation Arts' studio is located in Halle, Germany, and their office is on the river bank of Saale. The managing director of the company is Marco Zeugner. The studio specializes in globetrotting point-and-click adventure games, such as Secret Files and Lost Horizon.

BattleGoat Studios is a Canadian Software Developer committed to developing leading edge “Intelligent Strategy Games” for the PC. Although Supreme Ruler 2010 is the first PC title they have developed, their game design history dates back to 1982. The design team firmly believes that Strategy Gamers are looking for more sophisticated games that also remain fun to play. BattleGoat insists that their approach to development will always emphasize an accurate, heavily researched environment assuring players an entertaining and immersive gameplay experience.

Escalation Studios is a game development studio founded in 2006 by Shawn Green and Tom Mustaine, and located in Texas (USA). The company's first project is the first-person shooter Severity, announced in December 2006 and developed in cooperation with John Romero. It was tailored for professional gaming for the eSports organization The CPL who licensed it to Escalation Studios. That organization however ceased operations in March 2008, but the game is said to be still in development. Since then Escalation has released the Wii game Samba De Amigo (2008), a remake of the Dreamcast title of the same name, developed together with Gearbox Software. Next was the iPhone title Dr. Awesome: Microsurgeon M.D.

Big Finish, Inc. is a product company founded by Chris Jones and Aaron Conners, both known for their work on the Tex Murphy detective series. The company's first title was the psychological thriller 3 Cards to Midnight, released in May 2009, and part of a planned series of games. The sequel, 3 Cards to Dead Time, was released in 2010. Also in pre-production is the game Secret Project: Fedora.

Black Shamrock is a game development studio founded in 2016 and based in Dublin, Ireland. The studio was co-founded by Olivier Masclef, formerly of Widescreen Games. On 23rd February 2017 Virtuos announced the company's acquisition through a controlling interest.

Blue Giraffe Games is a game development studio based in Eindhoven, the Netherlands. It was established on 9th January 2015. Many developers previously worked at GameHouse B.V. (formerly Real Games and Zylom).

A former internal Electronic Arts studio based in Cologne, Germany since 2000, Bright Future was formed as an independent studio in March 2006 by Gerald Köhler, Petr Vlcek and Thomas Schwan.  An EA Partner studio (which allows the company to trade technology with EA and use them in their own future independent ventures), Bright Future is mostly associated with the development of the Total Club Manager/FIFA Manager series.

Bugbear Entertainment is an independent game development studio located in Helsinki, Finland. The company was founded in March 2000 by Janne Alanenpää, Tatu Blomberg and a number of friends. It was initially funded by one of the producers / designers (Alanenpää's neighbour) at Carts Entertainment, a company that was closed soon after the release of Thrust Twist + Turn in 1999 and they still own Bugbear to this day. Many of the initial people at Bugbear knew each other since they were teenagers and worked together as the demoscene group Byterapers. Bugbear exclusively creates racing games and its first release was Rally Trophy for JoWooD in 2001. The first game the studio worked on was Hat Trick Hockey, not a racing game, but it was never released. After Tough Trucks: Modified Monsters in 2003, the studio became best known for the FlatOut arcade racing series. They released FlatOut in 2004, FlatOut 2 in 2006 and FlatOut: Ultimate Carnage in 2007. When the franchise's publisher Empire Interactive collapsed, the rights to the series were lost and sold to Strategy First who had other development studios create further games in the series. Meanwhile Bugbear had also created Glimmerati for N-Gage in 2005 and on the PSP SEGA Rally Revo for SEGA in 2007. Bugbear then turned its racing expertise to the Ridge Racer series for Namco Bandai Games. They created Ridge Racer Unbounded (2012) as well as the free-to-play game Ridge Racer Driftopia (2013). In February 2013 Next Car Game was announced, a new racing title and the first independent release for the studio. After launching a tentative funding initiative in September, they launched a full Kickstarter crowd funding campaign in November. As the $350,000 goal would not be reached, they cancelled the campaign at the end of the month and took it to the Steam distribution portal where it was released in the Early Access program. It was released fully in 2018 as Wreckfest. On 14 November 2018, Bugbear Entertainment was acquired by THQ Nordic.

column1: China West Coast Tech Co., Ltd.

column2: Contraband Entertainment, Inc. was formed by a group of experienced game development professionals. Created to be a "Fresh Start", Contraband has gathered some of the best game designers, artists and programmers from along the last decade. Project leads at Contraband have anywhere from six to eighteen years of game development under their belts.  Contraband principal Rebecca Heineman has been involved in game development for over eighteen years, a career ranging from the Atari 2600 to Windows XP and modern consoles. With dozens of completed games to their names, and the hard-earned experience from their past work, Contraband management and Production staff have "The right stuff" for game development in the 21st century. Contraband develops original game titles. Starting from a blank page, Contraband is experienced at developing new games from internal designs and external concepts. Project Manager and Designers at Contraband are adept at the task of creating comprehensive Game Design Guides, Story References, and Technical Design Documents.  Attention to detail, careful planning and passion for the game concept lead to well designed, fun games that beat the trend of poorly planned, over-late and over budget creations.  Contraband Entertainment, Inc. takes pride in the vast array of consoles and operating systems it can develop games for. Here are a few:   Mac OS X   Windows XP   X-BOX   Nintendo GameCube   Sony Playstation 2   Game Boy Advance   Game Boy Color  Source: Selected articles from Contraband Entertainment Official Company Website - Company Info

Crafts & Meister Co., Ltd. is a game development studio based in Osaka, Japan. The company was established in June 2004 by Capcom veterans Noritaka Funamizu and Katsuhiro Sudo, and as of May 2011 employs 51 people.

We are a sound design, editorial, and mixing company specializing in feature films while also designing for commercials, television, games, and other short form projects. In addition, we offer transfer between most analog and digital formats as well as video and audio digitization for multimedia.  Our library, which features over 120,000 sound effects - many custom recorded - is accessible directly via a 100Mbps network to all of our spotting and editing workstations.  We have built in effect audition and automated transfer capabilities into our centralized show spotting database to streamline our creative audio process as much as possible.  Source: Selected articles from Danetrack Official Website - Our Company http://www.danetracks.com/pages/company.html

column1: DigiPen Institute of Technology Europe-Bilbao S.L.

column2: Drakhar Studio in a game development studio based in Spain and established in 2010 by Moisés Otero and Luis Torres García. They met at university in 1995 and shared the dream of developing games. However, they both went on to work as software engineers at an R&D company, but when that company filed for bankruptcy, they took the leap to establish their game studio. They started a small office in the basement of a building similar to a garage lent by one of their parents and convinced some friends to join to work in art and design. Currently they operate out of two offices: one in Alcobendas, Madrid and one in Santa Cruz de Tenerife. The team started with mobile games such as Frantic Flight (2012) and Pea Guitar Rock (2013) and later branched out to titles on console and PC with games such as the Wii U title The Grumpy Reaper (2013) and their first multiplatform title Ginger: Beyond the Crystal (2016). Later titles are all based on popular, established franchises such as PAW Patrol: Mighty Pups - Save Adventure Bay! (2020), PAW Patrol: The Movie - Adventure City Calls (2021) and Hotel Transylvania: Scary-Tale Adventures (2022). They still create mobile games such as Los Rodríguez y el Más Allá (2019). The team works on advergames and general apps as well.

Eastridge Technology is a computer software development firm located in Princeton, New Jersey.  Founded in 1985, the firm has completed over 100 software projects. Recent projects include the following: * Internet databases for consumer electronics devices. Jshrink: Java Shrinker and Obfuscator. Director to Java Translator. Computer based training software. Multimedia software for pharmaceutical companies. Source: Selected articles from Eastridge Technology Official Website - About Eastridge Technology http://www.e-t.com/about.html
Easy Tech is a game company from China, specializing in turn-based military strategy games for mobile platforms. Easy Tech has been developing games for more than ten years.
Evryware was a development company founded by brothers Dave and Barry Murry who had been creating computer games together since 1979.

Exigent is a game outsourcing company established by Paul Steed, Garland Wong and Jesse Rapczak. The global office is based in Encinitas, California (USA). Art development is done at its two divisions: Exigent Game Art Pvt. Ltd. (India) and Exigent Computer Software (Shanghai) Inc. (China). The main company is sometimes also referred to as Exigent Holdings. The only games where art is associated with this main office are those where the credits do not clarify which division worked on the game.

Exis is an independent game development and art outsource studio. It was founded in 2003 by Peter Kojesta, and is located in Towson Maryland. The company is credited on games such as Fracture, FEAR 3, Xcom:Enemy Unknown, Bioshock Infinite, and Majestic-12.

Flagship was an independent developer funded by Capcom, Nintendo and SEGA, that was founded by game designer Yoshiki Okamoto on 24 April 1997. They created scenarios for new and existing games, and have developed for Nintendo several times for the Game Boy Color, Game Boy Advance and GameCube. They have worked on the Onimusha, Resident Evil and Zelda franchises. The company worked under Capcom. In May 2007, it was announced Flagship would be consolidated. It was merged into Capcom and then dissolved by the beginning of June.

column1: Flying Wild Hog Sp. z o.o.
column2: Flying Wild Hog is a Polish game development studio based in Warsaw. It was established in April 2009 by Tomasz Baran, Michał Szustak and Klaudiusz Zych. The team developed its own 3D engine called RoadHog. In September 2011 the studio released its first title, the fast-paced first-person shooter Hard Reset. It was expanded with the free DLC Hard Reset: Exile in 2012 and then brought together as Hard Reset: Extended Edition. In September 2013 a second title was released, a reboot of the Shadow Warrior franchise as Shadow Warrior. Two additional studios were opened - Krakow in 2016 and Rzeszów in 2018. As of 18 November 2020, the company is part of the Embracer Group through the Plaion operative group.

Frictional Games is an independent game development company located in Helsingborg, the south of Sweden. It was co-founded by Thomas Grip and Jens Nilsson. They created their own 3D engine: HPL.  The studio is known for its Penumbra horror franchise, a series of games that originated out of a tech demo for their 3D engine. The games combine elements from classic adventure games with a dynamic environment based on a physics engine and a 1st-person action setting largely based on stealth. Two games have been released so far, Overture (2007) and Penumbra: Black Plague (2008) (as well as the expansion Requiem). In September 2008 the company announced it was working on a new survival horror game set in the 18th century. This was later revealed to be Amnesia: The Dark Descent. After three years of development, it was finally released on September 8, 2010.

GameHouse Spain, SL is a Spanish division of GameHouse, Inc. based in Alicante, Spain, Europe. The division is often involved with testing. The team's first game they developed themselves is Sally's Salon: Kiss & Make-Up (2018).
Gameloft New Zealand Limited was a game development studio of Gameloft S.A., based in Auckland, New Zealand. It was established in 2010. In January 2016 it was reported the studio has been closed.
Hamumu Software is a small games development company that was founded in 1988 by Mike Hommel to market his games. In 2014 it is based in Anza, California.
Ironhide Game Studio is a Uruguayan game development studio established in 2010 by Alvaro Azofra, Pablo Realini and Gonzalo Sande.

K-D LAB was established in 1995 to develop games for the PC platform. In fall 1996 a publishing agreement for the Vangers title was signed with Buka Entertainment, a national game publisher, where they stood as licensor, selling the rights to an international publisher. Buka also funded the development. In parallel with long-term projects, K-D Lab also created some small-scale logic games in order to test their game ideas. In late 1996 their game called Brainy Ball got Second Prize ($10000) at ENIX Internet Entertainment Contest, a worldwide contest of entertainment software held in Japan by Enix Corporation, the famous console game developer. In July 2000 K-D LAB had became a long-term business partner of the biggest Russian software publisher and distributor, 1C Company. A publishing agreement to develop a full-scale unique RTS game Perimeter for the world-wide market was signed between K-D LAB and 1C. Perimeter was published by the 1C Company in CIS and Baltic region, and the company Codemasters became the world publisher.

column1: Konami Computer Entertainment Sapporo Co., Ltd
column2: Konami Computer Entertainment Sapporo (コナミコンピュータエンタテインメント札幌) was a development studio based in Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan. It was established by Konami in March 1997 at the same time as studios in Nagoya and Yokohama. In August 2000, it was merged with the Yokohama studio, becoming Konami Computer Entertainment Studios, but the Sapporo studio was split back off and merged into Hudson Soft in December 2001, ceasing to exist as a distinct entity.

Telltale Games is the trading name of the US company LCG Entertainment. It is based in Malibu, California and was established on 27th December 2018. LCG acquired the rights to much of the intellectual property owned by Telltale, Inc. that filed for assignment in October 2018 and were forced to shut down and sell off assets. LCG acquired the branding, games, and game licenses and announced in August 2019 they would be bringing the old Telltale Games titles back. The studio's first new release was The Expanse: A Telltale Series in August 2023, continuing the tradition of narrative-driven game experiences.
Level 77 Pty Ltd is an Australian development studio that trades as Blowfish Studios.
Lion Entertainment, Inc. was based in Austin, Texas. Founded in 1993, the company created original games for the 3DO and ported PC and 3DO titles to the Macintosh. It was dissolved in 1999.

LionHead Studios was founded by Peter Molyneux, Mark Webley, Tim Rance and Steve Jackson in July 1997, coming from Bullfrog Productions. The company was headquartered in Surrey, England. Around 2000, the company started offering companies to become a Lionhead satellite studio, to work on games under guidance of Lionhead as a main company:  Big Blue Box Studios (eventually merged into Lionhead) Intrepid Computer Entertainment Ltd. (until October 2004) Black & White Studios (separate division, not really a satellite studio)  So far, the company has worked with three franchises: the strategical god games in the Black & White series, the Fable RPGs, and the creative film industry simulation The Movies. On 6th April 2006, the company was acquired by Microsoft Game Studios. Since then, the Fable franchise has been continued with Fable II in October 2008. In January 2012 CTO Tim Rance left the company to establish the game development studio 22Cans. In March of that year Peter Molyneux announced to follow him there. They work together with Peter Murphy, who also was with Lionhead until around 2008. On 7 March 2016, Microsoft announced that development on Fable Legends was ceased and a proposed closure was confirmed. It was officially closed on 29 April 2016.

MGM Interactive, a unit of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. (NYSE: MGM), manages business development and production of interactive products for a variety of multimedia platforms, as well as talent and developer relationships.

Founded in 1995, Minds Eye Productions is located in the United Kingdom. They are mostly known for providing game testers by contract to major developers and publishers. They have been developing games for the OpenTV platform for a number of years. They also have the capabilities of porting games from one platform to another and provide this service to their clients. In 2005, Minds Eye was acquired by Disney. This was a natural move because they had a hand in the development of 7 Disney games.

Mistwalker was founded in 2004 by former Square Executive Vice President,  Hironobu Sakaguchi, after he was ousted from Square for producing the animated movie, Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within, which was a box office disaster. Mistwalker is financially backed by Microsoft Game Studios, who has been trying to capture a greater market share in Japan with their Xbox consoles, which has been a weak point for Microsoft due to a lack of RPGs (a popular genre in Japan) developed for the Xbox consoles. Mistwalker designs and writes scenarios for RPGs, what Hironobu Sakaguchi is best known for. They outsource the programming and coding of games to other companies. The company created two Xbox 360 exclusive RPGs for Microsoft, Blue Dragon (2006) and Lost Odyssey (2007). Both were received fairly well. In December 2008 it was announced a third RPG, Cry-On, was cancelled. Half of the scenario had already been written, but a year and a half to two years of additional development was still needed at the time of cancellation.

NaturalMotion Games is the games publishing division of NaturalMotion, known for the middleware technology Morpheme and Euphoria. On 30 January 2014, Zynga announced the acquisition of NaturalMotion for $527 million in cash and equity.

NeoBards Entertainment Ltd. is an independent game developer founded in February 2017. The company set up headquarters in Hong Kong and studios in Taipei and Suzhou, developing games across multiple platforms including PC, console, and mobile. NeoBards is most known for collaborating with publishers such as Capcom, working on co-dev projects such as Resident Evil Re:Verse, Resident Evil:Resistance, and remasters including Resident Evil Origins Collection, Onimusha:Warlords, and the Devil May Cry HD Collection. They have also worked on character skill design and implementation with Square Enix for Marvel’s Avengers.

Nintendo's Research and Development division 3 (R&D3) was formed in the 1980's.  Genyo Takeda  has always held the general manager position since the development team's founding.  This team is the smallest R&D team that Nintendo has. It usually makes whatever it can to help Nintendo along with its bigger projects, such as the battery backup for the NES, or making the Nintendo 64 controller. They also made some games in its early stages, such as Mike Tyson's Punch-Out, StarTropics, and many sports games Nintendo released. Most of R&D3's game were targeting the American market, and sold poorly or were excluded from release in Japan. Sine they assisted with Pilotwings 64, they have not developed any games, but they have focused more on hardware. Nintendo has recently also moved all software designers/programmers to Nintendo's EAD In 2000, they were renamed to Nintendo's Integrated Research & Development division (Nintendo IRD).
Paradox Arc is a publishing label of Paradox Interactive AB for games developed externally by smaller studios.
Realtime Games Software Ltd. consisted of Andrew Onions and Ian Oliver. They were still studying in Leeds (UK) when they presented their first game 3D Tank Duel in 1984.
The Research Centaur is the QA division of The Behemoth.
Formed partially by former Dempa employees, Rutubo has continued in the same tradition of making quality arcade conversions, mainly for Sega.

Secret Exit Game Development (Skinflake Games until 2006) is the official name for the tAAt development team. The early games were distributed with the tAAt name, but later they changed it to Skinflake Games, and eventually Secret Exit Game Development, although tAAt still exists.
Sekai Games is the publishing subsidiary for consoles of Sekai Project, established on June 7th 2018
Shiny Shoe is a game development studio founded in 2011 and based in San Francisco, USA.

Silicon Knights, Inc. was founded in 1992 in Ontario, Canada, by Denis Dyack. In 1998, they were signed by Nintendo as a second-party developer. They created two games for them and ended the contract in 2004. They partnered with Microsoft Game Studios in 2005 to develop the Too Human trilogy of games. Nintendo still held stock in the company. From 2007 to 2012, the company was involved in a legal battle with Epic Games, with Silicon Knights claiming they withheld features and documentation of Unreal Engine 3 from licensees so that Epic could focus on their own games while gaining income from external licenses. Epic Games quickly countersued Silicon Knights for attempts at making changes to the engine and presented it as their own, contrary to the license agreement. Epic would ultimately win the case, and Silicon Knights would have to pay US$ 4.45 million. On 16 May 2014, the company filed for bankruptcy.

Simutronics Corporation was founded in 1987. Incorporated in Virginia, Simutronics has offices in the St. Louis, Missouri and Washington, DC areas with more than 300 employees and contractors around the world. The company is privately held. Simutronics is one of the pioneers of the multiplayer online gaming experience. The company started off with GemStone II on GEnie, in the late 80's, which quickly evolved into GemStone III, a pay for play MUD type game. Their next game was CyberStrike which became Game of the Year in 1993 as an online graphical "mech" game, the first of its type. Simutronics capitalized on its Interactive Fiction Engine that ran GemStone III by developing DragonRealms, Modus Operandi (in partnership with Time-Warner) and Hercules and Xena: Alliance of Heroes. Many of these games continue to be available at Simutronics' web site (www.play.net), and have loyal fans. In 1998, Simutronics made its foray into 3D accelerated games by teaming with Publisher 989 (soon to be Verant Interactive / Sony) and putting out CyberStrike 2, a mech game that recreated the excitement of the original game. The latest in the Gemstone saga is GemStone IV, which they state is "the longest-running text-based game in the industry". Their current project is Hero's Journey, a 3D massively multiplayer online roleplaying game (MMORPG).
SingleTrac Entertainment Technologies was a game developer founded by Todd Kelly in Salt Lake City, Utah. GT Interactive acquired SingleTrac in Oct. 1997.

Slightly Mad Studios Limited is a development studio founded by Ian Bell. On 12th January 2009 it was announced Slightly Mad had bought the business and assets of Blimey! Games Ltd., also established by Ian Bell, as it was insolvent and unable to survive on its own following the insolvency of 10tacle studios AG, which was then the parent company. In March 2011 the establishment of the Gamagio division was announced, to develop mobile, social and browser games.
Snapshot Games Inc. is a company founded on 12th November 2013 in California, USA. It is the US office to the main development studio Snapshot Games Sofia based in Sofia, Bulgaria.

Soft Machine (ソフトマシン) was started in 1989. Pengo programmer Akira Nakakuma  (中隈章) was the CEO; Shinichi Oomori (大森信一) was the director. The company has developed, or assisted in the development of, games for many platforms including Famicom/NES, Game Boy, Mega Drive/Genesis, PC Engine CD/TurboGrafx-CD, PlayStation, Super Famicom/Super NES, WonderSwan and WonderSwan Color

SPIDERS is a video game development studio producing its own creations as well as offering part or full productions for third parties. The company was born when several French video game veterans worked together on the creation of the Silverfall game and its add-on, and decided to pursue the adventure together. Although the company is mainly specialized in the design and development of action/RPG games, owing to previous experience, it also has the capacity to provide solutions in different genres. The company was an official developer for the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 platforms. SPIDERS' first title is the action RPG Mars. They also created the Silk Engine, based on Sony's PhyreEngine.

Stoic is an independent game development studio based in Austin, Texas (USA) and it was first announced on the company website on 13 February 2012. It was established by Alex Thomas (design, animation, writing), Arnie Jorgensen (art) and John Watson (programming) who formerly worked at BioWare on Star Wars: The Old Republic. They are best known for the The Banner Saga series of tactical role-playing games.
TabTale d.o.o. is the Serbian game development studio of TabTale.
The Studio of Secret6, Inc. is the production studio of Secret 6, Inc. and is based in Manila, Philippines.

Turtle Rock Studios is a US game development studio founded in March 2002 by Michael Booth. The company initially worked on several Counter-Strike versions independently. These include the Xbox version (2003), the reworked Counter-Strike: Condition Zero (2004) and various maps for Counter-Strike: Source (2004). Booth was also responsible for the game's official AI bot. On 20 November 2006, the studio announced its first entirely original title, the co-op multiplayer shooter Left 4 Dead. On 10 January 2008, the studio was acquired by Valve Corporation and renamed Valve South. The team worked together with the main Valve team to complete the game. It was released in November 2008. In June 2009, it was confirmed Valve South no longer operated as an office. Several members moved to Bellevue, Washington including Booth. The sequel Left 4 Dead 2, released in November 2009, was developed entirely by the main Valve development team without involvement of Valve South. On 5th February 2010 the studio's website was relaunched and new owners Chris Ashton and Phil Robb announced to have reformed the company once again as Turtle Rock Studios with the remaining developers. In June 2010 the establishment of Turtle Rock Garage was announced, a division focused on casual and experimental games for platforms such as iPhone, Facebook and Xbox Live. On 26th May 2011 THQ announced to have signed the studio's next major title. Described as a shooter, THQ first revealed the game's name as Wild in June 2011. In March 2012, THQ trademarked the name Evolve, and it was later revealed Evolve is most likely the new name for the project. When THQ closed down in January 2012 and auctioned off its portfolio, Take-Two Interactive Software purchased the publishing rights for $11 million. Turtle Rock attempted to buy the IP as well, but its $250,000 offer was outbid by Take-Two. On 17 December 2021, Tencent Holdings announced the acquisition of the company.
WD Encore Software, LLC is the current parent company or license holder of Brøderbund, Hoyle Gaming, Punch! Software, Punch! CAD, and Viva Media.

WXP Games, LLC is a game development studio based in Seattle, Washington (USA). It also operated under the name WXP, Inc. (at least until 2006). WXP is short for The Whole Experience. The company was established around 1995 or 1996 by Jeff Connelly and Sky Kensok. Initially it operated out of Connelly's basement in Spokane, but in 1997 it was moved to Seattle where it still resides today. In 2011 the management team consists of Darren Schoen (Technical Director), Lyndon Sumner (Creative Director), and Patrick Moynihan (Studio Director).

The Russian (Moscow) branch of the Superscape company. The branch is a team of professionals, in which the main part of the Superscape development resource is concentrated. The main activities are the direct development and porting of games to various phone models.

Headquartered in Tokyo, Japan, ZeniMax Asia K.K. is a wholly owned subsidiary of ZeniMax Media Inc. ZeniMax Asia publishes original interactive entertainment content for consoles, the PC, and handheld/wireless devices throughout Asian territories. The publishing operations were announced on 28th April 2008 and the division is headed by Tetsu Takahashi. Titles are published under the Bethesda Softworks brand.

Founded in 1996 by Doug Boyes and Dave Boardman, 2db Music Productions was initially based in Wilmslow, Cheshire. 2dB recently relocated to Hertford, Hertfordshire.  Other scores by 2dB include:   Hogs Of War (Infogrames)   Viper (Ocean)   Wetrix (Ocean)   Space Race (Warner Bros.)   Asterix (I-Ocean)   Wacky Races (Infogrames)   Eagle One (Harrier Attack) (Infogrames)   Dragonseek (Children’s Television Workshop)   Loon’s ‘Fight For Fame’ (Warner Bros.)   Loon’s ‘Back In Action (Warner Bros.)   Super Monkey Ball Adventure (Sega)   Chicken Invaders III (Interaction Studios)
Abyss Lights Studio is a computer graphics and video games production company based in Kiev, Ukraine. It was established in January 2002.
Amuse, Inc. (アミューズ)  is a Japanese entertainment broadcasting company based in Tokyo, which specializes in the creation of multimedia based around existing artists, turning their work into products.

Arsys Software was established in November 1985 by a group of former Technosoft staff. Their first game, Wibarm, was released in 1986, and in the following years the company produced a number of titles, including Star Cruiser (1988) and Knight Arms (1989), as well as ports of titles such as Prince of Persia, Tenka Tōitsu, and Spindizzy II. By July 1996, the company consisted of only Kotori Yoshimura and a handful of other staff, and the company's name changed to Cyberhead. Cyberhead contributed to the development of several titles, including Gran Turismo and Omega Boost, but eventually closed in 2001.
Artematica is an Italian game developer based in Chiavari, region of Liguria. The company was founded in 1996 by Riccardo Cangini. They mainly focus on sports and adventure games.

British company famous for unique action/puzzle games such as Vaxine, The Assembly Line was also famous for excellent programming that was technically much more competent than most of its contemporaries. Its games were always very smooth, eminently playable, and pushes the capabilities of yesterday's computers to their limits. Although better known in the Commodore 64 and later Amiga circle, many of their games have also been ported to the PC and achieved modest success. Most of their games were published by US Gold.  Developers include Andy Beveridge, Adrian Stephens, Martin Day, John Dale.

Bilibili Inc. is the main holding company for Chinese video sharing website Bilibili, located in the Cayman Islands. This entry should not be credited unless no subsidiary is specific. Subsidiaries:   Bilibili HK Ltd. (Hong Kong)   Hode HK Ltd. (Hong Kong)   ﹂ Shanghai Bilibili Technology Co., Ltd. (China)   ﹂ Shanghai Kuanyu Digital Technology Co., Ltd. (China)   ﹂ Shanghai Hode Information Technology Co., Ltd. (China)   ﹂ Wuhu Sharejoy Network Technology Co., Ltd. (China)   Bilibili Co., Ltd. (Japan)

Burut Creative Team (aka Burut CT) is a Russian company in the field of PC game development. It was founded at the end of 1999. Development on its first game, the RPG Heath: The Unchosen Path, was started with a team of five people. The game was published in March 2001. The company owns several development studios, a sound production department, animation, localization and programming studios. In late 2004 the studio established the separate company World Forge focused on the development of real-time strategy games.

CING was a game development studio based in the Chuo ward of Fukuoka, Japan. It was established in April 1999 by a group of former Riverhill Soft staff, and was a subsidiary of contract developer giant TOSE. The company was well-known for its adventure games. CING filed for bankruptcy in March 2010.

Cascadia Games is a game development studio. Until 2018 it also used the divisions / brands / labels Retro Phone Games and 2D Ferocity. In 2012 it was described by member Chris Jorgensen as a loose collective of six creative people hailing out of Portland (USA). On 5th May 2009 they released the TGB Kart Kit for the Torque game engine. The kit allows for the fast development of kart-like racing games on iOS and PC using the Mode 7 technique. The kit was a prominent revenue source and they used to complement each update with it with a new game, like Zombie Karts and Cascadia Kart. They eventually licensed the rights to Apogee's Wacky Wheels and released the remake Wacky Wheels HD in 2017. Other early games the studio is known for are Cavorite and Cavorite 2. This eventually led to more 2D-scrolling platform shooters like the 2-bit Cowboy games (2014-2016), Ammo Pigs: Armed and Delicious (2018) and Mighty Aphid (2020). The studio is currently developing Bay Lynx and launched a Kickstarter project to fund Moon Raider.

Catalyst Outsourcing Limited is a UK based Game Production Services Company offering solutions for all aspects of videogame development, formed in March 2008. It is headed up by Ivan Davies. Catalyst offers a range of game development services; from the creation of art assets to the full project management of a game, and from the creation of presentation materials to full platform conversions.

Con Artists Productions was the name Chris Condon used to develop his online flash games, most notably The Last Stand. On 27th May 2008 he announced to have joined Armor Games where he is making games full time.

column1: EA World Wide Motion Capture Studio
column2: The Electronic Arts Worldwide Motion Capture Studio is located on the "EA Campus" in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada near Vancouver.

Eclipse Entertainment was the company responsible for the open source 3D Engine Genesis3D. On 25th October 1999 WildTangent announced the acquisition of the company. The Eclipse development team relocated to WildTangent's Redmond headquarters to fuse the engine with WildTangent’s web driver.

Eternal Dream Arabization is a localization studio that began as a grassroots community of hobbyists, brought together by a shared love for localization with the aim of setting a better standard. As their efforts started rapidly gaining recognition by the local community, the scope of our ambitions grew. The experience they built soon paved the way for their professional debut. Since 2019, they've been successfully collaborating with developers, publishers, and agencies in capturing the hearts and minds of MENA players, pushing for the quality they believe Arabic speaking audiences deserve at each step of the way. Their Arabic game localizations include Return of the Obra Dinn, Tunic, Dicey Dungeons, Goodboy Galaxy, Post Void, and more.

Flaregames is a German mobile game development and publishing studio based in Karlsruhe, Germany, and founded in 2011. On 18th April 2012 Keen Flare GmbH was announced, a joint subsidiary between developer keen games GmbH & Co. KG and Flaregames to develop mobile games. Keen games holds an 49% interest, Flaregames 51%. On August 02, 2016, Flaregames announced its acquisition of Kopla Games, following their partnership on Nonstop Knight. Part of the deal was that Kopla Games remains completely operationally independent.

G5 Software is a Russian development studio founded in 2001 by Vlad Suglobov, Alexander Tabunov and Sergey Shultz. In 2002 the studio released its first title for PC, Red Shark, published by Buka Entertainment and subsequently licensed to more than 15 countries all over the world, including Japan, Germany, and the UK. The same year, G5 Software released its first title for Qualcomm BREW wireless platform, Fight Hard 3D, brought by Reaxion to Verizon Wireless, AllTel and U.S.Cellular in USA, and Telstra in Australia. Ever since, the company has been working on both mobile and PC games. In 2005 a group of Scandinavian investors acquires a stake in G5 and it then becomes part of the the Swedish holding company G5 Entertainment AB.

Gamesource is the European office of Virtuos Ltd. and it is based in Paris, France. It was established on 14th October 2004 as a partnership between Virtuos and Gamesource. The latter provides facilities and technical expertise to Virtuos which is represented in Europe by Gamesource CEO, Christophe Gandon. The two studios previously collaborated by porting the car racing game engine of Gamesource's sister company Babylon Software to the PSP.
Gameloft DAD Studio is studio of Gameloft S.A. based in Danang, Vietnam. It was established in 2010. It is the second Gameloft studio in Vietnam along with Gameloft Company Limited.

Gevo Entertainment Pte Ltd is a Singapore based developer. The company was founded as G-Gadget Pte Ltd in 2004 as a daughter company of Genki Co. Ltd.. It became independent on December 31, 2006 and since 2007 it has been known as Gevo Entertainment. Managing Director of the company is Tsunemi Akiyama.
Grey Box is a publishing label of Redux! Games, LLC
GroundStorm Studios is a US company known for the GGPO middleware technology.
Hexany Audio is a Los Angeles based game audio production studio specializing in custom sound design and music for games and interactive media.
Homegrown Games is a label of Johann Ertl HRMC Project Management.

The Infogrames publishing label was relaunched on 23 April 2024 by Atari SA (itself called Infogrames until 2009) to publish games which "fall outside the core portfolio of IP associated with the Atari brand". Atari's COO Geoffroy Châteauvieux was appointed as the manager of the revived Infogrames label.

InnoGames is a game development studio with its headquarters in Hamburg, Germany. It was founded in 2007 to handle the operation and continued development of the game Tribal Wars. The browser game started as a hobby project for the brothers Eike Klindworth and Hendrik Klindworth who made it together with Michael Zillmer. The game was first launched in June 2003. A second world was introduced in 2004 and by 2005 it had 50,000 players. Because of the growth the three developers decided to work on the project full-time from that year on and in 2007 the company was officially established. In 2012 the company employs more than 200 people and the Korean subsidiary InnoGames Korea Ltd. was opened on 1st April 2010. In May 2010, the investor group Fidelity Growth Partners Europe (FGPE) joined InnoGames with a minority share. In 2012 the browser game Forge of Empires was launched. Other titles by the company are Grepolis, Lagoonia, The West, and West Wars. The studio currently pursues cross-platform play with mobile apps and intends to launch a new game called Kartuga in 2013, which was canceled before it's release. In 2014 the browser game Tribal Wars 2 was released.

Jetpack Interactive is a game development studio founded in 2011 and based in Vancouver, Canada. The principals of the company previously founded the studios Black Box Games, Deep Fried Entertainment and United Front Games between 1998 and 2007.
Lilith Games (莉莉丝游戏) is a Chinese game developer based in Shanghai, China.

Lobotomy Software was an American game development studio especially known for Powerslave (Exhumed in Europe) and their SEGA Saturn ports of Quake and Duke Nukem 3D. The studio was established in 1993 with a number of former employees of Nintendo of America for the creative side and from Manley & Associates for the engineering side. It originally operated out of the apartment of co-founder Paul Lange. Lobotomy was eventually acquired by Crave Entertainment in 1998 and renamed Lobotomy Studios. The team worked on a Caesar's Palace gambling game on the Nintendo 64, but after a year of development the game was postponed and eventually cancelled. At that point Lobotomy Studios was closed and employees were let go or given the option to be relocated to another position at Crave. The next title the team would have worked on was a sequel to Powerslave. Crave did however not acquire all talent with the takeover in 1998. Some employees chose not to make the transition, including Ezra Dreisbach (creator of Death Tank) who went on to find work at Snowblind Studios and currently works at Flat Games.
Microids Life is a publishing label of Microids SA.
Molok is a multilingual game, movie & digital localization and post-production company based in Milan, Italy.

Moonshark was established in 2012 and funded, produced, marketed and published mobile entertainment properties. On 22nd August 2014 Hitcents announced the company's acquisition and its intention to integrate Moonshark into Hitcents’ San Francisco, Shanghai, and Bowling Green offices.
Muse Games Corp. is a game development company specializing in multiplayer browser games. The company was established in November 2006 by Brian Kehrer and Austin Lane in New York City (USA).
A Russian company (Voronezh) developing computer games. The company specializes in the production of 3D first-person shooters.

Pieces Interactive was a game development company situated in Skövde, a small city in the midst of Sweden. The company was founded in 2007 by 9 people. The company's history goes back several years prior to starting the business, as a team of former students graduating from Sweden's game development educations. The company's first title was a puzzle game called Puzzlegeddon, released in November of 2008. The studio experimented with several different games within a multitude of genres, including Fret Nice, Leviathan: Warships, Kill to Collect: Gid Gud and Die Trying and Magicka 2. After being acquired by THQ Nordic GmbH in August 2017, the studio developed two expansions for the hack n' slash action RPG Titan Quest: Anniversary Edition, as well as the second reboot of Alone in the Dark. The studio was closed on 17 June 2024.

The company was founded as Piranha Bytes Software GmbH in 1997 in Germany. The team became known internationally because of the Gothic and Risen RPG series. In 1999, the company became a wholly-owned subsidiary of Phenomedia. The company itself is now defunct, but all the assets, trademarks and most of the staff were moved to Pluto 13 GmbH when it was founded in September 2002. Although Pluto 13 was now the actual company, Piranha Bytes was still used as a label and the moniker of the development studio. After the release of Gothic 3 in 2006, the development team split from JoWood, their publisher at the time. Pluto 13 and Piranha Bytes now no longer own the name Gothic and the franchise itself, which was officially confirmed on 6th June 2007. The team went on to develop Risen, the spiritual successor to the Gothic series, which was released in 2009. The series was continued with two sequels Risen 2: Dark Waters in 2012 and Risen 3: Titan Lords in 2014. 2017 saw the release of the post-apocalyptic RPG Elex. In 2019, THQ Nordic fully acquired the company and reincorporated it into Piranha Bytes GmbH. On 8 July 2024, Polish video game news/review website CD-Action reported that the company ceased operations in June 2024.
Pixel Toys is a UK game development studio founded in 2012 by Andy Wafer and Alex Zoro.

Progressive Media is a developer of games for mobile devices. Since 2002, the company has worked with leading game publishers, hardware manufacturers, mobile network operators and media companies on bringing original as well branded mobile games to market.
Project Soul is an internal development team of Namco Bandai Games Inc., formerly Namco Limited, responsible for all the games in the Soul Blade/Edge/Calibur series.

Ravn Studio AS is an independent game development studio based in Drammen, Norway. It was established in 2002 by Stine Wærn and Tinka Town. The company is licensed to develop games for the Nintendo Wii and DS, Sony PSP, PlayStation 2 and PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360.

RingZero Game Studio is a game development and publishing studio and it is based in Thailand with a branch office in Seattle (USA). It is a division of RingZero Networks (Thailand) Co., Ltd., which has been active since 1997.

SEGA Studios Australia is a game development studio of SEGA and based in Fortitude Valley, Queensland (Australia). The studio was started in July 2002 as The Creative Assembly International Limited, the Australian division of the UK studio The Creative Assembly. On 9th March 2005 the SEGA Sammy group announced the acquisition of The Creative Assembly, also acquiring the Australian division. In December 2010 it was renamed SEGA Studios Australia. The Australian team first contributed to Rome: Total War (2004) and was then responsible for Medieval II: Total War (2006) and the expansion Medieval II: Total War - Kingdoms (2007). The three games are part of the Total War series The Creative Assembly has been working on since the release of the first game in 2000. The studio also created Stormrise (2009), a real-time strategy game in an entirely new franchise. In addition the team ported the games in the Nintendo DS Sonic Classic Collection (2010). Its first work as SEGA Studios Australia was London 2012 (2012). In April 2013 it was announced that the studio would be closed later in 2013.

Sega Rosso was a SEGA-owned development studio. The studio was established in March 1996 as Sega AM Division Annex, a splinter of AM3. The studio was headed by Ridge Racer and Sega Rally creator Kenji Sasaki. AM Annex would become Sega AM12 R&D Division in 1998, then Sega AM5 R&D Division in 1999 after several non-software divisions were shuffled around, but along with each of Sega's other development divisions, AM5 was spun off as an independent studio on April 21, 2000, taking the name Sega Rosso. As one of Sega's smaller studios, they only released a handful of titles, including Cosmic Smash and several racing games based on the Initial D manga and anime license. Sega Rosso was merged into Hitmaker in October 2003, and Hitmaker itself was merged back into Sega in July 2004. Sasaki left Sega in 2005 to establish the independent studio Bitster.
Zombie Cow Studios is the team name used by Dan Marshall and Ben Ward for their projects.

Skydance Interactive creates and publishes original and IP-based virtual reality and other immersive games. Skydance Interactive’s first VR game – the award-winning Archangel– launched in July 2017 to great fan acclaim, with its wildly successful update, Archangel: Hellfire debuting in July 2018.  Skydance Interactive partnered with Skybound Entertainment to create its award-winning VR game based on the global phenomenon The Walking Dead titled The Walking Dead: Saints and Sinners, which launched worldwide in January 2020 and has been nominated for awards like Best VR/AR Game by The Game Awards and PC Game of the Year by the Golden Joystick Awards.

Indian subsidiary of Electronic Arts, most often tasked with assistance to larger teams within the corporation. Originally positioned under PopCap Games, the company was rebranded as Slingshot Studio by 2023.

Soft Action (소프트액션) was a South Korean video game developer. The company was founded on November 1st, 1990, by Nam Sangkyu. They developed games primarily for the PC, most notably the Fox Ranger series. Early 2000's saw a shift to games aimed at children, and in 2003 Soft Action switched to mobile games before becoming defunct in an unspecified year late in the decade.
Soldak Entertainment, Inc. was founded by Steven Peeler in late 2004.

SouthEnd Interactive was a game development studio based in Malmö, Sweden. The company debuted with the Xbox exclusive Deathrow in 2002. Its final title was Sacred Citadel in 2013. A strained relationship between SouthEnd and publisher Koch Media on that last title led to the closure of the company in June 2013. The team of 24 people was hired entirely by Ubisoft to join its Swedish Massive Entertainment to work on the game Tom Clancy's The Division.

Sperasoft, Inc. is a US division of the Sperasoft group of companies. Registered in Wilmington, Delaware, most likely it is a company created for administrative purposes to work with US companies and is not involved with development, unlike Sperasoft Studio, LLC based in San Jose, California. When it is not clear which Sperasoft division is involved, or Sperasoft, Inc. is mentioned in general, this company entry is used. All Sperasoft companies were acquired by Keywords Studios on 13th December 2017.
Spry Fox is a game development studio established by Daniel Cook and David Edery in August 2010.

Standing Stone Games was formed in December 2016 from former Turbine staff working on massively multiplayer online (MMO) games. The company took over the maintenance and further development of Dungeons & Dragons Online and The Lord of the Rings Online, with Daybreak Game Company as the publisher.
Strange Girl Studios is an indie developer that makes adult, hentai, and NSFW games. The aim is to make naughty and lewd games that have actual gameplay alongside a consistent art style.
