Streamline Studios Malaysia Sdn Bhd is the Malaysian division of the Dutch company Streamline Studios. Based in Kuala Lumpur, it is mainly involved with art outsourcing. Later it was rebranded as Streamline Games offering external development partnerships for programming, porting and design. The art outsourcing was moved to a new division called All Pixels.
A South Korean game music studio established in 1999.

Studio Gobo is a UK game development studio founded in 2011 by Tony Beckwith, James Callin, Paul Ayliffe and Tom Williams. All four of them previously worked together at Black Rock Studio until Disney shut down the division. The initial studio was based in Hove. In 2015 a second studio was opened in Brighton.
Tequila Works is a game development studio in Madrid, Spain. It was founded in September 2009 by Raúl Rubio Munárriz and Luz Sancho Rodríguez.

column1: The Men Who Wear Many Hats LLC

column2: Think Garage Co., Ltd is a Japanese video game development studio founded in 2005.

Ubisoft Nano is a publishing label of Ubisoft Entertainment since 2020. It is used for a series of browser based party games with Ubisoft properties and it is an initiative of the Vietnamese division Ubisoft Da Nang.
VadimBallzGame is an independent title developer of games from the franchise, Super Vadimka

Vanillaware Ltd. is a Japanese game development studio established by George Kamitani. It was originally founded in February 2002 as Puraguru and that name was kept until Autumn 2004, when the company moved to the Kansai area. The studio was formed around the team at Atlus Co., Ltd. that was responsible for Princess Crown (1997) for the Saturn.

column1: Vile Monarch Sp. z o. o. Sp. k.

column2: Viriya Jaya Bersama is a game development company in Bandung, West Java, Indonesia that operates using the name Own Games.

Virtual Mechanix is an experienced outsourcing studio producing the highest quality 3D CG models & textures, visualisations and animations for PC, mobile, film and game console. Our main studio is in Brisabne, Australia with art teams in Asia and Europe. With over 15 years of international experience, using the best talent, our artists design and create some of the most exciting and accurate 3D vehicle models and assets for world renowned computer games for a variety of media; PC, console, mobile, TV and Film. Gaming credits include WRC7 Rally, TT Isle of Man: Ride on the Edge, CSR2 Racing and Project Gotham Racing.
Based in Brisbane, Australia, Wildfire Studios Pty. Ltd. began operations in 1995.  The company develops games for the PC.
ZeptoLab, OOO is a Russian game development studio incorporated on 5th July 2011. It is based in Moscow. The studio was originally founded in 2008 by the twins Efim Voinov and Semyon Voinov.

John Pickford and Ste Pickford left Binary Design Ltd. with two programmers to found Zippo Games in 1987. The company was later asked by Rare to develop NES games for them and eventually folded into the company becoming Rare Manchester. In 1990, John and Ste left the company and moved on to Software Creations Ltd..
Zoink Games AB was a game development studio based in Göteborg, Sweden. In 2020, it was merged into Thunderful Development AB alongside Image & Form International AB and Guru Games.

Zono was an independent game development studio established in 1991. The studio was named after its two founders, Ed Zobrist (Zo) and William Novak (No). A third partner was called Jeff Fort. The early years of the company focused on console game design, and in 1995 Zono grew into a full development shop for console and PC games. The company's client list included publishers such as Electronic Arts, SEGA and Psygnosis. The studio was closed circa 2005 and the assets were sold off wholesale to MumboJumbo, who used it to establish its MumboJumbo LA, but with no people of Zono involved except for David Eaton.
iXie Gaming is a division of Indium Software focused on game testing.
Kamibox is an independent German video game developer founded by Philipp Stollenmayer. He is the sole employee and mainly creates mobile games.

4X Technologies was a French company founded in 1997 by Emmanuel Forsans and Jérôme Larrieu. 4X was located in Paris and employed about 50 people at its peak. It specialized in the creation of middleware tools and is especially known for it Phoenix3D engine, which later became the foundation for Kylotonn Entertainment's Kt engine. Other tools include 4X Movie (movie compression for Windows, Macintosh, Dreamcast and Game Boy Advance games), Phoenix VR (tools package for 360° photo-realistic environments immersion), and the X3D engine. In September 2000 the internal game development division 4X Studio was created. The company had a third division called 4X Productions, doing similar work as 4X Studio, but not geared towards the games industry. The main company along with the divisions were closed in early 2003. Emmanuel Forsans went on to become the President of AFJV (Agence Francaise pour le Jeu Video), a video game agency.
ABA Games is the company of the independent Japanese game developer Kenta Cho.
Abrakam Entertainment is a game development studio based in Liège, Belgium.
A Finnish video game company specializing in porting games to Linux and Mac platforms.
AMEO Production is a music production company established by brother and sister Olivier Derivière and Marion Derivière. The formation was announced on 28th June 2010.

Particle Systems was a game development company formed in 1993 by industry veterans Michael Powell and Glyn Williams in the United Kingdom. The company specialized in science fiction games at the cutting edge of technology. The most well-known games from Particle were the Independence War series. In 2002 Particle Systems was acquired by Argonaut Software and subsequently renamed Argonaut Sheffield. The company closed in 2004 as did this division.

Artists Entertainment Limited is a Polish outsourcing company active since 2011. Service include 3D modeling, concept art, promo arts, special effects, 2D and 3D animations, illustration, 2D graphics. They also create music, sounds and spots.

Big Huge Games was founded in February 2000 by four veteran game developers: Tim Train, David Inscore, Jason Coleman, and Brian Reynolds. These founding partners previously worked on classic strategy titles such as Civilization II, Colonization, and Alpha Centauri. The company established the Rise of Nations strategy franchise, converted the Settles of Catan board game to the Xbox Live Arcade game Catan and developed The Asian Dynasties expansion for Ensemble Studios' Age of Empires III. In January 2008, THQ confirmed to have acquired the company, but put it up for sale again more than a year later. In May 2009, 38 Studios confirmed to have acquired the company. Founder Brian Reynolds did not move along and went to work at Zynga. Under the new ownership the studio developed the action RPG Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning. Published by Electronic Arts, it was released in February 2012. The game did not meet the intended number of sales and all staff of Big Huge Games as well as parent company 38 Studios was confirmed to have been laid off on 24 May 2012, closing the studio. In early June 2012, Michael Capps, president of Epic Games, confirmed the leadership of Big Huge Games came to Epic for help to keep the team together and found a new studio called Epic Baltimore. In February 2013 Epic founder Tim Sweeney confirmed that the company, renamed Impossible Studios in the meantime, had been closed. The members were offered the opportunity to reform the studio under the existing name. In October 2014, it was announced that the name and logo of Big Huge Games was acquired by Brian Reynolds and Tim Train at an auction held by Rhode Island state following the bankruptcy of 38 Studios. The new Big Huge Games is currently working on DomiNations, a mobile strategy game under development since mid-2013.

Bigpoint GmbH is a German online development studio. It was founded by Heiko Hubertz . In February 2010 the company announced to open a new studio in San Francisco (USA). At that point it already had four other offices, in Hamburg, Berlin, Malta and New York. The company hosts a game portal. In February 2010 it consisted of over 50 titles in 25 different languages. In 2012 it was announced they were working on Game of Thrones: Seven Kingdoms, an MMO, which was never released.

Boston Animation, Inc. was game developer headquartered in Stow, Massachusetts (USA). They provided a complete package of services that include programming, design, writing, localization as well as music and sound effects produced in their in-house studios. Most of the core game development (programming, design, art) was done at the division Boston Animation Ltd. based in Kiev.

Brizo Interactive was a mobile games studio founded by ex-Brezzasoft producer Yosh Jinno following that company's merger with Sun Amusement. Like Brezzasoft, it employed several ex-SNK employees, including King of Fighters programmer Souta Ichino and sprite artist Hiroto Kittaka. In the west, they're best known for their enhanced remakes of Double Dragon for Zeebo and iPhone, while in Japan they became known for original mobile spinoffs of the Shin Megami Tensei series. Following Brizo's shutdown, Shinyaku Last Bible series director Masaya Ichikawa would go on to develop the original mobile RPG El of Genesis.

Cardboard Computer is the name used for the games by the independent developer Jake Elliott, along with his friends such as Tamas Kemenczy. The first post on the Cardboard Computer website appeared on 12th May 2010.

column1: Chengdu Trias Digital Technology Co., Ltd.

column2: Colossal Order Ltd. is a Finnish game development studio founded in 2009, and currently located in Tampere. They specialize in business simulation and city-building games, with a big focus on public transportation.

Crate Entertainment is an independent development studio established around 2008. It initially consisted mainly of developers from Iron Lore Entertainment, including lead designer Arthur Bruno, who founded the studio after Iron Lore was closed down in 2008. Initially, the company did contract work for another studio in the area, but in 2009, Crate worked out a deal to use the engine and toolset used in the Iron Lore game Titan Quest and the expansion Titan Quest: Immortal Throne. The team is released Grim Dawn, an open world action RPG also partially funded through crowdfunding, in 2016. In 2022, their next title Farthest Frontier would enter early access.
Digital Legends Entertainment is a mobile game development studio based in Barcelona, Spain. It was founded in 2001. On 28th October 2021 Activision Publishing announced the studio's acquisition.

Burst was a development division of Virgin Interactive Entertainment based in Irvine, California and managed by Neil Young, Vice President of internal product development at VIE, and Christopher Yates, Vice President of technology and operations at VIE. On 17 August 1998, Electronic Arts bought the studio alongside Westwood Studios for $122.5 million, after Virgin Interactive struggled with financial difficulties. It was subsequently renamed to Westwood Pacific. While developing Nox, Westwood co-founder Brett Sperry approached the studio to develop Command & Conquer: Red Alert 2, himself supervising design. Following successful sales and reception, and after developing the Yuri's Revenge expansion pack, Westwood Pacific focused on Command & Conquer: Generals, which would bring the RTS series to a 3D engine.  By mid-2002, the company was rebranded as Electronic Arts Pacific. Shortly after releasing Generals, the company merged with Electronic Arts Los Angeles alongside remaining Westwood assets and willing staff after the latter's closure, in order to consolidate resources. Within the company, this team was occasionally referred to as the "RTS team" to differentiate from existing EALA staff who worked on titles like the Medal of Honor series.

column1: Flux Game Studio Jogos Digitais Ltda.

column2: Fork Particle is a computer graphics visual effects modeling and software development kit (SDK) developed and sold by Fork Particle, Inc. Fork Particle uses its real time particle system technology to simulate visual effects or particle effects such as CGI explosions, fire, rain, smoke, dust, etc. Fork Particle is used in video games and visual simulation software such as a flight simulator. It has been licensed to game developers for PC, Apple Mac, Linux, PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, Xbox One and PlayStation 4. Notable Fork Particle licensees include Ubisoft, Trickstar Games, Firaxis Games, Zenimax Online Studios, Electronic Arts, Microsoft, LEGO, and Sony. Video games that have utilized Fork Particle’s technology include Elder Scrolls Online, Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth, Rocksmith 2014 Edition, Empire Earth III, LEGO Universe, Splosion Man, and Sid Meier's Civilization V.
Game Audio Australia Pty Ltd. is an Australian company established in October 2006 when Mick Gordon of Lava Injection Studios and Andrew Curnock of Beat Therapy announced to merge their business.

GamecoStudios is a French game development and game art outsourcing studio providing services including concept art, illustration, 3D modeling, animation, trailers and full motion videos. It is the sister company of Game Consulting SARL.

Almanic Corp. was established in 1992 by a group of former Technos Japan employees and headed by former Enix designer Takashi Yoneda. The company changed names to Givro circa 1995, eventually vanishing after their last release in 1997.

Holistic Design is a small independent game publishing and development house located in Atlanta, GA.  Originally known as "Several Dudes Holistic Gaming", their first game was "Battles of Destiny" in 1992, with QQP.  Since then, the company has gone on to create a number of award winning games such as "Machiavelli the Prince" and "Final Liberation: Warhammer Epic 40K".   In addition to computer games, the company publishes its own line of role playing books, the core of which is their "Fading Suns" universe, a very rich and deep far future science fiction setting.  It uses its own rules engine, but has also seen a d20 conversion, and been made into a LARP.  As well, they have recently delved into modern day role playing with their "Real Life Roleplaying" series using the d20 engine (current installments are Afghanistan and Somalia, with Columbia coming soon). Further, HDI publishes several miniatures games: "Carnage", a fantasy miniatures game; "Noble Armada", a space ship combat game based in their Fading Suns universe; and "Battle Zone", a post-apocolyptic miniatures combat game.

Moscow-based developer, formed in 2002 by Nikolay Dybowskiy. In 2005, they released their first game, Mor: Utopia, which gained wide acclaim in its native country. It was re-titled Pathologic and published throughout Europe in 2006. Their second game, Turgor, was released in Russia in April 2008 and internationally in 2009 as The Void.

Imaginarium Studios is a Performance Capture and Virtual Production company based at Pinewood Studios, UK,  and also has a smaller volume at SIDE PTW near Kings Cross, London. Formed in 2012 by actor and director Andy Serkis, Imaginarium Studios offers recording with full performance capture (audio recorded on set), motion capture, locomotion, stunts and Facial recording with Automated Dialogue Recording.

Javaground is development studio focused on the creation of mobile development tools. Its most important technology is the Xpress Suite that allows programmers to develop games and port them to a range of platforms, including JAVA, BREW, Android, Windows Mobile and iPhone. The studio also uses its own game technology to develop and port mobile games. Javaground was originally started in Brussels, Belgium in December 2001 as Java Ground SPRL. In May 2005 the company was relocated to Irvine, Southern California (USA) as Javaground USA Inc. and currently it also has an office in Imola (Italy) as Javaground Italia s.r.l. Since 2006 the company has been working extensively with Sony Pictures, which publishes most of its titles, as they are often based on Sony licenses. Javaground's first major independent title was the iPhone game UniWar, released in April 2009. In 2009 Javaground also launched its own mobile game marketplace called Xpressed.com.

Kindly Beast Inc. was a video game development studio based in Ottawa, Canada. It was folded into Joey Drew Studios Inc. in 2021. In 2019 the studio acquired Karman Interactive, another Ottawa-based studio.

KOALABS specializes in cross-platform applications and 3D adventure video games. We are a french developer of games and applications for Windows, MacOS, Android and iOS based in Montreuil, near Paris. Among our products, you can find the well-known Home Design 3D and many adaptations of games such as Syberia, Atlantis, Dracula, Red Johnson, etc...
Maelstrom Games was the publishing company and label created by Mike Singleton in about 1988 when he found it impossible to find another publisher for Dark Spectre.

In 1993, Aaron Hall created Space Empires, a prototype space strategy game inspired by Star Fleet Battles, Master of Orion, Starfire, and Wing Commander. He decided that the prototype could be worth selling to the public if it were expanded upon, which led to the release of Space Empires II, and the establishment of Malfador Machinations in 1995. Development began on the next game, Space Empires III, with Aaron's long-time friend Russell Saito joining the company in 1996 as designer and artist. The game was released as shareware in 1997 and allowed players to customize their experience by editing graphics as well as data files to add or change technologies, ships, and planets. Following the success of SE III, work started on the sequel, Space Empires IV. The game was planned to have improved graphics as well as a redesigned interface, so new artists were brought on to the development team. Shrapnel Games, Inc. acquired the rights to publish SE IV in July 2000, and the game was released commercially in November of that year. Aaron Hall's Dungeon Odyssey, the company's first attempt at delivering a fantasy role-playing game, was released on 16 September 2002. This was followed up by Space Empires: Starfury, a free-roaming real-time 3D space combat game where the player controls only a single ship rather than an entire empire. In April 2006, Strategy First, Inc. acquired all intellectual property of Malfador Machinations before the release of Space Empires V in October that year. The game featured 3D graphics, hexagon grid system sectors, and an overhauled user interface. The company teamed up with Shrapnel Games, Inc. again for the November 2010 release of World Supremacy, a "beer and pretzels" turn-based strategy wargame set in contemporary times. Three years later, Space Captain, a top-down action role-playing game similar to Space Empires: Starfury was released for Android devices.

Media Molecule is a UK-based game development studio founded in January 2006 by a small troupe of Lionhead Studios veterans: Mark Healey, Alex Evans, Dave Smith and Kareem Ettouney, who, bolstered by their work together on cult indie game Rag Doll Kung Fu, started working on new games together. The company's first title was LittleBigPlanet (PS3) released in November 2008 as one of Sony's PS3-exclusive flagship titles for the holiday season. The company is a continuation of QI Creations, the name used by a large part of the current team who worked together on Rag Doll Kung Fu while still at Lionhead. As of 2 March 2010, the company has been owned by Sony Interactive Entertainment.

MegaPixel Studio S. A. is a Polish game development studio established in 2019 as a subsidiary of Forever Entertainment S. A. It is led by Zbigniew Dębicki. The studio's first work were the Nintendo Switch ports of Agony and Grave Keeper in 2019. The first independent work was The Sparkle 4: Tales in 2020 followed by Panzer Dragoon: Remake, a remake of the classic SEGA game. In 2021 the first-person shooter Hollow 2 was released and in 2022 another SEGA remake: The House of the Dead: Remake.

Mercuna 3D Navigation is an AAA-quality 3D navigation middleware for flying AI and underwater AI. It includes 3D pathfinding, steering, movement and dynamic avoidance. Unity and UE4 integrations are currently available. Licenses are per project and include all platforms, including consoles.

Founded as Emergent Software in 1993, the company was renamed Ratbag in 1998 and was based in Adelaide, South Australia. Ratbag's first title Powerslide was released in 1998 and the studio has been focused on racing games ever since. Ratbag also owned the motion-capture studio Madcap in Sydney. Ratbag's titles were driven by the company's proprietary Difference Engine. This was the first PC engine to support unlimited textures and 60 frame per second high resolution graphics. The company's second title was Dirt Track Racing (1999), followed by Dirt Track Racing: Sprint Cars. World of Outlaws: Sprint Cars 2002 was the title that marked Ratbag's first foray into the realm of PlayStation 2. WoOSC2002 was a racing title in the vein of Dirt Track Racing: Sprint Cars. It was released in Spring 2002 in the USA and May 2003 in Australia / New Zealand. Dirt Track Racing 2 and WoOSC were Ratbag's most recent PC titles, released in September 2002 and March 2003, respectively. They were preceded by Leadfoot and Dirt Track Racing Pinball. The Ratbag story is one of struggle and ultimately success. Greg Siegele and Richard Harrison spent three years and all of their personal savings developing the company's early technology. In 1996 they took the original Powerslide demo to E3, knowing that if no publishing deal were forthcoming the company would have to close its doors. The game received a lot of attention, and before they knew it Greg and Richard had no fewer than eight of the biggest publishers in the industry engaged in a bidding war for the rights. Coming full circle, Ratbag showcased Powerslide: Slipstream for PS2 at E3 2003. The studio was eventually acquired by Midway in August 2005 and renamed Midway Australia. A mere 4 months later, in December, it was shut down.
The game development studio Outbox SRL uses the trading name Pomelo Games.
PT Redhot Indonesia is the Indonesian division of the Chinese art outsourcing company Red Hot Software (Shanghai) Ltd.

Packrat Video Games is a producer of homebrew video games for Atari 2600, Odyssey 2 and Vectrex consoles. The company was set up in 1999 and was originally based in Provo (Utah, United States in America). In 2012 the company was taken over by David Flemming in Milwaukee (Wisconsin, United States of America).

Pandemic Studio Pty. Ltd. was the Australian satellite development studio of the US-based company Pandemic Studios. It was established in 2000 by Andrew Payne and Adam Iarossi who left the Los Angeles studio to the branch in the Brisbane suburb of Fortitude Valley. The studio was also referred to Pandemic Brisbane or Pandemic Australia. The team's first title was Army Men RTS (2002). Later, the division would work on the Destroy All Humans! franchise with the titles Destroy All Humans! (2005) and Destroy All Humans! 2 (2006). In November 2005, Pandemic as a whole formed an alliance with BioWare Corporation, backed financially by Elevation Partners. This also affected the Australian studio. Through the operation, a holding company called VG Holding Corp. was created. BioWare's two co-founders Greg Zeschuk and Ray Muzyka, and Pandemic's two co-founders Andrew Goldman and Josh Resnick, became shareholders and senior executives. John Riccitiello from Elevation became the company's CEO. On 11 October 2007, it was announced VG Holding Corp, including both BioWare and Pandemic, would be acquired by Electronic Arts, effective January 2008. On 7 January 2008, the company officially became a part of the EA Games label. THQ asked for a third Destroy All Humans! game in late 2006, but the Australian studio declined, preferring to work on new IP. On 23 October 2006, it was announced a second development team at the Australian studio was formed. The Alpha team began working on an open world Wii game tentatively called The Next Big Thing while the Bravo team pitched a number of concepts to the LA office. These were all rejected in favour of game similar to Destroy All Humans!, but playing as the son of Satan and collecting souls. With enthusiasm low for such similar game design, it was eventually canned. EA, however, had the rights for the Batman IP for another 18 months and the Bravo team started work on a game. After several months they were informed the game would need to be tied to the then upcoming The Dark Knight movie instead of the general franchise, meaning much work had to be scrapped. It was turned into an open world game, similar to the US studio's Mercenaries series, but the Australian team had no experience with such designs and the engine of The Saboteur they used, a then upcoming game of the US studio, was eventually deemed unfit for such large worlds. The enhancements and modifications they had to make put such pressure on the hardware it brought the dev kits to their knees. The team eventually grew to 130 people to get it done, but there was not enough time to meet the movie's release date. In September 2008, the game needed to go to an alpha stage, but was in such an unpolished state management decided to can the project entirely. Naturally the team size was reduced, but by December, Electronic Arts announced another major restructuring making the Australian team the main candidate. The Bravo team disappeared and the Australian studio was set "free", leaving the alpha team independent, but with the rights to the Wii game they were working on. As such, Pandemic Studios Pty. Ltd. as the Australian division of Pandemic Studios ceased to exist. The main Los Angeles studio would follow in December 2009, after the completion of The Saboteur. Lead designer Morgan Jaffit went on to found Defiant Development in 2010, which was closed in 2019.

column1: People's Republic of Animation Pty Ltd, The

column2: Playground Games is a game development studio based in the UK. It was established in 2009 by Gavin Raeburn and Ralph Fulton after they left Codemasters. The studio's first work was contributing to the development of DJ Hero 2 (2010) by FreeStyleGames. On 5 March 2012, the studio announced its first own project, Forza Horizon, a new entry in the Forza Motorsport racing series. It was released in October 2012. On 10 June 2018, they were acquired by Microsoft Corporation to be part of the Microsoft Studios (today Xbox Game Studios) label.

Pocket Studios was a United Kingdom based company which developed games for the Game Boy Color and Game Boy Advance platforms. The company was founded in 2000 by Steve Iles. It began using the name Pocket Studios (UK) Ltd. in June of 2004, but then filed bankruptcy in September of that year and closed down.

RedJade Inc. was founded out of the ashes of Digital Illusions Canada, Inc. and is located in London, Ontario (Canada). The company is led and founded by Fredrik Liliegren, former CEO of DICE Canada, along with several ex-employees. The company focuses on art creation services for the PC as well as current and next generation consoles. The company name was also used for a Californian company at the end of the nineties, where Fredrik Liliegren was CEO and COO in between holding positions at DICE.

Respawn Entertainment is a development studio based in the USA and founded on 12 April 2010 by Jason West and Vince Zampella. Both were previously managers at Infinity Ward, an Activision-owned development studio known for the Call of Duty series. Zampella and West left the company after a legal dispute with Activision over the royalties for Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2. With Respawn Entertainment, they signed to the EA Partners program, where Respawn retained all the rights to the intellectual property. Their first titles were in the Titanfall series. On 9 November 2017, Electronic Arts announced their intent to purchase Respawn Entertainment, and the acquisition was completed on 1 December 2017. Since then, Respawn Entertainment has published Apex Legends in February 2019, with no direct involvement from EA, and the Star Wars: Jedi series since 2019.

Ruffian Games is a game development studio based in Dundee, Scotland. The formation was announced on 19th January 2009 and the company is headed by Gary Liddon. It is a reformation of Xen Services, Ltd. When Midway Studios - Newcastle closed down in mid-2009, a large number of designers moved on to Ruffian. It also includes a number of people who previously worked at Realtime Worlds. That led to an awkward moment when Microsoft chose Ruffian to develop a sequel to the Realtime Worlds title Crackdown. Realtime initially offered to do a follow-up itself, but Microsoft couldn't predict the success of the title yet, leading Realtime to shift focus to the MMO APB: All Points Bulletin instead. The company also worked on the cancelled Game of Glens (formerly announced as Tribal Towers).

SEEC (Which stands for Surprise Enjoy Evolve Company) is a company that was formed in 2005 and is mainly operating in the advertising, e-commerce and business consulting spheres. It also has an application development department, which develops idle clickers, adventure games and visual novels for Android and iOS devices since 2014. As the company itself notes, most of their departments were established due to their employees expressing their wishes to try something new, which might explain their diverse business portfolio.

SEGA Interactive Co, Ltd. was established during SEGA's restructuring ín 2015 and handles the development, manufacturing and sales of SEGA's amusement machine business. The company was absorbed into SEGA Games, which was renamed SEGA after that, on April 1, 2020.

SKY NETWORK, s.r.o. are the operators of Erogames.com, an online game portal which distributes adult games. The website's address was Eroges.com until early 2020. The company is incorporated in the Czech Republic.

Silver Cloud, Silver Cloud Games, Blue Sky, and Blue Sky Games all seem to be aliases used by the same entity which first used the name Dark Knight. They develop JRPGs using the RPG Maker toolkit. Timeline of events  27 August 2019: Ladies Orders is released on Steam, developed & published by Dark Knight. 1 September 2019: On the Steam page for Ladies Orders, Dark Knight's name is changed to Silver Cloud. 22 September 2019: Dragon Slayer is released on Steam, developed & published by Silver Cloud. 27 October 2019: Kira's Contract is released on Steam, developed & published by Silver Cloud. 26 July 2021: Heroines is released on Steam, developed & published by Blue Sky. 16 September 2021: On the Steam page for Heroines, the name Blue Sky is changed to Blue Sky Games. 15 October 2021: On the Steam pages for Ladies Orders, Dragon Slayer, and Kira's Contract, the name Silver Cloud is changed to Blue Sky Games. On the Steam page for Heroines, the name Blue Sky Games is changed to Silver Cloud Games. 16 October 2021:  Guardians of Greenheart is released on Steam, developed & published by Silver Cloud Games. 18 December 2021: The Forgotten Empire is released on Steam, developed & published by Silver Cloud Games. 29 April 2023: Assassins of Darkness is released on Steam, developed & published by Silver Cloud Games. 22 July 2023: Blood Samurai is released on Steam, developed & published by Silver Cloud Games.  As of 23 July 2023, Blue Sky Games are listed as the developers and publishers of Ladies Orders, Dragon Slayer, and Kira's Contract on Steam, while Silver Cloud Games are listed as the developers and publishers of Heroines, Guardians of Greenheart, The Forgotten Empire, Assassins of Darkness, and Blood Samurai on Steam.

Smoking Gun Interactive Inc is a game development studio founded on 4th June 2007 by John Johnson, Angie Radwan-Pytlewski and Drew Dunlop, all former senior staff from Relic Entertainment. The studio is led by CEO and Creative Director John Johnson who was previously the Director of Franchise Development and Producer on Company of Heroes, while Angie Radwan-Pytlewski served as Art Director and Drew Dunlop as Lead Programmer on the critically acclaimed real-time strategy hit. The company's first project was the transmedia experience Exoriare. The team also contributed to Kinect Adventures (2010), the launch title bundled with Microsoft's Kinect peripheral.

Snowblind Studios was a game development studio based in Kirkland, Washington (USA), founded in 1997 by Ryan Geithman.  In February 2009, Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment announced to have acquired the studio. Geithman confirmed in October 2011 to have left the company. He went on to found the independent social/mobile game development studio Ember Entertainment. The company was merged with Monolith Productions in 2012.

Steel Penny Games, based in Austin, Texas, is a videogame development company specializing in mass-market "casual" games. The company was started by ex-Naughty Dog developers Jason Hughes and Andrew Gilmour in May 2006. The company was reorganized as an incorporated entity in May 2007, almost exactly a year later, and officially announced in January 2008.
Studio Bean Games is the independent game development studio of Michael Molinari. His first commercial release was BasketBelle in July 2012.

T-Time Technology is a Taiwanese game developer and publisher based in New Taipei City. The company was founded on April 11, 1992.  In 1996 they opened a branch in Beijing, in 2003 in Hong-Kong, and in 2004 in Shanghai and Singapore. As a developer, they are best known for their card and board games. They also publish Japanese PC games (primarily visual novels) in Chinese-speaking countries.

Toka, a video game development company located in France, was founded by Carlo Perconti and Lyes Belaidouni. The company specialized in games for console platforms. Toka was among the first to use Motion Capture technology.

Tomorrow Corporation is an independent game development studio co-founded by Kyle Gabler, Kyle Gray and Allan Blomquist. The establishment was first announced on 8th March 2010. All of them worked for Electronic Arts in the past and they were also are involved with founding the Experimental Gameplay Project. The studio's first title, Little Inferno, was released in November 2012.
A publishing label of Puppet Combo

Undead Labs is a game development studio established by Jeff Strain, previously the co-founder of ArenaNet. It is based in Washington, Seattle (USA). The formation was first announced on 23 November 2009, and released on 5 June, 2013. With a history in multiplayer games, the studio's first announced title is an XBLA zombie game called State of Decay, to be followed by Class4, which will be a continuation of the storyline, developed as a full console MMO. On 10 June 2018, they were acquired by Microsoft Corporation to be part of the Microsoft Studios (today Xbox Game Studios) label.

United Front Games Ltd. was a game development studio based in Vancouver, Canada. It was formed in 2007 by former employees of Electronic Arts, Radical Entertainment, Black Box Games, Rockstar, Action Pants, Propaganda Games and Next Level Games. In May 2009 the company announced to have signed with Activision to develop True Crime: Hong Kong for the publisher. Almost two years later however, in February 2011 Activision Blizzard said to discontinue the True Crime series, canning the game. Following that announcement, at least 25 people were laid off at the studio. On 2nd August 2011 Square Enix made known to have picked up the publishing rights to the True Crime: Hong Kong project (but not the rights to the name of the series). Development on the game at United Front Games was continued with the new title Sleeping Dogs and overseen by Square Enix London Studios. The studio's first title, the PS3 racing game ModNation Racers, was released in May 2010. Sleeping Dogs was released in August 2012.  As of October 2016, the studio is closed and all in-development titles (notably Smash+Grab) are cancelled.

Uppercut Games is an independent video game development studio based in Canberra, Australia. It was founded in 2011 by Andrew James (Art Director), Ryan Lancaster (Tech Director) and Ed Orman (Design Director), when the trio decided to leave their AAA studio background and forge their own path as independent developers. In 2012, Uppercut expanded to include John Travers and Evan Zachariadis, with Ben Driehuis joining in 2014.

Wargaming Seattle (formerly known as Gas Powered Games) was a development studio founded by Chris Taylor, along with Jake McMahon, Bartosz Kijanka, Mike Biddlecombe and Rick Saenz, coming from Cavedog Entertainment. Initially, the company focused solely on the RPG Dungeon Siege series, for which the film rights have been sold as well. In February 2007, the company released the real-time strategy game Supreme Commander followed by the action RPG Space Siege in August 2008.  Demigod, a real-time strategy game influenced by the Warcraft III custom map Defense of the Ancients, was released in 2009 and the sequel to Supreme Commander, Supreme Commander 2, in 2010. For a time, they were working on the fantasy RTS Kings & Castles, which was ultimately never released. On 14 February 2013, Wargaming.net, Inc. announced to have acquired the company. On 23 May 2018, the company's closure was announced. At that time, the company had employed roughly 150 staff members. Many developers moved on to Crystal Northwest, a new studio established in 2018.

White Birds Productions is a development studio founded by Benoît Sokal, Olivier Fontenay, Jean-Philippe Messian and Michel Bams in August 2003 in Paris, France. Prior to the establishment of the company, the founders worked together on AmerZone and the two Syberia games at MC2-Microïds. The company released its first game Paradise in April 2005, but they do not only focus on game development. White Birds released a series of Paradise graphic novels and are working on the film Aquarica. Benoît Sokal is the company's artistic director and the team of circa 30 members focuses on the creation of ideas and art, while the main portion of the coding and graphics work is outsourced to companies in Canada and Slovenia. In October 2007, White Birds released their second game, the murder mystery Sinking Island. In June 2008 it was announced that the company is developing their first game for the Nintendo DS system, The Last King of Africa, a remake of Paradise, with an expected release in late 2008.
Yamago is a small French company specializing in the creation of games for the internet. It was co-founded in Paris by Frédéric Smyczynski in 2001.

Yippee! Entertainment Ltd. is a Manchester-based software developer and digital publisher which was founded in 2011 by Michael Delves. On January 2, 2020 Team17 announced that it had acquired the company.

Zeboyd Games is a small independent game company which was founded between 2009 and 2010 by Robert Boyd and Bill Stiernberg. Their games are 8-bit and 16-bit-style 2D RPGs for Xbox LIVE's indie games channel and also PC.

ZeniMax Germany GmbH is a subsidiary of ZeniMax Media Inc. based in Frankfurt, Germany. The opening of the office was announced on April 2010. Originally a business office, this changed when in August 2015 when id Software, part of ZeniMax, announced to open a new division in Frankfurt, Germany. This was most likely a deliberate move to attract talent from Crytek GmbH that was under heavy restructuring. Presumably there was never a separate office and the German division of id Software as it was probably part of the existing ZeniMax office from the start.
Zipline Games is a Seattle (USA) based mobile games company and the creator of the Moai game development platform.
17-BIT is an independent game development studio founded by Jake Kazdal in 2009.

2 By 3 Games was founded in 2000 by three game industry veterans, Gary Grigsby, Joel Billings and Keith Brors, to produce highly detailed computer wargames. Their primary focus is on games covering World War II.

5518 Studios was an outsourcing studio based in Los Angeles, USA. It was founded in 2016 by Michael Casalino (CEO) and Maxim Miheyenko (COO). Next to the LA headquarters it operated production studios in Moscow and St. Petersburg in Russia. On 11th February 2021 Pole To Win announced the acquisition of the company, merging it into a new company 1518 Studios along with their existing studio Orange Rock.

Adeline Software was an independent French game development studio, best known as the creators of the Little Big Adventures series. It was founded in 1992 by the Infogrames employees Frédérick Raynal (Creative Director), Didier Chanfray (Artistic Director), Yaël Barroz, and Laurent Salmeron. Adeline was bought by Sega in 1997 to become the console maker's first 100% owned European studio under the name "No Cliche". Many Adeline developers such as Sébastien Viannay, Didier Chanfray, Lionel Chaze and Paul-Henri Michaud came together to work at Little Worlds Studio.

AeroHills was founded as independent company in 2001. Until 2004 they also operated under a brand name of Creative Dimensions, introduced in 2001 by the current Director of AeroHills, Oleksiy Honcharov. AeroHills works with different outsourcing projects coming from all over the world. The main offices located in Ukraine, along with representatives in the US and Europe.

Apeiron is a Russian game development studio. It was unofficially started by Vladimir Ufnarovskiy in 1999. He had worked on the global space strategy game Remember Tomorrow at SoftWarWare, but when the company ceased to exist due to financial matters, he started a new project on his own: the tactical strategy game E5. He was soon joined by Dmitriy Ivashkin and Stanislav Simonov and together they formed the main development team. In May 2002 the game E5 was released on the internet. Russian publisher 1C Company expressed interest in the game and offered a contract for commercial development. At the end of 2002, Apeiron was officially established and they released the tactical game Brigade E5: New Jagged Union in July 2005. In 2007 the company employs about 20 people and completed the sequel 7.62 in August 2007.

column1: Association Internationale des Groupes Cyclistes Professionnels
BANDAI NAMCO Studios Singapore Pte. Ltd.
column2: Bandai Namco Studios Singapore is a development studio of the Japanese company Bandai Namco Studios Inc. and it is based in Singapore. It was established on 1st March 2013 as Namco Bandai Studios Singapore. On 25th January 2014 the name was changed to Bandai Namco Studios Singapore.

Beep Games was a game development studio established in May 2000 in Kirkland, Washington (USA). Founded as Beep Industries, the name was changed to Beep Games in September 2003. It was founded by Clayton Kauzlaric, previously the Creative Director at Gas Powered Games and before that Lead Designer / Art Lead at Cavedog Entertainment. Several employees previously worked at Cavedog. The studio debuted with the 3D platformer Voodoo Vince in 2003 as a first-party developer for Microsoft's Xbox console. After that five casual titles were created: Flying Leo (2005), Zodiac (2006), Four Houses (2006), Word Spiral (2006) and Realms of Gold (2007). From around 2009 Beep Games most likely only consisted of Kauzlaric because he joined Microsoft as Senior Design Director. He later became Principle Creative Director of Xbox Games Studios Publishing at the company. Kauzlaric has close ties to Ron Gilbert, through their shared history at Cavedog Entertainment between 1996 and 2000. They co-created the character Deathspank (2010) for Hothead Games and did some smaller titles together as Beep Games such as Word Spiral (2011), a new mobile version of the studio's 2006 title of the same name, as well as The Big Big Castle (2012) and Scurvy Scallywags (2013). In 2017 Voodoo Vince: Remastered was released as a remastered version of the studio's debut title and in 2020 a completely new action game Bartlow's Dread Machine was released, co-developed with Tribetoy Inc. Most likely that was the last game for Beep Games, as according to Kauzlaric's LinkedIn page the studio was closed in May 2019.

Bitmap Bureau is a UK development studio established in February 2016 by Mike Tucker and Matthew Cope. They are based in Southampton and several other members are spread across Europe. They are long time friends and previously worked together at Infospace Games - IOMO studio. Tucker in particular has a long history in the industry, starting with games testing at SCi Games Ltd. in 1995 and then the first mobile games at IOMO where he specialised in cross-platform mobile technology. Later he formed by studio Megadev focusing on high quality flash games and that studio developed Adult Swim's first Steam title, Super House of Dead Ninjas (2013). The studio develops fast action arcade game with a retro vibe and pixel art graphics. The word Bitmap in the studio name was chosen particularly because they want to get across their speciality in 2D games with strong pixel art, and the word "pixel" is already used by thousands of indie developers. The team debuted commercially with the 2D action platformer 88 Heroes in 2017. In the same year the local multiplayer action game Ninja Shodown was released. Before that, in 2016, they also created the homebrew SEGA Mega Drive title Fatal Smarties in 48 hours for a Global Game Jam, but not using the Bitmap Bureau name. For their third game, Xeno Crisis, they launched a Kickstarter crowdfunding campaign. It is a top-down arena shooter for up to two players described as Smash TV meets Aliens made a new title for the retro systems SEGA Mega Drive / Genesis and Dreamcast, both as a physical cartridge and a downloadable ROM. The project raised £72,569 and eventually the game was released in 2019 and for many platforms. The game was created on PC, with their own engine, and several custom tools they developed. It was then ported to the other platforms. In 2021 the studio released Battle Axe, developed together with Henk Nieborg and also following a successful Kickstarter crowdfunding campaign raising £73,918.  In 2022 they released Final Vendetta, a 2D side-scrolling brawler inspired by Final Fight and Streets of Rage with music by Utah Saints. Just like Xeno Crisis, Final Vendetta was also announced as an original homecart release for the Neo Geo platform.

CBE software is an independent video game development studio which was transformed in 2011 from the original two-man operation called Cardboard Box Entertainment. It is based in Brno, Czech Republic. The studio debuted with the paranormal comedy game Ghost in the Sheet in 2007. In 2012 CBE software released the sci-fi narrative video game J.U.L.I.A., its spin-off prequel J.U.L.I.A. Untold for iOS and Vampires! (PC, Mac). After a successful crowd funding campaign, CBE software launched J.U.L.I.A.: Among the Stars in 2014.
A Russian (Moscow) company engaged in the development of computer games.

The company was founded as Kuju Sheffield in 2002, as one of the regional development studios of Kuju Entertainment Ltd.. In June 2007 the company's name was changed to Chemistry. In June 2009 Kuju announced that the Chemistry studio would be closed imminently unless a last minute management buy-out deal happened. It was closed shortly after.
Cold Beam Games is the independent game development studio of Steve Hunt (ShadowRage).
Concrete Software, Inc. is a developer of games and applications for various mobile systems including Blackberries, PDAs, Smartphones and Mobile Phones.

CreaTeam-Software is a two-man business from Uwe Berents and Kay Elbert. At first they made two PC conversions of board games from the company Ravensburger AG but couldn't get a official license to distribute them. Then they specialised in application programmes, hardware solutions and shareware games, especially about the card game skat.

Creative Reality was a British developer founded in mid-1980's by Neil Dodwell and David Dew. They are perhaps best known for their cyberpunk adventure game DreamWeb (1994). Their final game was Martian Gothic: Unification (2000).
Critical Reflex is a publishing label by Inpleron Ltd..
Cybione is a French company founded by Sébastien Soulier in 2010 and offers localization services for a variety of languages.

Denki Ltd. was founded on 20 March 2000 by four former team members of DMA Design. One of the co-founders was Colin Anderson. The company was located in Dundee, Scotland, and began as a very small independent games studio. Their first release was Denki Blocks! in 2001. During recent years, Denki has focused on interactive television development and has established itself as a leader in the production of games for this platform, routinely taking products from paper concept to completition in less than 10 weeks. The quality and significance of this work was recognised by the games community in 2003 when Denki received an 'Industry Excellence' award for its pioneering work in this field. Denki was commissioned by Realtime Worlds to oversee design and production during the initial phase of its next-generation product Crackdown, which was released for the Xbox 360 in February 2007. In December 2008, Denki announced that it would return to consoles with Quarrel for Xbox Live Arcade.

Digital Eel is the name of an independent team of developers which began in 1999 in Kirkland, Massachusetts. Not a company as such, the principals at first worked out of a residence while still being employed by other companies. The team is comprised of Rich Carlson and Iikka Keranen, who had worked together at Looking Glass Studios, plus William R. Sears (Phosphorous), an artist.

Heliovisions Productions was originally a French, Lyon-based company working in the domain of video (dubbing, special effects, editing). Around 1996, a games division was created to work on PC games, when former Infogrames programmers such as Denis Dufour and Vincent Terraillon joined the company. In the beginning of 1997, the team was expanded to work on PlayStation games when former Adeline Software programmers Olivier Lhermite and Mickaël Pointier joined. In mid-1998, the team expanded to include Dreamcast games as well. Along with the addition, the video game division was renamed Helio Game. The name Heliozo also appears to has been used. In September 2000, the studio name was settled as Doki Denki Studio. Eventually, Doki Denki consisted of two divisions: game development and animation. That way, additional work was also provided for other games, such as Kya: Dark Lineage (2003). In February 2003, the company acquired the French development studio Delphine. Work was started on Moto Racer Traffic, the fourth installment in the Moto Racer series by Delphine, for Windows and PlayStation 2, but eventually it was not released as Doki Denki was declared bankrupt on 4 March 2004.

EA Gothenburg, formerly known as Ghost Games, is a game development studio of Electronic Arts and it is based in Gothenburg, Sweden. The formation of the outfit was announced in March 2012. It is the company's second studio in Sweden after the acquisition of Digital Illusions CE in 2006. The Gothenburg studio was established to create new games based on the Frostbite 3 game engine.

East Side Games is a proudly independent and profitable Vancouver, BC game studio with a collaborative, creative, and fun culture. Our games fund all our new projects, and everyone who works here has a direct impact on the day-to-day business. The studio was founded in July 2011 by Josh Nilson, Jason Bailey and Galan Akin. It's first game, Pot Farm on Facebook, was a smash hit with over 6 million players and 1.2 million likes. Other games on mobile include Pot Farm: Grass Roots, Dragon Up and Trailer Park Boys: Greasy Money.

Emerald City Games is a game development studio based in Vancouver, Canada. It was established in March 2008 by Derek Day. The studio debuted with the web games Sacred Seasons and Sacred Seasons 2 and then moved to mobile game development with titles such as Lionheart Tactics and Stormblades.

Emerald Software was founded in early 1988 with financial support from the Irish government. First based in the UK, it relocated to Waterford and was the first big developer in Ireland eventually with about seventeen programmers and five graphic artists. It was established by Mike Dixon (formerly EMI) and Dave Martin (formerly Martech).

FXLabs Studios Pvt Ltd. is an Indian game development studio founded in September 2004 by Sashi Reddi. The company has its production studio in Hyderabad, India and a sales office in Los Angeles. In August 2008 the company announced to move into the outsourcing business for art and development.

The company was founded as Ino-Co in 2004 and it is based in Krasnodar, Russia. In the summer of 2007 the development studio was acquired by 1C Company and renamed 1C: Ino-Co. The team's first release was the fantasy strategy game Fantasy Wars (2007).

Jaibo Games is a casual games development company which was founded by Anton Saburov and located in the Ukraine. The actual date of formation is uncertain. It is known that the Jaibo Games website was "in construction" on July 7, 2007, and was active for the first time on January 1, 2008. The company's officially credited games are mostly "match 3" tile-matching puzzle games, the first being Magic Shop, released in September 2007. There is cross-over between this company and Mr. Saburov's other one, Bee Games, but the corporate connection between the two, if any, is not known.

JoWooD Vienna was founded in 1999 as an in-house development studio of JoWood Productions Software. Their first project was to develop The Nations together with neo Software. Then they focused on casual games (Neighbors from Hell, Itch!, Pusher). In 2005, JoWooD's CEO Albert Seidl announced to expand the Vienna development team. But later that year, the game development unit of this studio was shut down. It was merged into the main company on 1 January 2006.
Laser Dog Games is UK game development studio established in 2013. It consists of Simon Renshaw and Rob Allison. Their debut title was PUK in 2013.

column1: Live Motion Games Sp. z o. o.
column2: Live Motion Games was founded in 2017. The main activity of the Studio is the production of computer games for the Steam platform. The Company's business model involves creating low- and medium-budget projects and then selling them worldwide in a digital model, via the Steam platform. In 2021, Live Motion Games plans to debut on the NewConnect market.

MBA Studios GmbH & Co. KG is the company of Markus Baader. It specializes in visualization, special effects and computer graphics in general. When working on video game projects, it is mostly involved in the creation of cutscenes or trailers.

Mad About Pandas is an award-winning German independent video game developer founded in 2005 by Patrick Rau and based in Berlin. The studio focuses on producing narrative games such as the mystery adventure title “Hitchhiker”, while also working on commissioned projects for clients such as Goethe Institute, Bundesagentur für Arbeit, and Disney. For many years, the studio was focused mostly on the production of games based on mobile devices (iOS, Android, Nintendo DS and Switch), which resulted in titles such as Ubisoft’s “Galaxy Racers”, “The Great Jitters: Pudding Panic”, “Forever Forest”, “Truck Simulation 16” and “Laika”. The production of “Hitchhiker”, however, marked a turning point towards a focus on high-quality narrative games for PC and console that contain a signature atmosphere of playfulness and surrealism.

As the name implies, this UK team concentrated mostly on games using mathematical methods of drawing screen displays. It was founded in June 1987 by former musician Andy Craven and Danny Gallagher. It was one of the notable studios writing for Activision's Electric Dreams label. One month after the formation the studio was landed a contract to do the Spectrum, Commodore and BBC Micro conversions of Star Wars. This was done by a development team of three people, as the founders hired 16-year-old programmer Ciaran Gultnieks. With a good result, the company received the contract to port Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back as well. Gallagher had already left for Ocean by then, but Derrick Austin, Bill Pullan, and Ian Martin joined the team. While working on the Empire project John Lewis also arrived, taking the role of company director and Gallagher's 50% share of the company. After that, the vector graphics were abandoned and the team moved on to an advanced 3D system of graphics. The company established a new sub-company Sprytes Ltd to create core systems for a wide array of games and platforms, and Muzik Ltd to do the same for music and sound effects. The first game to use the new graphics system was Strike Aces (Fighter Bomber in Europe) in 1989. After developing a number of original games the studio was acquired by Microprose in 1992. It then became Microprose's internal Leeds development studio.
Most Wanted Games is a publishing label of the German company WalkOn media publishing GmbH & Co. KG.

Onix, ltd. is an audio production company and provides originally composed music and sound for games as well as other markets. The company name is usually credited as Onixmusic. The company's early gaming projects were for Burut Creative Team and included both of the Kreed games and others.
Overhaul Games is an internal development division of Beamdog. The division's first work was the HD release of MDK 2 in October 2011.
Headed by Dan Bunten, also consisting of Bill Bunten, Jim Rushing, and Alan Watson.  Developed M.U.L.E., Seven Cities of Gold, and Heart of Africa.

Panda Entertainment (熊貓軟體) was a Taiwanese game developer active during the 1990s. They are best known for their fighting games such as the Sango Fighter series. In 2012, the company's entire back catalog was acquired by Super Fighter Team, which began to develop new products based on the material.

Paradox Tinto is a development studio of Paradox Interactive AB and it is based in Barcelona, Spain. The formation was announced on 1st June 2020. The studio is headed by Johan Andersson, designer of the Europa Universalis series, and the focus is on the development of grand strategy titles.

Parallax Software was a development studio best known for the Descent series. It was founded by Matt Toschlog and Mike Kulas in 1993. Prior to forming Parallax, Matt and Mike worked for subLOGIC and Looking Glass Technologies, writing simulations and 3D engines.  Parallax had offices in Champaign, Illinois and Ann Arbor, Michigan, and decided to split the company into two separate divisions in 1997: Outrage Entertainment and Volition. At that moment, Parallax Software Corp. ceased to exist.

Pinhead Games was created in 1987 by Mark Darin as an independent developer of freeware games for the C-64. Since then Pinhead games has developed games for several platforms including the Amiga and PC. Most recently we have shifted our focus to specialize in web-based point & click adventures that can be played within a web browser.  Source: Excerpt from FAQ, Official Site Pinhead Games is dedicated to bringing quality Point & Click adventure to the web. Our primary goal is to create games with story and characters that the player can identify with. Games rich with character and story depth form a unique bond with the player, and leave a lasting impression, one that they are eager to pass onto and share with others. Our titles are fun, episode length games designed to bring you the entertainment equivelant of a saturday matinee while engaging the player with brain teasing puzzles and addicting gameplay. Source: Excerpt from About Us, Official Site
Plaion Ltd. (Benelux) is the Dutch subsidiary of Plaion.

Playdemic is a games company based in Cheshire, United Kingdom and it is owned by Electronic Arts. It was established on 16 December 2009 in Manchester by Paul Gouge and Alex Rigby as a developer of social games, mainly for Facebook and later also for iOS and Android. Both founders had a history at Rockpool Games, a UK company creating content for mobile devices and other mobile companies before that. Rockpool was acquired by Eidos Interactive and in January 2009 confirmed to have been closed. Playdemic debuted with the social Facebook game Gourmet Garden in 2010, targeting women aged 35 to 50. Other social games released in the early years include Crossword Buddies (2012), Eye Spy! (2012), Village Life (2012) and Quiz Buddies (2013). The release of Gang Nations (2015) displayed other groups were targeted as well. In January 2011, Playdemic was acquired by RockYou and was renamed. At the time the studio employed sixteen people. Later that year RockYou faced financial instability and the studio performed a management buyout. The company was renamed Playdemic again. In 2012 it acquired the studio Ideas Pad based in Cheshire and they renamed it Playdemic Development. The two studios most likely moved into a single location as Playdemic's address became the Cheshire location. From then on Playdemic was always referred to as a single entity as Playdemic Ltd., even though both companies remained active. On 27 February 2013, the company announced that UK game pioneer Ian Livingstone was appointed company chairman as he was an angel investor in the studio. The company's biggest success is the social golf game Golf Clash (2017). By September 2018 revenue was estimated to have surpassed $225 million. On 8 February 2017, Tt Games (owned by Warner Bros.) announced the acquisition of the company with the goal of creating new LEGO titles for mobile devices. In 2019, the studio launched their first game LEGO Star Wars Battles co-developed with TT Odyssey for Warner Bros., but it never left the beta phase and was shut down on 1st July 2021. In the meantime the title was reworked by from a free-to-play title to a full game part of the Apple Arcade library and re-released in September 2021. In June 2021, Playdemic was purchased by Electronic Arts for $1.4 billion. Warner Bros. stated that they sold Playdemic to focus more on building Warner Bros. storied franchises.

Playerthree is an independent games company formed in 2001 by David Streek and Pete Everett. Initially focused on developing flash and shockwave titles, Playerthree creates casual games, educational games and self-IP titles for a variety of media owners such as Cartoon Network, Miniclip, BBC, Channel Four Television Corporation, Spil Games and numerous advertising agencies. They produce games for web, Unity3D, iOS devices, Android, PSP and PS Vita.
Portkey Games is a publishing label of Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment used for their games which use the Harry Potter/Wizarding World license.

Red Forge are two spanish Music Producers and Sound Designers for video games and audiovisual projects. Alberto Rojas and Elías Fraguas have been providing delightful sound to video games and all kinds of products since 2014. Nestled in the indie game scene, they have worked with developers from all over the world, from Korea to Texas, through England, Australia, Finland, etc. Until they have created sounds for everyone, they won't be satisfied.

Reply Game Studios is an Italian game development studio part of Reply S.p.A., a Consulting, Systems Integration, Application Management and Business Process Outsourcing company. The subsidiary was initially established as Forge Reply Srl. The re-branding from Forge Reply to Reply Game Studios was announced on 29th April 2021.

Micro Forté was founded in 1985 with the purpose of developing world-class AAA computer games. The company is one of Australia’s leading game developers with development studios in Sydney and Canberra. Micro Forté develops innovative, quality technology and computer games with high design and production values.  Micro Forté is committed to ongoing research and development focusing on new technology for emerging games markets. Micro Forté’s, award winning BigWorld’ Technology represents the most scalable, fault-tolerant, and customisable MMOG middleware available anywhere in the world. Very few developers in the world can boast of such technology. In 2002 Micro Forté was the Australian winner of the The Asia Pacific Information and Communications Technology Award (APICTA), in the Creative Digital Industries category, for its BigWorld’ Technology. Micro Forté also won the Cisco Systems Innovation Category of the 2001 Telstra and ACT Government Small Business Awards for its outstanding technology. Micro Forté employs some of the best Australian talent, and provides a fantastic game development culture with a strong working environment. Micro Forté’s developers have worked on multiplatform game development projects, original titles as well as franchises.  Micro Forté enjoys a strong leadership position in the Australian games industry, having founded the Academy of Interactive Entertainment Ltd (AIE), Australia's leading educational institution for computer game developers. Micro Forté is also responsible for the creation of the Australian Game Developers Conference and the Game Developers Association Australia, both key players in Australia's ever-growing interactive entertainment industry. On 17 October 2022 Riot Games announced the acquisition of the studio. It was renamed Riot Sidney.

column1: Rochester Institute of Technology MAGIC Spell Studios, LLC
column2: MAGIC Spell Studios is the commercial division of Rochester Institute of Technology, New York state, USA. It publishes games developed by the student body as well as collaborating with other developers.

The company was founded as Barking Dog Studios, Ltd. in Gastown, Vancouver, British Columbia, by six ex-Radical employees: Brian Thalken, Peter Grant, Sean Thompson, Christopher Mair, Glenn Barnes and Michael Gyori. Their first project was the Cataclysm standalone expansion for Relic Entertainment's Homeworld in 2000. Next, they developed their first standalone game, the FPS Global Operations, released in 2002. In August 2002, Take-Two Interactive acquired the company and renamed it Rockstar Vancouver, as one of the many Rockstar divisions. Their first game as Rockstar Vancouver is Bully, released in October 2006. Rockstar Vancouver was merged to Rockstar Toronto in July 2012.

Rogue Entertainment was a development studio active in the late 1990s and housed in the same office building as id Software. All of their titles used id Software game engines and they also created two expansions for games in the Quake series. Their own games Strife (1996) and American McGee's Alice (2000) were well-received and praised for their originality. The company was shut down in 2001 and many of the members moved on to Nerve Software.

Silverstring Media was founded on January 1, 2013 by Lucas J.W. Johnson in Vancouver, BC, Canada. That same year, he partnered with Claris Cyarron to change the studio into something more. Silverstring Media has done work for Lazy 8 Studios and Brace Yourself Games, among others.

Sirtech Canada was founded in April 1994 in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada. It was formed from staff of Madlab Software during the development of the original Jagged Alliance. After its original publisher, Sir-tech Software, Inc., closed in September 1998, Sirtech Canada remained in business and took over the former's intellectual properties and website domain. From this point, Sirtech Canada's games were published by a variety of different companies. In December 2002, the company's developers would publicly announce to be available for new projects, as the company itself was closed around that time by Strategy First.

Studio XELFLEX is a small development company based in the Shinjuku ward of Tokyo, Japan. It was established in December 1999, and as of 2011 employs ten people. Though they have developed a few full titles under contract, they traditionally provide development support for other developers, such as Arc System Works and Flight-Plan. They also offer design and planning services for toys, and have worked with major manufacturers including Takara Tomy and Kotobukiya. The company's director is Keisuke Ōuchi.
Sunny Side Up Creative was a creative marketing agency based in Québec, Canada. In January 2021 it was announced Sunny Side Up had merged into KWM with Fire Without Smoke.
Take-Two Interactive Software UK Limited was founded in 2015. Their exact business is unknown, but their name is associated with digital game releases in Hong Kong and South Korea.

Tango Gameworks is a Japanese company founded in March 2010 by former Capcom developer Shinji Mikami in Odaiba, Japan. In August 2014, it moved to Tokyo. It was originally a subsidiary of ZeniMax Media and sister studio to ZeniMax Asia. It is best known for The Evil Within series, Ghostwire: Tokyo (2022) and the award-winning Hi-Fi Rush (2023). The studio's closure was announced on 7 May 2024. However, it was acquired by Krafton along with the Hi-Fi Rush IP. On 1st January 2025 Krafton announced the studio was re-established as Tango Gameworks Inc.

The Coalition is a game development studio of Xbox Game Studios and it is based in Vancouver, Canada. The studio was officially announced in May 2011, but was already active at least since February 2011 under the moniker Zipline Studios. As Zipline, the studio contributed to the Facebook game Relic Rescue.

Tribute Games is a game development and publishing company founded on 9th May 2011 by ex-Ubisoft employees Jonathan Lavigne and Jean-Francois Major. It is based in Montréal, Québec, Canada. The studio focuses on fast games with classic design and pixel art, and debuted with Wizorb in September 2011. Later the studio moved into publishing for other teams, with Steel Assault (2021) as its first title in that role.

Tt Games Ltd. is a UK company founded in 2005 by the merger of development studio Traveller's Tales and publisher Giant Interactive Entertainment, Ltd. The company consists of the development studios Travellers Tales and Tt Fusion, the animation studio Tt Animation, and the publishing division Tt Games Publishing. Tt Games was acquired by Warner Bros. on 8 November 2007.
Two Star Games is the independent game development studio of Gavin Eisenbeisz. It was established in 2017.

Vivid Image is one of the finest development houses in Europe, involved in creating only the highest quality original games.  The company has a small but a very talented and dedicated team of people, headed by award-winning developer Mevlut Dinc. We are renowned for originality and unsurpassed technical achievement. The company was originally located in the United Kingdom, but in November 2000 Mevlut Dinc relocated himself and Vivid Image to his native country Turkey and set up Dinc Interaktif as the new company.
Waku Waku Games is a "micro-indie" publishing label of Chorus Worldwide Games, Ltd.
A Russian company developing casual games for PC/Mac/iPhone/iPad.
Wordlab is a company that specializes in videogame localization. It was established in 2005 by Diana Díaz Montón.

YAGER Development GmbH is an independent developer of computer and video games based in Berlin, Germany.  Founded in 1999 by five dedicated developers and artists, our focus is the creation of vivid and meaningful AAA gaming experiences.  Today, a team of 100 plus developers is busy at work bringing YAGER’s vision of gaming to life.

Zainsoft (also known as Sein and Xain), established in 1984, was a Japanese developer of games for personal computers. They were a competitor of Nihon Falcom in the field of early action role-playing games with titles like Tritorn (1985) and others.

Zed Two was formed in 1996 by John and Ste Pickford (who originally formed Zippo Games in 1988, and also worked with Nintendo and Rare during the mid-1990s). Originally, Zed Two started up in Ste's house, with no funding at all, but soon boomed into a major development house thanks to the puzzle game, Wetrix. It was located in Manchester, United Kingdom. In December 2002, Zed Two was acquired by Warthog of UK and no longer existed as an independent company. In 2005, the Pickfords went on to form a new company, Zee 3 Limited, an online distributor and publisher of digital media.

14° East (read as 14 Degrees East) was founded on 3 March 1999 as the strategy division of Interplay Entertainment Corp., headed by Brian F. Christian. They developed games in the Fallout franchise and Star Trek-licensed games. After 1999, Taldren was effectively spun off from 14° East. In June or July 2002, the official website was taken down and the link from Interplay's site was removed, implying a closure occurred around this time.
2K Games Madrid, referred to also as simply 2K Madrid, is a testing and QA studio of Take-Two Interactive Software under its 2K Games label. It was founded in Madrid, Spain in 2021.

Action Forms Ltd. is a game software developing company, based in Kiev, Ukraine. It was founded in 1995 by four enthusiasts Oleg Slusar, Yaroslav Kravchenko, Igor Karev and Denis Vereschagin. It took almost two years to form a solid professional team, including programmers, level designers, sound engineers and artists. Currently the company is dormant and members have founded Tatem Games to port games in the Carnivore franchise to platforms such as iPhone, iPad, PSP and PS3.
Albion sp. z o.o. was founded back in 1994 in Wrocław, Poland. The company has created and published mainly multimedia programs and games for children. It was closed in 2006.

Angry Mob Games is an independent iPhone development studio started around June 2009 and based in Romania. Their first game, Guerrilla Bob was released in early 2010 and later reworked for other platforms such as the iPad, Android, Windows and Macintosh. Previously, four of the studio's main developers worked at 24seven3D for six years (2003-2009), providing 3D art assets for commercial games. They contributed to FUEL for instance. Bogdan Iliesiu, CEO of Angry Mob Games, was also CEO and Creative Director of 24seven3D. In the summer of 2010 a second game was released: Predators, as a tie-in for the 2010 Robert Rodriguez movie.

Arkane Studios, LLC was a game development studio based in Austin, Texas (USA), incorporated on 24 May 2005. It was established as a sister studio to the French company Arkane Studios SASU. One of the co-founders Raphaël Colantonio moved to the US to help set up the new studio and it was opened in July 2006. Most of the development remained in France and the focus for the Austin studio was establishing relationships with other studios to generate work-for-hire projects to augment Arkane's own projects. The studio co-developed the 2012 title Dishonored. The company's closure was announced on 7 May 2024.

Aspiegel is a subsidiary of Chinese electronics and telecommunications company Huawei Technologies established in Dublin, Ireland in 2015. As of April 2019, the company operates all of Huawei's mobile services, including the AppGallery store, in Europe, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand.

Bay 12 Games was founded by Tarn Adams and Zach Adams in Silverdale, Washington (USA). The company established an online presence in December 2000 and is "dedicated to providing original games free of charge" with financial contributions from the public.
The Bearded Ladies Consulting is the name used by the Swedish company ayeWARE AB for its game development.

Blackbird Interactive (often abbreviated as BBI) is a private, independent game studio headquartered in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. The company was founded in 2010. The founders are a team of experienced and successful video game industry veterans including senior Electronic Arts staff and founders of Relic Entertainment. In 2010 development started with an ambitious sci-fi game entitled Hardware. Inspired by Homeworld, a franchise developed by some of BBI's founders, it was originally planned as a free-to-play real-time strategy game. After Gearbox Software bought the Homeworld IP in 2013, a deal was signed at PAX between Gearbox and BBI to turn Hardware into the next game in the Homeworld franchise and that became Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak, released in January 2016. They would also remaster the first two games in the series in 2015, as well as develop a full-blown sequel Homeworld 3, released in 2024. Their title Hardspace: Shipbreaker was released in 2020 in early access and 2022 as a full product. The licensed RTS CrossFire: Legion also shipped in 2022 to a lukewarm response.
Blendo Games is the name Brendon Chung uses to releases his modifications and independent games.
Bluehole Studio, Inc. is a Korean game development studio that focuses on MMORPGs. It was established in March 2007.

Bluemoon Interactive hails from Estonia, and is best known for the SkyRoads lineage of futuristic racing games. Their latest game project was Thunder Brigade, which didn't become a commercial hit because of the lack of gameplay testing time. The company's team was also instrumental in writing the software for the popular file-sharing program KaZaA and peer-to-peer Internet telephony software Skype.
The company specialised in creating graphical assets for computer and video games.
COWCAT is an independent video game development and publishing company based in France. It is owned by Fabrice Breton.
CTW Inc. (short for Change The World Inc.) is a Japanese company which operates G123.jp, an online portal for free-to-play browser games.
Caiysware are games developed and designed by Anthony Case aka Caiys.

Tap4Fun is a videogames company headquartered in Chengdu, China, with studios in Paris, Beijing, Barcelona and Bangkok. The core business of the company focuses on developing, operating and investing in mobile online games.
Chukong, also know as Chukong Technologies, is the Chinese company behind the Cocos2d framework. It also owns CocoaChina and PunchBox. It was established in 2010.
Together with Detalion Games, the Detalion Art studio appears to be a continuation of the former Detalion after its closed its door. Detalion Art creates graphics for computer and video games.

Contrail was a second-party development and production house owned by Sony Computer Entertainment Inc. It was established on October 14, 1997 and headed by Takahiro Kaneko. As a division of Sony, Contrail oversaw development of a number of titles, most notably the Wild Arms and Alundra series. Contrail ceased to exist in August 2000 when SCEI consolidated its internal development.

The company was founded by Mark Sheeky in 1991 under the original name of Scorpius Software, developing shareware and commercial games for Amiga computers. Their first PC game was Arcangel in 1999, a squad level strategy game. Cornutopia is based in South Cheshire in the United Kingdom and now develops and sells games and utilities for Windows PC's. For the most part Mark Sheeky designs, programs and creates all of the necessary graphics and sound for the software devloped by Cornutopia. Andrew Williams assists with game designs and proofreading, and a small team of friends and volunteers help with the final stages of testing and feedback. In 2007 Cornutopia Music was formed.
