A record label and music publisher, Cornutopia Music provided an outlet for Cornutopia game music and the instrumental music of Mark Sheeky.

Cryptic Studios, Inc., located in Los Gatos, California (USA) was established in June 2000 and was initially an independent developer of massively multiplayer online games for the PC and next generation consoles. Its first game, City of Heroes, was launched in April 2004. In October 2005, it launched the sequel City of Villains. In February 2008, Cryptic Studios announced that it was developing Champions Online, a high-action, totally customizable, superhero MMORPG based on the Champions role-playing game. It was released in September 2009. In November 2008, Cryptic Studios recruited Flagship Studios co-founder Bill Roper as Design Director and one month later, in December 2008, Atari announced to have acquired the company for 26.7 million dollar, along with a performance-linked deal. Ubisoft also wanted to acquire the company, but was beaten to the punch by Atari. The studio's first title developed for Atari was the MMORPG Star Trek Online. It was released in February 2010. In May 2011 Atari's financial results revealed that the studio was listed as "discontinued operations" and Atari said to be looking for a buyer. Support for Star Trek Online and Champions Online was continued, as well as work on a new title, Neverwinter. Atari stated to move on to fewer, but more profitable releases as well as expanding into mobile and casual games, and relying more on external development teams. It was announced a few weeks later that Cryptic had been acquired by Perfect World Entertainment (later Gearbox Publishing San Francisco). Despite revenues of €15.9 million over the last 12 months before the announcement, Cryptic still made a loss of €5.3 million. That was however an improvement over the €12.6 million loss of the year before. On 3 November 2023, the company laid off an undiscosed number of employees and was moved to the Deca Games division of the Embracer Group.

Crytek UK was a development studio of Crytek GmbH and it was based in Nottingham, UK. The company was initially founded as Free Radical Design. After leaving developer Rare in February 1999, former GoldenEye 007 and Perfect Dark team members David Doak, Steve Ellis, Karl Hilton and Graeme Norgate began trading as independent development studio Free Radical Design a mere two months later in April 1999. The company was based in Sandiacre, Nottingham, England. With a team of only eighteen, Free Radical shipped and delivered the first-person shooter TimeSplitters to Eidos for the PS2 launch in October 2000. Over the years Free Radical Design received numerous awards and nominations including CTW Developer of the Year 2001, the Develop Industry Excellence award for Best Independent Development Studio in 2003, along with five BAFTA nominations for TimeSplitters 2 in 2004, and two BAFTA nominations for Second Sight in 2005. Furthermore, they were listed in the Sunday Times Tech Track 100 as one of the UK's fastest growing technology companies. The studio only developed first person shooter games. After the TimeSplitters series and Second Sight, the studio's final game was Haze (2008), which received mediocre to negative reviews. On 18 December 2008, the studio was reported closed, after the development of the next game for LucasArts, Star Wars: Battlefront III, did not go through. There was also no publisher announced for TimeSplitters 4 and it was reported that two of the founders, Dave Doak and Steve Ellis, had already left the company earlier that month and established the studio Pumpkin Beach. On 31 December 2008, an administrator announced the studio had not been closed entirely (140 employees had been let go), but that about 40 people had been kept on board to work on a new game concept. It paid off, as on 3 February 2009, Rob Yescombe confirmed the studio had been acquired by Crytek. It was consequently renamed Crytek UK. As a part of Crytek it focused on multiplayer and console development. The first title the UK studio was involved with for Crytek was Crysis 2 (2011). In January 2013, Crytek bought the Homefront IP following publisher THQ's bankruptcy for $500,000. In June 2014, the title Homefront: The Revolution was revealed, in development at Crytek UK, with a tentative release date for 2015. On 30 July 2014, however, it was confirmed Koch Media (via the Deep Silver label) bought the entire Homefront IP from Crytek. At the same time the new Deep Silver Dambuster Studios was established and in accordance with UK law all Crytek UK staff moved along to the new studio, ending the UK Crytek presence. A relaunch of Free Radical Design proper was started by Embracer Group in May 2021 to work on the TimeSplitters series, but was closed by 11 December 2023.
Founded in 2018 as a part of Room 8 Group, Dragon's Lake Entertainment is a full-cycle game development service provider focused on AAA/AA+ PC and console games.

Darkside Game Studios is a game development studio formed in 2008 and based in Coral Springs, Florida (USA). It is the game development division of Shadows in Darkness, Inc. That company was started in 2002 with the goal to grow into a full game development studio, but it became best known for its art outsourcing services. Darkside Game Studios was then started as a separate studio so as to keep the activities separate.

Double Sided Games is a publisher of homebrew video games with a focus on retro computers. Based in Quebec, Canada, the company was founded in 2018 and has since published games for the VIC-20, Commodore 64, and Amiga platforms.

Efecto Studios is a game development studio based in Bogota, Colombia. It was established in March 2011 by three of the four founders of Immersion Software & Graphics Ltda. (Julián Andres Castillo, José Miguel Posada, Eivar Rojas Castro) along with CFO William Ocampo Flores. The studio develops games for PC, PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, iOS and Android devices. The team debuted with the iOS game Grabbity in August 2012.
Epic Games Publishing is a publishing label of Epic Games, Inc. It was announced on March 2020. The first game to carry the label was Alan Wake: Remastered in 2021.

Exact (EXcellent Application Create Team) was a small Japanese development studio established circa 1990 by Hiroyuki Saegusa, Kazuki Toyota, Toshimitsu Ōdaira, and Hiroshi Yamamoto. The company produced a number of action games for the Sharp X68000, the last of which, Geograph Seal, would be reworked into their first PlayStation title, Jumping Flash. Exact continued to work with Sony through the late '90s, producing a number of first-party PlayStation titles. The team would eventually become part of Sony studio Sugar & Rockets around 1998, which was then subsequently merged into SCEI in 2000.

FASA Studio, formerly FASA Interactive, was the video game arm of tabletop game company FASA Corporation. Hence, it worked with the latter's BattleTech license, including the MechWarrior and Mech Commander series. On 19 November 1998, they became a development studio for Microsoft, who simultaneously acquired the video game rights to the BattleTech and Shadowrun intellectual properties. FASA Studio would have its MechWarrior 3 project moved in schedule as MechWarrior 4: Vengeance due to development problems, while Zipper Interactive stepped in for MechWarrior 3 to release in 1999. In the 2000s, FASA Studio would also release Crimson Skies: High Road to Revenge in 2003 and their final game Shadowrun in 2007. The company closed its doors on 13 September 2007.
A Russian company engaged in the development of multimedia products and games, localization of Western projects for the domestic market, production.

With its headquarters located in Taipei, Taiwan, Gamania Digital Entertainment Inc. publishes and develops online interactive entertainment contents. Spanning across markets in Greater China, Japan and Korea, along with the proprietary GASH virtual bank system, Gamania provides services for MMOG titles including Lineage, Lineage II, EverQuest, Seal Online and others.

Honeyslug is an independent game development studio founded in mid-2008 by Ricky Haggett, Mark Inman and Nat Marco, ex-members of an Eidos development team.  In September 2015, they announced their departure from Honeyslug to pursue new projects. Honeyslug remained open to distribute games produced by the studio.
In Utero is the game development department of Mater Machina, a company dedicated to multiformat artistic production in France. In Utero is located in Montreal, Quebec, Canada.
Innerwaves was a French localization and sound design studio. It was active at least since 1998. The company website disappeared in 2003.
Interphase Technologies Inc. was reportedly a one-man operation, with all of the games being designed and programmed by Stephen Willey from his home near Vancouver, Canada.
A small Russian studio-developer of browser games.

Kadokawa Corporation is the holding company which, among others, holds Kadokawa Games, Ltd. and Kadokawa Shoten. It has no direct relation to video games and no games should be associated with this company entry.
Katauri Interactive is a Russian game development studio based in Kaliningrad. It was founded in 2004 by members of Elemental Games.
KingsIsle Entertainment, Inc., founded in January 2005 by Elie Akilian, creates massive multiplayer online entertainment. The company employs industry veterans from Midway, Wolfpack and Ion Storm.
Knights Peak is a publishing label of My.Games established in June 2024, focusing on premium games.

Kronos Digital Entertainment was a North American game developer based in Pasadena, California. The company was founded by Stanley Liu in 1992 as an animation and CG effect house. During their early days they collaborated with Sierra, creating the animated intro for King's Quest VI and art assets for Phantasmagoria. Their first independent game was Criticom (1995), followed by a few other versus fighting games. The company is best known for their Fear Effect games. Their last game was Fear Effect 2: Retro Helix (2001). Unable to find a publisher for Feat Effect 3: Inferno, the company disbanded in 2002.

This Russian Voronezh-based development company was founded in May 24, 2004 and launched their first project, The Bad, The Ugly and The Sober, a comic adventure game set in Wild West. Published by Akella in 2008, this game and 4 other titles were released in the fall of 2009. All of them as well as all upcoming projects are classical adventure games.
MWM Interactive is a division of Madison Wells Media, LLC. It started in 2015 as VR game developer Reality One (later MWM Immersive), but rebranded itself as publisher MWM Interactive in 2019.

MegaHouse Corporation is a major Japanese toy manufacturer, and part of the Bandai group of companies. Originally established in March 1962 as Kagaku Giken Co., Ltd. (often shortened to "Kaken"), the company was acquired by Bandai in March 1996. In March 1997, it was merged with two other Bandai subsidiaries, Angel and B-AI, and rebranded under its current name four months later. Though the company published a small number of PlayStation and Wonderswan titles, its primary business has shifted to children's toys, puzzles, and anime figures.

Whiteboard was a development company established in 1985, which produced arcade and home mahjong games such Mahjong Cop Ryū. The company was run by Takeshi Tozu, who had previously run Crux and Orca, and mostly did development work for SEGA. By 1989, the company's name had changed to Santos and it produced a handful more arcade and Mega Drive titles, most notably Battle Golfer Yui. The company was acquired by SEGA in December 1991, and renamed once more to Megasoft. As a division of SEGA, Megasoft produced two titles, Aa Harimanada and Shinobi III, but the staff was soon after merged into SEGA's own internal R&D departments. After the buyout by SEGA, Takeshi Tozu left the company to establish another development studio also called Santos, which would eventually be merged into Aicom when Yumekobo was established. Another group of former Santos staff led by Tomohiro Ishigai established Gaibrain in the early '90s.

MobilityWare is a division of California-based software developer Upstanding. It was established in 2003 with the purpose of developing software utilities for PDAs. In 2008 the company expanded into the realm of games, releasing 10 games onto the iOS AppStore when it launched on July 2008.

Nude Maker Co., Ltd. is a Japanese development company founded on 15th November 2002. The company focuses on hentai titles but has recently returned to regular games by co-developing Infinite Space with Platinum Games. Members such as Hifumi Kouno have an extensive history in game development.
ODT S.A. is a game development company based in Montevideo, Uruguay. It was founded in 2005 by Fernando Sansberro. It uses the name Batovi Games Studio for its games.
Pixmain is the publishing arm of the company ByteDance, known for the TikTok social media platform. The establishment was revealed in November 2020.

Plus Localization, formed by experienced people of Turkish translation sector in May 2019, is a team that translates video games which Turkish gamers desire to play. Their team includes people who have been working on Turkish game translations since 2013. The company's most important mission is to localize the maximum amount of games to make video games more understandable for Turkish people.
Rainbow Train is an indie company run by ​Maciej Targoni and based in Miedzylesie, Poland.

Rarebyte is an Austrian development studio formed in 2006 as Rarebyte Angermann OEG. The team first came together in 1999 to work on projects, but waited seven years to officially establish the company. The key management team consists of Rainer Angermann (CEO), Christoph Probst (CFO), and Mateusz Gorecki (Lead Artist). The name of the company was changed in August 2009 to Rarebyte OG.

4A Games is a video game development company founded in 2006 in Kiev, Ukraine by former employees of GSC Game World, including several programmers who worked on the engine used in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games. They came to prominence with their first title, Metro 2033, for which they developed the new 4A Engine. In May 2014, the company announced they were opening a new headquarters in Malta and relocating key members of staff to the new studio. As of 2017, there were 80 employees based in the Kiev studio and 70 in Malta.

Red Barrels is a game development studio based in Montreal, Canada. It was founded in 2011 by Philippe Morin, David Chateauneuf and Hugo Dallaire. They all previously worked at Ubisoft Divertissements (Ubisoft Montreal) and Daillaire also at EA Montreal. The studio was first revealed in July 2012. In the same month Réjean Charpentier joined the company. In September three more members joined: Jonathan Abenhaim, Alexandre Sabourin and Patrick Lalonde, and in October Marc-Antoine Senecal became part of the team. On 17th October 2012 the studio announced its first game, the survival horror game Outlast.
Owned and operated by Seth and Akiko Robinson, Robinson Technologies is located in Hiroshima, Japan. This husband and wife team have developed a wide variety of games and software.

From self-presentation in 2017:   Rocketcat Games is a small company made up of three people.   We make games with a focus on depth, experimenting with familiar mechanics, and hat fashion.   We are:  Kepa Auwae: Planning, Business Stuff, Design. Updates Twitter and Facebook.  Jeremy Orlando: Programming, Sound, Special Effects. * Brandon Rhodes: All other Art, and a lot of the writing.

Rollingmedia Limited is a UK development studio with Roll7 as its trading name. Most likely it is also part of RDIP Ltd., a company established in 2019. It is owned by Take-Two Interactive Software, Inc., which announced the acquisition of the studio on 15th November 2021, as part of its Private Division publishing label. It was founded on 30th April 2008 by John Ribbins (Creative Direction), Simon Andrew James Bennett (Business / Marketing) and Thomas James Hegarty (Production) who have a background in Education, Music and Creative Multimedia – having founded the pioneering youth education company; RollingSound. Between 2008-2013, Roll7 worked as a gun-for-hire studio on original IP and marketing projects for a number of clients, including Channel 4, The Home Office, Lloyds Banks and NeuroSky. During this time, the team also created several prototypes. In 2013, Roll7 pivoted to focus entirely on developing and exploring its own original IP. From a small studio in Deptford in south-east London, the team developed three original titles over three years; OlliOlli, Not a Hero and OlliOlli2: Welcome to Olliwood. With over 75 Awards and Nominations, the OlliOlli series has over 3 million players across 12 platforms and remains Roll7's most successful IP to date. In 2016, Roll7 moved its operations from a physical office into the cloud and developed a distributed production model, scaling up to over 30 people for the multiplayer title – Laser League. ​In 2021, they introduced OlliOlli World; a new direction in the OlliOlli franchise with Take-Two's publishing label Private Division that acquired the studio. In August 2022 Rollerdrome was released. The studio's games strife to offer fast action-based gameplay that is described as 'Flow State Gaming' where mechanics and controls are intuitive and refined, but are meant to grow deep requiring a strong focus until players reach the 'zone'; fully immersed in focus and involvement. This is for instance apparent in the quick tricking and comboing in the OlliOlli games, the popping, sliding and shooting in Not a Hero, or weaving through the hypnotic patterns of Laser League.
Sakari Indie (Sakari Games) is a independent development studio based in Antwerp, Belgium. It is owned by Pepijn Rijnders who is the creative director of the company.

Sega Technical Institute was a San Francisco, CA development studio run by Sega of America between 1989 and 1996. The studio produced three original titles, Kid Chameleon, Comix Zone, and The Ooze, and also assisted other Sega divisions with development, notably Sonic the Hedgehog 2 with Sonic Team, and Die Hard Arcade with Sega AM1. Additionally, Sonic Team used the studio's facilities during the development of Sonic the Hedgehog 3 and Sonic & Knuckles, though the STI team was not directly involved with development of these titles. The studio was disbanded in 1996 following the completion of Die Hard Arcade and the cancellation of Sonic X-Treme. Several key team members including Adrian Stephens and Peter Morawiec would go on to establish the development studio Luxoflux following STI's closure. Sonic Team would also later return to San Francisco in 1999 to establish Sonic Team USA. Other notable STI alumni include Mark Cerny and Stieg Hedlund.
State of Play is a London, UK-based casual games development studio established in 2008 by Luke Whittaker and Katherine Bidwell.

Supergiant Games is an independent development studio based in San Jose, California (USA). The formation of the company was first announced on 9 March 2010. It was established by three developers who previously worked together at Electronic Arts Los Angeles and quit in August 2009: Amir Rao, Gavin Simon and Darren Korb, shortly thereafter joined by Greg Kasavin.

TaleWorlds Entertainment is a independent Turkish development studio, originally started by a husband and a wife in 2005. The company is known for the free-form medieval warfare sandbox game series Mount & Blade.

The Artistocrats is a game development studio based in Hasselt, Belgium. It was established on 17th September 2009. The team specializes in strategy titles and is known for the Order of Battle series. In 2022 Starship Troopers: Terran Command was released, a real-time strategy game based on the popular sci-fi franchise.

The Chinese Room is a UK game development studio based in Brighton, England and it was founded by Dan Pinchbeck. It originated as a mod team for Half-Life 2 at the University of Portsmouth in 2007, which lead to the release of its first full standalone game Dear Esther in 2012 as a remake of its Dear Esther mod, one of the team's many modifications. Initially the studio was called Thechineseroom, but it was renamed The Chinese Room on 11 June 2013. It is named after John Searle's Chinese room thought experiment. In August 2018, it became a subsidiary of Sumo Digital. On 21 July 2025, it became independent again after a management buyout.

Tower Studios is a London, UK based developer of games, founded by industry veterans Jon Hare, Mike Montgomery and John Phillips on 4th June 2004.  2005 they rewrote two Sensible Software games to work on mobile phones: Sensible Soccer and Cannon Fodder. In 2006 the company released British Lions Rugby 7s. In 2009, Jon Hare took sole control of the company. In 2009, Me Motes Messenger, a messaging app, was developed with Atomic Planet for a U.S. publisher. In 2010, Tower released Vivid Games title Shoot to Kill on iOS. In 2011-2013 Speedball 2 Evolution, a modern version of the Bitmap Brothers' classic futuristic sports title, developed by Vivid Games was released on iOS, Android, Steam and Playstation. In 2014 Word Explorer, a world-exploring word game and Jon Hare's first original design to be published in 20 years was released on iOS and PC. In 2016-2017, Tower toured Sociable Soccer, its football title for mobile, PC, console & VR, around European venues including the London Science Museum.
Started in August 2000, Unimatrix Productions began as a group of internet buddies intent on creating computer-animated flash movies. The company mainly develops games in the adventure genre.
VRKiwi is a publishing label of Mekiwi.

column1: Wayi International Digital Entertainment Co., Ltd.
column2: Wayi International Digital Entertainment (traditional Chinese: 華義, Hua Yi, also known as Hwaei and Waei) is a Taiwanese company based in Taipei. The company was founded on August 12th, 1993. During the 1990s they focused on translating and porting Japanese PC-98 games to DOS. Afterwards they began to concentrate almost exclusively on online role-playing games.
Blue Shadow Games is a game development studio established in 2010. It is based in Granada, Spain.

ZeniMax Online Studios, LLC is a division of ZeniMax Media Inc., the parent company of Bethesda Softworks. It was founded on 1st August 2007 and focuses on the Massively Multiplayer Online Game (MMO) market segment. It is headed by Matt Firor, one of the founders of Mythic Entertainment. The company is located in located in Hunt Valley, Maryland (US).

2015, Inc. (pronounced twenty-fifteen) is an independent company located in Tulsa, Oklahoma, specializing in first-person, 3D action games for the PC, consoles and handhelds. The company was founded in 1997 by Tom Kudirka. Some of the first titles by 2015 were created by the separate development division Trainwreck Studios (first announced in April 2000), specializing in mid-price to budget games. Under that name Laser Arena (2000) and CIA Operative: Solo Missions (2001) were created. In 2007 it resurfaced with Time Ace for the Nintendo DS. 2015, Inc's first own title was SiN: Wages of Sin (1999), an expansion to Ritual Entertainment's popular shooter SiN (1998). The studio is especially known for pushing Electronic Arts' Medal of Honor series forward with the release of World War II shooter Medal of Honor: Allied Assault in 2002, the first game in the series to appear on the Windows platform. Following the release, EA decided to move development on expansions for the title to its internal Electronic Arts Los Angeles team. A large part of the upper echelons of the company left to form Infinity Ward, a studio that would become known for the rival Call of Duty series based around the same concept. The studio, no longer involved with either of the two franchises, started work on an entirely new game: a shooter set during the Vietnam era. That game became Men of Valor and it was released in 2004  In September 2008 the company announced to have opened the development branch Tornado Studios, focused on casual games. At the same time, 2015, Inc. confirmed that it was still focused on developing action games.

ALTAR interactive is a sister company of ALTAR publishing, the creator and publisher of the most successful fantasy role-playing game in the Czech Republic, Dragon's Lair, and other fantasy and board games. In 1997, after gaining experience from hobby games in the field of computer entertainment, the developers decided to make use of their contacts. They published their first game in 1998: Fish Fillets, a puzzle game for two fish and one brain. Next, they developed the RTS game Original War for Virgin Interactive Entertainment, followed by UFO: Aftermath for Cenega Publishing in 2003 and UFO: Aftershock (2005). ALTAR Interactive is based in the Czech Republic.

Another Ltd. was an independent programming company run by Naoki Morishima in the late 1980s. The company ceased to exist in 1991 when Morishima joined Toshiba-EMI after working on the Genesis port of Master of Monsters.

Arrowhead Game Studios is an independent game development studio based in Stockholm, Sweden. The team members have been working together since the beginning of 2008. The company was formed around the development of the game Magicka. Originally a student project at Luleå University of Technology, it won "Game of the Year" at the Swedish Game Awards 2008 and was turned into a commercial title. It was released in January 2011. The studio was originally located in Skellefteå in northern Sweden, but after the completion of Magicka: Vietnam parts of the team relocated to Stockholm where a second studio was set up. In January 2012 the rest of the team followed. The company's second game, The Showdown Effect was released in March 2013.

column1: Art Bully Productions India Pvt. Ltd.
column2: Art Bully Productions India Pvt. Ltd. is a division of Art Bully Productions based in Gautam Buddha Naga, India. It was established on 23rd June 2020.

B-Side Games was a Japanese publisher owned by Flyhigh Works which specialized in physical releases of indie games.  On August 31st 2021 B-Side Games closed its online shop and discontinued all sales.

column1: BANDAI NAMCO Studios Malaysia Sdn. Bhd.

column2: THE BROTHERHOOD is the development studio of the brothers Christopher Bischoff and Nicolas Bischoff.

Bedtime Digital Games is an independent game development studio based in Aalborg, Denmark. It started as a student production for the 2011 browser game Back to Bed up to Christmas in 2011. It attracted the attention of local and international press and the team decided to develop it further into an expanded game, fixing the bugs, adding more levels and bringing it to more platforms. Most of the work was done in the weekends as many team members had either no or limited time for development due to their jobs. The game did well in several game shows and conferences and received a good deal of nominations and wins. One of these conferences became the turning point for the title. It was among the student showcase winners at IGF 2013 in San Francisco, and even though it did not take home the grand prize it received a lot of attention, notably by CAP NOVA, a Danish investment firm with experience with games. Two team members, Klaus Pedersen and Jonas Byrresen, saw this as a chance do a complete professional release and perhaps something more in the long run. A smaller team was created during the latter half of 2013, and on 16th December 2013 the company Bedtime Digital Games was born. Finishing the game became a long trek and it also took a crowdfunding initiative for the 2014 release of Back to Bed. In the same year the team released the time travel puzzle platformer Chronology. Since then the team has released the musical action games Figment (2017) and Figment 2: Creed Valley (2023) as well as the puzzle adventure The Forest Quartet in 2022.
Game development studio Big Red Button Entertainment, Inc. was co-founded by industry veterans Bob Rafei and E. Daniel Arey. The company was publicly announced in February 2008.

Big Time Software was a development studio, active at least since 1994, and focused on historical strategy games with Charles Moylan as a prominent designer. In 1998 however, the publishing company Avalon Hill they signed with was in process of being acquired by Hasbro Interactive, Inc., which hindered the availability of Big Time Software's product in retail space. This was resolved when the company announced in 1999 to become a part of the publishing company Battlefront.com, which Moylan co-founded a few years earlier, and where the studio was eventually absorbed.

BioWare Austin is a division of BioWare, which is in turn owned by Electronic Arts. It was headed by Gordon Walton and Richard Vogel, and the opening was announced on 13 March 2006. The studio's first title is the MMORPG Star Wars: The Old Republic. It was launched in December 2011. It was announced in February 2011 that Gordon Walton had left the company for the social gaming studio Playdom.

Development studio Black Wing Foundation has existed since late 2006. The company has operating offices in Dnepropetrovsk and Kiev, Ukraine as well as representative offices in Moscow, Russia and Beijing, China. The studio's activities include game development, production and PR, and graphics and sound outsourcing. The Black Wing team is currently developing Scivelation, which was formerly known as Salvation.

Blizzard North was a North American developer based in San Mateo, California. It was founded in 1993 as Condor by Max Schaefer, Erich Schaefer, and David Brevik.  In June 1996, the company was acquired by Davidson & Associates, then-owners of Blizzard Entertainment, and renamed to Blizzard North. They went on to develop Diablo (1996) and its sequel Diablo II (2000). On 20 June 2003, eight key employees (including the founders) left the company to found Flagship Studios (later re-formed as Runic Games in 2008). Nine more left to form Castaway Entertainment. On 1 August 2005, Blizzard closed down the development team.
Breslin Studios was founded in 2008 and is involved with writing, editing, localization, and voice-over.
CP.Brain (株式会社シー・ピー・ブレイン) is a Japanese video game company led by former Aicom developer Takehiro Takemori.

Centroid Animation GmbH was an animation facility founded in 2004 and located in Berlin, Germany. An additional motion capture studio was established in January 2006. The Berlin location was lead by Studio Manager Sven Bergmann. This facility created high definition motion capture footage for the Playstation 2, Xbox and Xbox 360 consoles. Its parent company is Centroid Motion Capture (now named Centroid 3D Group), headquartered in the United Kingdom. This location shut down all studio operations in 2007. However, the name of this facility is still in existence since Centroid hopes to open another German studio in the future.

Champion Soft (チャンピオンソフト) is a software company based in Osaka, Japan. The company was founded in 1983 and was instrumental in popularizing the eroge market for personal computers. They released a few adult games under their main company name, but started using the Alice Soft brand in 1989.

Cipher Prime is a development studio that was first registered as the Delaware (USA) company Cipher Prime, LLC on 1st August 2008. On 29th June 2009 a second company called Cipher Prime Studios, Inc. was incorporated in Pennsylvania (USA). It is not clear which of the two names is used predominantly, but both companies are still active and exist alongside each other.
Co-FUN Games is a publishing label and sister brand to Shiravune used for releasing English and Chinese versions of Japanese doujin games.

The Crazy House Company founded in 2002 united people with a great experience in the game industry. Its main sphere of activity is development and localization of PC games. The company began with localizing the famous quest game “Phantasmagoria” for the “Soft-Club” and “Discus” companies, and then began cooperation with “Akella”, “Discovery” and "1C". In September 2002 the company began developing its first own project - a quest game named “Vij: Retold Story”, and in April the same year one more project: “Tank T-72 Balkans in Fire”. Moreover, the company also does some web-designing and developing of multimedia projects.

Crows Crows Crows GmbH is a game development studio founded by William Pugh and Dominik Johann in 2018 and it is based in Berlin, Germany. Previously the name Crows Crows Crows was already used by the UK company Roberts & Co Bunsen Outlet Limited, founded on 25th November 2013 by the same people. The studio is known for its experimental and humorous titles. William Pugh worked together with Davey Wreden as Galactic Cafe to create The Stanley Parable (2013). The 2022 version The Stanley Parable: Ultra Deluxe was developed and published by Crows Crows Crows as a whole. The team also worked together with Justin Roiland at Squanchtendo to create the Accounting VR titles.

Helmut Kobler and Ron Little founded Cyclone Studios in December 1993.  With the help from an angel investor's capital and monies out of their own pocket, Cyclone Studios produced a prototype of what would become Captain Quazar.  That prototype helped them secure a contract with 3DO to make Quazar for 3DO’s home console system.  Quazar was a top down isometric 3D cartoon-ish style shooter.  The contract allowed Cyclone to move from Ron Little’s apartment in Oakland to their first small office in Redwood City, California in June 1994. A second title was started called BattleSport that was also for the 3DO system.  BattleSport was a first person 3D tank/soccer type game similar to Ball Blazer.  Soon after in the spring of 1995, Cyclone moved into a still larger office in Menlo Park, California.  Quazar shipped in early 1996 and BattleSport in late 1995.  Both were met with moderate to solid critical acclaim but sold poorly. Poor sales of their first two titles put Cyclone in a dire financial situation at the end of 1995.  Little and Kobler were forced to sell the studio to the 3DO Company in the December 1995.  Cyclone Studios remained as a separate development house but was entirely funded by 3DO.  Kobler was given leadership of the new division and Little was given the roll of tech lead. In the summer of 1996, Cyclone moved to its final location in San Mateo, California.  Two original PC titles were born during this period.  Those two games were Requiem: Avenging Angel and Uprising.  Requiem was a story driven first person shooter.  Uprising was a hybrid first person action/strategy game.  Uprising shipped in October 1997 and Requiem in the April 1999.  Again, both were met with modest to solid critical acclaim but sold below expectations.  Two sequels were made that were inspired by Uprising’s critical success.  Uprising 2: Lead and Destroy for the PC and Uprising X for the Sony Playstation were the last games to be completed by Cyclone in their San Mateo office.   The company’s culture could be best described by a quote from Gordon Gekko in the film Wall Street, “Give me guys that are poor, smart and hungry.”  This seemed to be the hiring mantra for Cyclone.  For most of Cyclone’s history, nearly all the artists and programmers had little or no professional game development experience when hired.  Many of the employees were straight out of college.  Virtually all hires had one common trait.  All were avid lifetime gamers.  This mixture paid off in passionate and sometimes volatile results.  Despite the teams’ inexperience (or due to it) all the games made at Cyclone were built from the ground up.  Every game had it’s own unique code and art database.  Everything that went into the game was tailored to the game’s requirements.  This allowed for ideas to be more freely considered and added to the design by anyone involved with the game.  This also contributed to the enthusiasm and volatility at the company.   In the end, some employees would say it was the best job they ever had and others would say the worst.  However, all would agree it was never boring.  In December 1998, Cyclone Studios and its employees were absorbed into 3DO and closed its doors for good.

column1: Dark Design Studios Holdings Co. Ltd

column2: An international game studio, the main office of which is located in Riga, Latvia.
Darkling Room is a game development company founded by Jonathan Boakes and located in the United Kingdom.
Darkpaw Games is a division of Daybreak Game Company founded in January 2020. It is tasked with maintaining and creating new content for EverQuest and EverQuest II.

Darkworks S.A. was an independent game development studio based in Paris, France. It was founded on 8th January 1998 by Antoine Villette (President) and Guillaume Gouraud (General Manager and Artistic Director) as Darkworks Interactive. They both worked at Verity Interactive SARL, the French subsidiary of the American company Verity, Inc., and acquired it to establish it as their own studio. The name was later changed to Darkworks S.A. During its existence the team created and completed two games: Alone in the Dark: The New Nightmare (2001) and Cold Fear (2005) as full Darkworks titles. The team was also involved with other projects such as creating Les Visiteurs: Le Jeu (1998) together with Cryo Interactive Entertainment. Many sources claim the company worked on the PS2 / Xbox version of Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter (2006), but the credits only reveal that a number of Darkworks developers contributed to the level design of the Xbox 360 version, but without explicit mention of the company. Other titles the company was involved with are 1906: An Antarctic Odyssey (1998 - PS2 - sales demo) and USS Antarctica (Xbox - cancelled). Together with TriOviz the company created TriOviz for Games Technology, a technological solution that enables smooth stereoscopic 3D conversion of video games or multimedia products (Windows, Xbox 360, PS3). It was used in such games as Batman: Arkham Asylum (Game of the Year Edition), Enslaved: Odyssey to the West, Thor: God of Thunder, Green Lantern: Rise of the Manhunters, Captain America: Super Soldier, Gears of War 3, and Batman: Arkham City. The team then worked on a third title, I Am Alive, but in March 2009 it was announced Ubisoft had taken it out of their hands after three years in mutual agreement to have Shanghai UBI Computer Software Co., Ltd. finish it. It was eventually released as a Ubisoft game in March 2012. In September 2011 it was announced the studio would be closed. Another game called Black Death (Windows, Xbox 360, PS3) was still in development, but cancelled. TriOviz acquired all stereoscopic 3D technology and rights.

The Designers Republic was a British graphic design studio founded by Ian Anderson in 1986. The company was actively in all areas of design and advertising, and in relationship to games they were responsible for the visual design, packaging and manual of Sony's Wipeout series, the interface of Hardwar (1998), and packaging and posters for Grand Theft Auto (1997). On 20th January 2009 the company was closed.

Detalion was a Polish developer of computer software games, before closing due to financial difficulties in March of 2005. The games developed by Detalion were noted for the complexity and great difficulty of their puzzles, and also were hailed as having some of the best graphics in the industry at the time.  Detalion was one of the first developers to use the DVD-ROM disc as an effective medium for software distribution. Two new studios were established when Detalion closed its door: Detalion Games and Detalion Art.

Doctor Entertainment AB is an independent game development studio based in Uppsala, Sweden. It was founded in 2009 by the veterans Jesper Rudberg and Anders Pistol. The studio's first title, Puzzle Dimension, was released in June 2010.

Established in 1974, Dynamic Planning, Inc. (Dynamic Kikaku in Japanese) is the production company of manga luminary Go Nagai, and is involved in a wide variety of media ventures including manga, animation, and of course video games. Dynamic Production is a sister company, and is similarly involved in a wide array of fields.

column1: Eternal Alice Game Soft Co., LTD.

column2: Firesprite is a UK game development studio based in Liverpool. It was founded in 2012 and mainly consists of people who were previously with SCE Studio Liverpool (previously Psygnosis) before Sony closed it in 2012.

GameChanger Studio was founded by two academicians, a librarian with no gaming background and a lecturer with a dream to be a game developer. They both have developed more than 30 games since 2013 (PC and Mobile). The studio decided to focus on developing PC game after the viral success of “NSFW” that covered by youtubers with more than 7.5 million combined views. The success continues with “My Lovely Daughter” that not only gone viral in China but also followed with great sales. GameChanger Studio will always continue to develop a game that’s truly out of the box.

Gentle Giant is a 3D design and modeling studio best known for their sculptures of characters from television and movies. They can create detailed models from scratch, from 2D concepts, or from 3D scans made of real life objects and people.  Some of their work has included actor scans for Pirates of the Caribbean and Spy Kids, and their actual scanning equipment was seen in Iron Man. They also have their own line of movie and TV-inspired sculptures from works like Battlestar Galactica and Lord of the Rings.

Glowfish Interactive is a game development studio based in Kortrijk, Belgium. It was established in 2014 by Emiel De Paepe and Brecht Lecluyse who studied Digital Arts and Entertainment at Howest in Kortrijk. The studio provides art to other projects, but also creates its own concepts. Their first original game was Trifox (2022).

Hangar 13 Novato is a game development studio based in Novato, California, USA. It was established on 4 December 2014 with Haden Blackman as a division of 2K Games, a publishing label of Take-Two Interactive.
HeroCraft PC is a publishing label of HeroCraft Ltd.

High Impact Games was a game development studio founded in 2003 by former members of Insomniac Games. Originally based in North Hollywood, California, in 2007 the company moved to Burbank (USA). The company's releases include the PS2/PSP title Ratchet & Clank: Size Matters (2007/2008), the PSP game Secret Agent Clank (2008), and the PS2/PSP title Jak & Daxter: The Lost Frontier (2009). The studio was closed in November 2012.

Hit Maker, Inc., sometimes also written as Hit Maker Co. Ltd., is a Japanese game development company. It should not be confused with Hitmaker, the now-defunct SEGA development division formerly known as Sega AM3 R&D Division. It was founded in April 1998.

Hobby Japan (ホビージャパン) is a Tokyo-based company mainly specializing in toys and action figures. The company was founded on September 27th, 1969. They also release card and table games (including role-playing games). Hobby Japan also produced computer games, such as Ring Master RPG series, which mirrored the mechanics developed for their table RPGs.
Hook is a publishing division of Digital Bros. It is based in Milan, Italy. The establishment was announced in July 2022. Published titles are often violent and aimed at a mature audience.
Horrorsoft was a label from Adventure Soft UK that was created to publish their multimedia horror adventure games.

Ice Code Games is a Polish game development studio with offices in Kraków, Rzeszów and Warsaw, even though most of the production team works remotely. It was established in 2014 by Paweł Wilk and Mateusz Pilski, who met during their years at the university of Warsaw. In the early years the company Solution3.14 was also used, which Wilk established independently in 2012. Their first game was an AR multiplayer mobile game called Hools: Football Club Territory (2013), where players fight enemy football clubs for control over territories. It was inspired by Ingress. The team grew and work was started on the prototype of a real-time strategy game known as Cult, with the player controlling a protagonist cult leader in a cyberpunk world. In the meantime more experiments with VR were done and in 2017 the platform game Deep Blue 3D Maze in Space with VR support was released. The following years the studio released the puzzle game Packed Train (2018) and Cult saw the light of day as Re-Legion in 2019. In 2022 the tactical strategy game Hard West II was released. On 7th February 2022 the company announced it had merged with Avatrix SA, for which negotiations started in 2020 but were slowed down due to formalities and slower of work of courts during the COVID19 pandemic. As a result of the merger, Avatrix changed its name to Ice Code Games. The new company is led by Wilk as President and Pilski as Vice-President.

Igloo Digital Arts Sdn Bhd is an outsourcing company based in Malaysia. It was founded in April 2006 as a partnership between games industry professionals from the UK and founding members of Fly Studio Sdn Bhd, an independent CG studio based in KL, Malaysia. Helming the foundation are Ash Colclough as Chief Executive Officer in partnership with Wong Cheng Fei as Chief Operating Officer and Ken Foong as Art Manager. In May of the same year, industry veteran Glyn Williams joins the company as Chief Creative Officer & Chairman, responsible for overseeing all aspects of digital art production. Igloo Digital Arts' first major project was announced in April 2007, as they signed with Namco Bandai Games America Inc. to provide art services for Namco's US division in-house developed title Afro Samurai. They created about 70% of all art for the game. Since then they have also contributed art for Sonic & SEGA All-Stars Racing (2010) and Splatterhouse (2010). The studio has a UK division called  Igloo Digital Arts Ltd..

column1: Ingram Micro México S.A. de C.V.

column2: Rareware Limited was founded in 1995 as a sister company to Rare Limited, around the time when Nintendo Co., Ltd. bought a 49% share of Rare. Their purpose is not known exactly, but it is assumed they were used for Rare's self-publishing activities. It is important to note that the Rareware logo was trademarked to Rare Limited, not Rareware Limited, and appears on most Rare-developed games between 1994 and 2003. MobyGames uses Rareware when the logo says "published by Rareware".

Kepler Ghost is a division/subsidiary of Kepler Interactive established in 2023 meant for publishing, funding and marketing independent studios' titles. Their respective developers retain the intellectual properties.

Lost Boys Interactive is a game development studio established in 2017 by Shaun Nivens, Mark Stefanowicz and Rod Runnheim. It is a remote-first studio with offices in Madison, Wisconsin (USA) and Austin, Texas (USA). In 2020 Chase Jones and Timothy Gerritsen joined the company. On 21st April 2022 Gearbox Entertainment announced the studio's acquisition, adding Lost Boys' 220 team members to Gearbox's global headcount of approximately 1,300. Lost Boys became a subsidiary of Gearbox, part of the larger Embracer Group AB. The studio contributed to The Quiet Man (2018) and provided additional development for Tiny Tina's Wonderlands (2022).
MINTROCKET is a division of Nexon Korea Corporation. It was announced on 3rd May 2022. The studio's first title Dave: The Diver was released in Early Access in October 2022.
Making Fun, Inc. is a mobile and PC developer and publisher headquartered in the San Francisco Bay Area with staff and partner studios across the U.S., Canada, Argentina, Uruguay and Romania.

Motive Studios is a game development studio based in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. It was founded in July 2015 by Jade Raymond, previously an Ubisoft executive, and the company is owned by Electronic Arts. In August 2017 it was confirmed BioWare Montreal would be merged into Motive Studios.
MunkyFun is an independent studio founded in 2008 that creates  freemium mobile games.

The company Napoleon games was started by Jindřich Rohlík in 1994. We concentrate exclusively on development of high-quality computer games for the PC platform. We are always trying to shift the way in which the particular genre is perceived. We published our first computer game Colony 28 in 1996, two years later an RPG The Gates of Skeldal followed. This game was very successful in The Czech Republic. During the year 1999 we participated on the development of noir adventure Twilight (an original project of Numedia company). In 2002 we finished the game The Fifth Disciple, which was translated into several languages and is being distributed all around the world.
Nordcurrent Labs is a publishing label of Nordcurrent, established in 2021.
Other Ocean Emeryville is a division of Other Ocean and it is based in Emeryville, USA. Since 8th June 2015 it also houses the division Digital Eclipse.

P Studio is a development division of the Japanese company Atlus Co., Ltd.. The P in the company references the team working on the Persona series. The existence of the studio / brand / division was discovered in January 2013.
Paizo Inc. is a American tabletop role-playing game publishing company. It is best known for its Pathfinder and Starfinder intellectual properties.

Paradox Arctic was a development studio of Paradox Interactive AB located in Umeå, Sweden. They were founded in January 2014 and their first assignment was to take over the development of the ongoing multiplayer game War of the Roses: Kingmaker. The studio was closed in April 2023.

Paradox Thalassic was a game development studio of Paradox Interactive AB based in Malmö, Sweden. It was established in May 2017 to develop mobile games based on Paradox properties. It was closed in April 2023.

Phantagram (판타그램) is a South Korean video game developer and publisher. The company was established in June 1994 by Lee Sangyoun and Lee Kyuhwan, who previously worked together and developed games for Topia. For a short while, Phantagram was hosting the Sonnori team. In 2000, the company was acquired by NCSoft, but re-gained its independence shortly afterwards. Phantagram is best known for their Kingdom Under Fire series.

PortaPlay is a studio established in 2006. It is based in Copenhagen, Denmark. The company creates games, but also learning & edutainment titles, digital marketing and interactive entertainment. For games the studio has collaborated with the fellow Danish company NapNok Games (formerly KnapNok Games).
PowerSlash Studios is the independent game development studio of Marcell Rocha.

Purple Lamp Game Development GmbH is a game development studio based in Vienna, Austria. It was established in 2018 by former employees of Sproing Interactive Media GmbH, which had closed in 2017. Purple Lamp acquired the rights for the Sproing brand and certain games previously made by them. In November 2020, the company was acquired by Embracer Group, and was placed under THQ Nordic as the parent company.

PxlHrt is a group of freelance game localization specialists formed by former SEGA Europe in-house translators around 2018. They mainly work on SEGA and ATLUS titles. The team is managed by Luis J. Paredes López. Their first project as a group of freelancers was 13 Sentinels: Aegis Rim.
Quarter Circle Forward + Design (QCF Design) is a game development studio based in Cape Town, South Africa.
Radial Games is a game development studio founded by Andy Moore in 2010, Radial Games specializes in rapid-prototype development.
A multimedia house from Finland, founded in 2013. In addition to video game development they do commercial animation, web design, business videos and digital illustrations as commission work.

Strangelite is a development team based in the Northwest of England, comprising of several veterans of the games industry and some relative newcomers. Strangelite was an internal development team of Empire Interactive until March 2006 when it was acquired by Rebellion Developments, becoming one of their many development houses. Rebellion now refers to the old Strangelite studio as Rebellion Runcorn (aka Rebellion Liverpool).

The Reverb Team is a dynamic group of professionals bringing together years of expertise working with technology, consumer electronics, talent booking and event production. Our collective experience allows us to offer total business solutions to our clients. Working as an extension of your company, Reverb integrates into your business to provide the experience and resources necessary to communicate your message while increasing your bottom line. Located in the small Northern California town of Twain Harte, Reverb employees enjoy the fresh air of the Sierra Nevada Mountains with no traffic. The Reverb staff thrives in this low-hassle environment, which is demonstrated in the invigorating creative energy we bring to every account.

Runic Games, Inc. was a US game development studio founded by Travis Baldree, Max Schaefer, Erich Schaefer and Peter Hu following the closure of Flagship Studios. It was first announced on 8th August 2008 and consists of the team that worked on Mythos at Flagship. It is headed by Travis Baldree and Max Schaefer. The company's first release was Torchlight in October 2009. The company's closure was announced by Perfect World Entertainment on 3 November 2017.
SE {} KS is a developer & publisher of video games established in Germany in 2021.

Saber Interactive Spain S.L. is a game development studio based in Madrid, Spain. It is a division of the US company Saber Interactive, Inc. and it was established in July 2016 by Jesús Iglesias Sánchez. The studio is largely a continuation of Virtual Toys, S.L., which was closed in June 2016, a month earlier, and was also led by Sánchez. Prior to the closure the studio was working on NBA Playgrounds and that title was taken along and finished at Saber Interactive Spain.

column1: Shanghai Hode Information Technology Co., Ltd.

column2: Skunkape Games is a small team of developers mostly from the original incarnation of Telltale Games, led by former CEO and co-founder Dan Connors. Having acquired the rights to Telltale's Sam & Max series after the former company's liquidation, Skunkape creates remasters of those games.

Snap Finger Click is a British video game developer based in Brighton, England. The studio was founded in November 2015 by Martijn van der Meulen and Ed Gladwin, former employees of Sony PlayStation who met whilst working on PlayStation Home. The studio is as of 2020 made up of several former employees of Relentless Software.

Founded in 1973 by David and Muriel Hinkle, Sonalysts headquarter is located in Waterford, CT, USA, with an additional 19 offices located throughout the United States. Sonalysts started as sonar analysts for the US Navy (hence the name), but have since branched into many different aspects of business, including business consulting, production (full soundstage, video and audio), entertainment, education, and more.  Sonalysts have designed two games under the Jane's Combat Simulations when it was owned by Electronic Arts: 688(I) Hunter/Killer and Fleet Command. Both have been requisitioned by the US Navy for training purposes, and both are the only titles in that franchise to become available for sale after the license expiry, after they were modified to remove references to the Jane's Information Group.
Spherical Pixel S.L. is the brand name of, educational and advertising games developed on demand, by DevilishGames.

Squanch Games, Inc. is a virtual reality game development studio established in 2016 by Rick & Morty co-creator Justin Roiland and former Epic Games Executive Producer Tanya Watson. They are known for their humorous titles, for instance collaborating with Crows Crows Crows on the Accounting games. The company was first established as Squanchtendo Games, a portmanteau of Squanch (a planet from Rick & Morty) and Japanese platform holder Nintendo. On 5th December 2017 the company announced to rebrand as Squanch Games to avoid any potential clash with Nintendo, even though Nintendo did not contest the name nor sought legal action. On 8th January 2022 it was announced Tanya Watson stepped down as CEO with Justin Roiland taking over the next month, transitioning from the studio’s Chief Creative Officer to CEO. Watson stayed aboard as a consultant.
Square Enix London Studios is part of Square Enix Europe, sitting within Square Enix's European head office in Wimbledon, South West London (England).

Stellar Stone LLC was an American video game developer founded in 2000. They commissioned game development in Eastern European locations, primarily Russia and Ukraine, to produce games at low expenses. Out of their seven-title library, their only well-known game is Big Rigs: Over the Road Racing, a 2003 racing game considered to be one of the worst ever created, holding Metacritic's all-time lowest video game score at 8/100. After the release of Midnight Race Club: Supercharged! in 2004, the company ceased all operations, and had its website shut down in 2006.

Stormling Studios, originally known as Zoetrope Interactive, is a small independent game development company located in Istanbul, Turkey. The development team members are Onur Samli, Oral Samli and Galip Kartoglu.
T&E Soft, Inc. was established in 2008 when it split off from Digital Golf.

T3 Entertainment, Inc. is a Korean company involved with MMOGs. They are especially known for the dancing game Audition. The company picked up Hellgate: London and Mythos (still in development at the time) after development studio Flagship Studios was closed and T3 acquired a controlling stake in the publishing company HanbitSoft that claimed to own the rights to both games. To continue development on Mythos, a new development studio in San Francisco was established.
Teknogames is an independent game developer. The company also goes by the name Teknopants. The main developer is Beau Blyth.
TextFarm is a German localisation agency that has been around for 25 years. Most of the games are credited to its owner, Rolf D. Busch.
Yokohama-based developer of console (historically handhelds like the PSP/3DS) and smartphone games with a focus on anime IP titles.
Toneplus Animation Studios is a division of Nexus International LLC, a firm legally registered in Shinjuku, Tokyo and Miami, Florida.

We Create Stuff is a team of developers best known for creating Portal: The Flash Version, a 2D browser-based flash game inspired by Portal. When the developers later adapted their levels to the 3d Source engine, the original development studio Valve invited the team to have fourteen of them included in the Xbox 360 XBLA version of the game: Portal: Still Alive. The core team consists of Ido Tal and Hen Mazolski. On 14th June 2018 the studio was formally established as the Israeli private company Totes Magotes Ltd. The name Totes from Guts Ltd. is used as well. Publicly We Create Stuff is still mainly used as the company name.

Trilobyte Games, LLC was founded in November 2010 and is the successor company to Trilobyte, Inc., which closed down more than eleven years earlier. They ported Trilobyte's earlier games to iOS platforms.

Trilobyte was a computer game developer founded in December 1990 in Oregon, USA, by Graeme Devine and Rob Landeros. They are best known for their adventure game The 7th Guest (1993) and other multimedia titles. The company closed down in early 1999, but was revived eleven years later as Trilobyte Games.
Tripwire Presents is a publishing label of the US company Tripwire Interactive. The label was launched in 2020.

Ubisoft Entertainment India Pvt. Ltd., informally known as Ubisoft Mumbai, is a Ubisoft studio based in Mumbai, India. It is the second Ubisoft studio in the country following Ubisoft Entertainment India Pvt. Ltd. carrying the same name, but based in Pune. The studio was inaugurated on 1st October 2018.
United Label is a publishing label owned by the Poland-based company CI Games S.A.. The launch of the label was announced on 21st January 2019.

A Russian company that develops computer gamess. The team is also actively engaged in outsourcing for Russian and Western customers. The backbone of the team consists of people from the computer animation studio Animation Magic Inc.

Velan Studios is game development studio founded in 2016 by Guha Bala and Karthik Bala. It is based in New York City (USA). Previously they founded Vicarious Visions in 1994 and after the acquisition by Activision in 2005 they stayed with the company until April 2016.

Vigil Games was a game development studio based in Austin, Texas (USA). It was founded by comic artist Joe Madureira, David Adams, Marvin Donald and Ryan Stefanelli in 2005. The company was acquired by THQ Inc. in 2006. Vigil's first release was the action hack-and-slash game Darksiders (2010). The sequel Darksiders II was released in 2012. The studio also contributed to Homefront (2011). In December 2012 parent company THQ filed for Chapter 11. All of its studios and assets were up for sale, but Vigil was the only one that was not picked up and closed down when the auction ended on 22nd January 2013. Before its closure the studio had been working on Warhammer 40,000: Dark Millennium. Originally revealed in 2007, it was confirmed afterwards that development had been halted in March 2012. In a goodbye message on the website NeoGAF lead combat designer Ben Cureton revealed that the studio had been working on a project codenamed Crawler. Following the closure, Atsushi Inaba, producer at Platinum Games, expressed an interest in acquiring the Darksiders franchise. On 28th January 2013 Crytek GmbH announced to open the new studio Crytek USA Corp., headed by Vigil co-founder David Adams and 35 Vigil developers, making it the spiritual continuation of Vigil, but without taking along the Darksiders franchise. When Crytek USA was downscaled at the end of July 2014 and its project HUNT: Horrors of the Gilded Age was moved to the Crytek Frankfurt studio, Adams quit and took along a core group of former Vigil Games developers to establish the independent studio Gunfire Games.

Virtual Prophecy Entertainment is a dedicated computer game software developer based in South Florida. Since its creation in 2007, Virtual Prophecy Entertainment has always been centered on graphic superiority, pleasurable gameplay, and imaginative design. With this focus, Virtual Prophecy has established a foothold in the ever-changing games industry. As new technologies continue to move forward, we remain dedicated to retaining our creative nature while upgrading to an even higher level of quality in electronic gaming.
Virtuos China Ltd. is a division of Virtuos Ltd. and it is based in Shanghai, China.

Vitei Backroom, since 9th October 2020 publicly re-branded as Chuhai Labs, is a sister company to Vitei Inc. It is based in Tokyo, Japan. Vitei Backroom was created to make prototypes of virtual reality software and experimental games. Vitei Backroom works with a looser organization that the main Vitei company that uniquely works with Nintendo, as an extension of the Kyoto R&D and much more structured.

Void Studios is a game development studio based in Sao Paulo, Brazil. It was founded in February 2015. The studio debuted with the action RPG Eternity: The Last Unicorn in 2019. The team also contributed to G.I. Joe: Operation Blackout (2020), providing additional art. They also ported the PC title Fobia: St. Dinfna Hotel (2022) to consoles.
WB Games San Francisco is a division of Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment and it is based in Burbank, California (USA). It was established on 22nd March 2013.

Wilkin Games is a one-man operation by indie game developer Justin Wilkin. From 2010 to 2020 it was known as XWILKINX. Wilkin Games develops free games based on Flash (2010 to 2018) and HTML5 (since 2018) as well as asset packs.
Wings Interactive is the trading name of the Swedish company Vingar Interaktiva AB.

The Workshop was a game development studio based in Marina Del Ray, California (USA). It was founded in January 2008 by Peter Akemann (President), Chris Busse (General Manager) and Charles Tolman (CTO). Akemann previously founded the studio Treyarch Invention in 1996. The team debuted with the PS3 game Sorcery in May 2012. On 3rd May 2016 Skydance Media announced the acquisition of the company and the team was used to launch a new interactive division for the company: Skydance Interactive LLC.

World Forge, founded in late 2004, is a game development studio based in Voronezh, Russia. It was established by Burut Creative Team as an expansion of its activities and focused mainly on real-time strategy games. The studio created Ancient Wars: Sparta (2006) and its sequel/independent expansion pack Great War Nations: The Spartans (2007), as well as Age of Alexander (2009). Between the release of those three games set during the time of classic antiquity, the company released a real-time strategy game set in the middle ages called The Golden Horde (2008). The studio next game was the action RPG Taras Bulba. It was released under the banner of the World Forge development team, but was mainly created by Burut as the two studios had merged by then. At its height, the company had employed 50 employees. The studio still exists in 2023.
Yobike is a video game studio founded in 2018 by Bruno Kremer and Johan Fablet. It is based in Paris, France. They develop games for PC, console, mobile and VR.

A media company with over 70 years of history, Ziff Davis was at one time the owner of websites 1UP.com, GameVideos.com, and FileFront, as well as gaming magazines EGM, GMR, and Computer Gaming Monthly. All of their gaming properties were either sold off or shut down during the 2000s and today the company deals exclusively in technology and computer application magazines.

MAUS Software was founded in 1995 and its headquarters are in Bochum, Germany. The company is comprised of an international team of software writers/developers, artists, and engineers. The company's products have been published in 60 versions in Germany, Great Britain, France, USA, Benelux, Ukraine, Spain, Russia and Turkey. Besides being the developer of games, Maus offers infotainment and edutainment titles, productivity and learning software, system utilities and localization services. Their proprietary 3D engine is named Whirlwind with which the game Battle of Europe was made. In 2006 the name soft Xpansion GmbH & Co. KG was registered as the new company name.

thatgamecompany is a game development studio founded by University of Southern California Interactive Media Division students Kellee Santiago and Jenova Chen. It was established after the success of Chen's online flash game flOw. It became the first of three PlayStation Network downloable games for the PS3, positioning the company as a second-party developer for Sony. Previously, they also created the game Cloud (2005). Focusing on stylish visuals and unusual game design, the company's second title for Sony, Flower, was released in 2009 as an downloadable title exclusive to the PlayStation 3. A third title, Journey, was released in 2012. Shortly after the release of the game, in March 2012, co-founder Kellee Santiago announced to leave the studio on amicable terms. Other people who left the studio around the same time were producer Robin Hunicke, Chris Bell and John Nesky. In June 2012 the company announced that after the three-game deal with Sony future projects would become multiplatform to reach a larger audience. First released on iOS in 2019, Sky: Children of the Light marks the company's fourth game and first foray into the mobile gaming market.

2Awesome Partners is a publishing label of 2Awesome Studio. Announced on 20th May 2020, 2Awesome Partners helps developers publishing their games on multiple platforms providing porting and quality services as well.

2D Boy is an independent game studio located in San Francisco (USA) established in 2006. The core team originally consisted of Ron Carmel and Kyle Gabler, both former employees of Electronic Arts. They were later joined by Allan Blomquist, also coming from EA. The company's first game, World of Goo, was released in October 2008. At the Independent Game Festival in 2008, it won in the categories Design Innovation and Technical Excellence.

Accolade is a publishing label named after the Accolade company which was absorbed in 1999 by Infogrames (later Atari). It was revived in June 2017 by Billion Soft (Hong Kong) Limited, before being bought back by Atari in April 2023.

Active Enterprises Ltd. was likely formed in 1989, the year in which, according to their company information from 1993, the idea for Action 52 was formed. The company, formed by Vince Perri and Raul Gomila was based out of Florida with a headquarters in the Bahamas. In 1991 Active released their initial videogame title "Action 52" to the market. General information would tell us that based on its rarity it must not have sold well, but no sales figures exist. In early 1992, Active trademarked several of its creations such as, Cheetahmen, and Action 52. By 1993, Active had contracted California based company Farsight Technologies (now FarSight Studios) to create Action 52 for the Sega Genesis and SNES as well as Sports 5.  In 1993 Active published their first and only Sega Genesis cartridge, Action 52. It took advantage of the sixteen bit power of the Genesis to provide a significant graphics and sound upgrade to the 1991 NES original. The release of Action 52 for the Super Nintendo likely would have provided a superior game to the Genesis version but it wasn't released, nor was the Action Gamemaster or either version of Sports 5.  By the time 1994 rolled around Active had apparently left the video game market. What happened to Active Enterprises after this is really anyone's guess. What we do know is that they merged with Ivan Koulakovski's company "Voice Technologies" and that Vince Perri left the company a short time afterward. [Source: Cheetahmen Corner]
Airdorf Games is the name used for the titles by the independent developer Mason Smith. The studio is best known for the FAI✝H horror game series.

Airtight Games was a game development studio established in 2004 and formed around the core team that worked on Crimson Skies: High Road to Revenge. It was based in Redmond, Washington (USA). Key members of the studio included Jim Deal, Matt Brunner, Jared Noftle and Ed Fries. On 17th October 2007 the studio's first title was announced: Dark Void (2010), for Capcom. In August 2011 a second title was announced, the physics puzzler Quantum Conundrum (2012). In 2014 two more games were released: Soul Fjord for the OUYA and next Murdered: Soul Suspect. In early July 2014 the studio was officially closed.
